column1: Gore and his wife Tipper were driving from Nashville to a farm 50 miles east of the city. They stopped for dinner at a Shoney's, a low-cost family restaurant chain. A waitress recognized the couple and said they were former Vice President Al Gore and Tipper Gore.

CNN's John Defterios writes a weekly column on the state of the news in the world. This week, he writes about his trip to Nigeria to meet with a group of young people. He says he was inspired by the young people he met in the country.

Gore: I want to focus on what many of you have said you would like me to elaborate on: What can you do about the climate crisis? Gore: I add new images, because I learn more about it every time I give it. Gore: "It's like beach-combing, you know?"

There is more global warming pollution that comes from buildings than from cars and trucks. Most of these expenditures are also profitable. Carbon Capture and Sequestration is likely to become the killer app that will enable us to continue to use fossil fuels in a way that is safe.

CNN's John Defterios: Be a green consumer. He says it's easier than you think. There is a carbon calculator, he says. He urges people to make a decision to live a carbon-neutral life. Defterio: Those of you who are good at branding, I'd love to get your advice.

Climate change is a global issue, and we need to take action to address it. We need to make our businesses carbon-neutral, and invest sustainably. We also need to teach others, learn about it, talk about it. I am personally going to train people to give this slideshow -- re-purposed.

Support the idea of capping carbon dioxide emissions -- global warming pollution -- and trading it. Become politically active. Make our democracy work the way it's supposed to work. The role of logic and reason no longer includes mediating between wealth and power.

President Obama: Let's re-brand global warming, as many of you have suggested. "This is not a political issue. It's a true story -- every bit of this is true," Obama says. Obama: "We have to buy a lot of those ads"

Fossil fuels are not available, and solar energy doesn't cook the way that they like. The idea was that you could take waste paper and make it into fuel. But this device was very slow to work with, so students made their own. They were able to triple the efficiency.

Haitian students have developed a way to turn waste from sugarcane into charcoal. The waste is called "bagasse" and has no other use. It's too fine and it burns too quickly to be useful for cooking. But it can be used to make a very thick, sticky porridge, which you can use to bind together the charcoal.

The project has the potential to make a huge impact around the world. It addresses one of the biggest health issues on the planet, the number one cause of death in children under five. Kids and women are especially affected by it, because they're the ones who are around the cooking fires.

Scientists have developed a way to make a stronger briquette to compete with wood charcoal in the markets in Haiti. In Haiti alone, about 30 million trees are cut down every year. There's a possibility of this being implemented and saving a good portion of those.

CNN's John Defterios traveled to Ghana last month. He found a way to use agricultural waste material to create a cooking fuel. The technology transfer is so easy, he says, it's "the most exciting thing in my life right now"

This is one of the incredibly rare situations where you also have economic benefits. People can make their own cooking fuel from waste products. They can generate income from this. It's really rare that you don't have trade-offs between health and economics, or environment and economics.

If this were Afghanistan, only one person in this room would know how the use the Internet. If this were Zambia, 100 of you would have AIDS or HIV. These are the issues that we need to come up with solutions for.

Amy Smith: We're working on ways to do low-cost water quality testing. Smith: It's a difficult thing -- it's a marketplace which is very fragmented and a consumer population with no income. The other thing is you have to do things with a long time frame, Smith says.

The majority of the world neither benefits from capitalism nor from democratic systems. Most of the globe experiences the state as repressive. Tens of billions of dollars are supposedly spent on building capacity with people who are paid up to 1,500 dollars a day.

Economics taught in most of the elite universities are practically useless in my context. We have three critical terms: economy, civil society and the state. If we are to call the tyranny of assumptions into question, then we must be willing to subject our own assumptions to debate.

The least important form of capital, in this project, is financial capital -- money. Money is not capital in most of the developing countries. The first challenge is to rethink, fundamentally, the issue of the time. The absolute majority of the world's population are below 20.

Ashraf Ghani was finance minister of Afghanistan until recently. Ghani: "What scares me most is -- is you, lack of your engagement" Chris Anderson: "I hope that this group would be able to deal with the issue of state and development"

Afghanistan has been subjected to one of the most immense, brutal forms of exercise of power. The Red Army for 10 continuous years, 110,000 strong, literally terrorizing the country. The sky: every Afghan sees the sky as a source of fear.

Afghanistan is one of the most dangerous countries in the world. The country has a long history of violence, but has also made progress in recent years. The U.S. government is working with the Afghan government to improve the country's infrastructure.

Clare Lockhart: "I think what we'll do is we'll see a successful, very successful, private space flight industry" "The question now, however, is both about which form of capitalism and which type of democratic participation," she says. "We have real specific instructions here not to talk about politics"

NACA, before NASA, never developed an airliner and never ran an airline. NASA is developing the space liner, always has, and runs the only space line. "We've shied away from it because we're afraid of it," he says.

CNN's John Defterios looks back at the first 100 years of aviation. He says it's a long way from the days of the Wright brothers and the Wright Brothers. Defterio: "We're entering a second generation of no progress in terms of human flight in space"

The most impressive airplane ever, I believe, was designed only a dozen years after the first operational jet. These things tend to happen every 25 years, with an overlap. You don't have innovation cycles if the government develops and the government uses it.

SpaceShipOne CEO: "I've looked for innovation cycles in space; I found none" In 2003, everyone that the U.S. sent to space was killed. "We know how to do it for sub-orbital flying now, do it safe enough -- at least as safe as the early airlines," he says.

Rutan: "I can't tell you when this will start, because I don't want my competition to know my schedule" Rutan: The moon doesn't have an atmosphere -- you can do an elliptical orbit and miss it by 10 feet if you want.

The U.S. is making progress on space exploration. The space race was won by the Soviet Union in the 1950s and 1960s. The U.N. is now making progress in the field of space exploration, says Dr. Richard Branson.
CNN's John Sutter says the U.S. has a long way to go before it can compete with Russia in space. Sutter: "I think we're going to have to wait a long time to see if we can do it"

Cars are not a suit of clothes; cars are an avatar. Cars are an expansion of yourself: they take your thoughts, your ideas, your emotions, and they multiply it -- your anger, whatever. It's true that the trust and the love, that makes it worthwhile.

Every car you see out there is sculpted by hand. The tension, that discovery, that push for something new -- and at the same time, that sense of obligation to the regards of craftsmanship -- that's as strong in cars as it is in anything.

Car designers don't have a problem talking about truth or beauty in that sense. We're not trying to find vanity and beauty, we're trying tofind the beauty in the truth. We don't do coffee table books with just one lamp inside of it.

BMW design boss: "I discovered something about love and design through a project called Deep Blue" "We're interested in finding beauty that's more than just an aesthetic; it's really a truth," she says. "I think this idea of soul, as being at the heart of great cars, is very applicable"

BMW chief executive says the company has to have a shared intimacy with its designers. "We are all a little bit like Pygmalion, we are completely in love with our own creations," he says. "You want to do cars, you've got to go outside to do them," he adds.

CNN's John Defterios has been working on a project with a team of engineers in Germany. They are trying to come up with a way to make a car that is more like an SUV. The project is called "Deep Blue" and the team is called the "Engineers of the Future"

CNN's John Defterios traveled to Malibu, California, to meet with engineers working on a car design project. The team lived in Elizabeth Taylor's ex-house for six months as they worked on the project. Defterio: "I was hoping that these two teams would get together, and this collusion of incredible creativity"

CNN's John Defterios has been working on a project with a team of engineers. They are trying to solve a problem that has been going on for more than a decade. The problem is that they can't agree on how to solve the problem.

"I went nuts. I screamed at them, I yelled at them," he says of BMW's designers. "What the hell is going on around here?" he asks. "I went into these people; how could they take BMW's money and produce nothing?"

Less than 5,000 microbial species have been characterized as of two years ago. The Sorcerer II Expedition is trying to sample the ocean every 200 miles. The experiments are incredibly simple. We just take seawater and we filter it, and we collect different size organisms on different filters.

Scientists have mapped more than half of all the genes on the planet. They hope to use this data to understand the origin of life on Earth. Scientists are now beginning to write the code for life on the Earth. The first step is to find out what genes are involved in life.

The first sequence of a free-living organism was published 10 years ago. The pool expanded even more when we looked at core sets of genes of around 310 or so. The only way to prove these ideas was to construct an artificial chromosome with those genes in them.

synthesizing accurate DNA in large pieces was extremely difficult. Ham Smith and Clyde Hutchison developed an exciting new method that allowed them to synthesize a 5,000-base pair virus in only a two-week period. The real concern that security departments have is designer viruses.

Scientists have created a synthetic genome that can take three million rads of radiation and not be killed. It reassembles its genome after this radiation burst in about 12 to 24 hours, after its chromosomes are literally blown apart. The first step is just transplanting them into a cell without a genome. Scientists think synthetic cells are going to have tremendous potential.

We're trying to modify photosynthesis to produce hydrogen directly from sunlight. We're also combining cellulases, the enzymes that break down complex sugars into simple sugars and fermentation in the same cell for producing ethanol. We think we can make a million different chromosomes a day. And we're going to be able to do this by the end of the century.

Apple's iPod violated every bit of common wisdom, says former CEO Steve Jobs. The lesson was: simplicity sells, and there are signs that the world is getting the message, he says. The Sonos thing -- it's catching on, Jobs says.

When you have a digital camera, how do you get the pictures back to your computer? Well, you either haul around a USB cable, or you buy a card reader and haul that around. What I do is, I take out the memory card, and I fold it in half, revealing USB contacts. I just stick it in the computer, offload the pictures, put it right back in the camera.
"Spot the TED Presenter Who Used to Be a Broadway Accompanist" premieres Tuesday at 8 p.m. ET on TED.com. The show also airs on PBS stations in the U.S. and Canada.

CNN's John Sutter writes a weekly technology column for the New York Times. Sutter says he's always been a technology nut, and he loves the column. He says the column comes with a downside: he gets a lot of email from frustrated readers.

The problem is, ironically, because the industry has put so much thought into making things easier to use, he says. He calls it "software rage" People are feeling overwhelmed. There's not enough thought put into the design of it to make it easy and enjoyable to use.

Apple's new voice-recognition software is making it easier for people to use voice-activated devices. The company has recorded calls to collect the funniest dumb user stories and pass them around on a CD. "Some of the stories are just so classic, and yet so understandable," he says.

Software is subject to another primal force: the mandate to release more and more versions. Software is not like buying a vase or a candy bar, where you own it. It's more like joining a club where you pay dues every year, and every year they say, "We've added more features"

Microsoft Word was last just a word processor in the Eisenhower administration. Software companies make 35 percent of their revenue from just these software upgrades. As you add more features, where are you going to stick them? You only have so many design tools.

Apple and Microsoft have a severely divergent approach to software design. Microsoft's approach to simplicity tends to be: let's break it down; let's just make it more steps. If they continue at this pace, there's absolutely no telling where they might wind up.

The Type a Word Wizard lets users type letters from a drop-down menu. It's designed to be as consistent as possible with real-world equivalents. The tool is available on Windows 8.1 and later versions will be available on Mac and iOS.

Apple is not the only company that has embraced the cult of simplicity, he says. Palm is also, especially in the old days, wonderful about this, he adds. "If any task on the Palm Pilot takes more than three taps of the stylus, it's too long, and it has to be redesigned"

Apple CEO Tim Cook: "I write the code that makes the whole world run" Cook: Every software company is doing Microsoft's R&D. "I put my software and IBM together; I got profit and they got the loss," Cook says.

Microsoft's new Windows 8 operating system is designed to work with existing software. The new operating system has been designed to make it easier for people to use Microsoft's software. Microsoft's Windows 8 software is meant to be used in conjunction with other software, not in its own right.

Apple co-founder Steve Jobs returns to the company after a 12-year absence. Jobs: "Don't cry for me, Cupertino. The truth is, I never left you" "I made a fortune over at Pixar. I know the ropes now, know what the tricks are," Jobs says.

The architect says the project is "substantially different from anything we'd ever thought about doing before" The goal was not to create something that would be there longer than it needed to be, he says. "Having it come out of actually seeing it in a real encounter, I think makes it a more powerful dialogue"

The World Trade Center site in New York City is set to be closed for six months. The city is trying to find a solution to the problem of how to keep the site open. The project is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

"I think there's a real opportunity to engage in a discussion of why we live in cities," says Mayor Bloomberg. "I don't think it has much to do with 50 or 60 or 70 or 80 thousand new office spaces," he adds. "We're looking for other things," he says.

The memorial was designed to be written on. The scaffolding you can see built up over the street is de-mountable. Ground Zero is unlike most any other tourist site in America. The kind of virtually instantaneous nature of its erection, and its being there, is part of its extraordinary presence.

David Rockwell is a New York-based architect. His work is highly sensual, even hedonistic. Rockwell: "I like that word 'hedonistic' ... it's about pleasure" The walls are bare by design so people can fill them with their own memorials.

"We had to find a way to make this happen," says the designer. "It was just extraordinary," he says. "We were able to do it in a few days." "It's not about winning or losing, it's about making a difference," he adds.

The city of New York is rebuilding a pier on the Hudson River. The project is called PS 234. The city is trying to make the pier more accessible to all residents. It is the first time the city has rebuilt a pier since World War II.

Dan Rather: I went down there with Rick and Liz and Kevin, and I've got to say, it was the most moving experience of my life. It was devastating to see the simple plywood platform with a rail around it, where the families of the victims had left notes to them. And it was amazing how much harder it was to believe in real life than it was on TV.

A half a million dollar project was needed to rebuild the World Trade Center. A developer who owns Rockefeller Center volunteered to underwrite the entire expense. The prices from the contractors were between five to 700,000 dollars. Now, as CBS's Jim Axelrod reports, they're putting the finishing touches on a new way to visit and view the scene.

Jim Axelrod: People were amazed at the destruction, but there was a sense of disbelief about the heroics of New Yorkers. Axelrod spent a lot of time in putting this together, watching the crowds that gathered at Saint Paul. The next day I got an email from the developer saying that he was withdrawing all funding.

"We knew that one way or another this was going to happen," says project leader. "It's all incredibly humble. It's all scaffolding and plywood. It doesn't have to be this way," he adds. "We want it to be a place for people to sit and reflect"

The iBOT was designed to be quick, cheap, safe, respectful and flexible. It can be attached to a kilogram of propane, and you could drive from New York to Boston if you so choose. The design was inspired by a kind of "Eat, drink, and be merry, for tomorrow we die" sense of existence.

It takes 25.3 kilowatt -- 25,000 watts of continuous power -- to make 10 gallons an hour of distilled water. The big idea here is, I think, a new piece of a solution to a fairly big problem in transportation.

The car was the clean environmental alternative to a horse and buggy. 50 percent of the global population now lives in cities. We've solved all the transportation problems that have changed the world to get it to where we are today. We don't compete with airplanes, or cars.

CNN's John Defterios says people shouldn't sit down in cities. He says the last mile is the problem, and half the world now lives in dense cities. China alone is going to move four to six hundred million people into cities in the next decade and a half.

In China, in the year 1998, 417 million people used bicycles; 1.7 million used cars. In 5,000 years, we've gone backwards in getting around cities. The most expensive real estate on this planet in every city is their downtowns. We can make it complicated, but what's the world fighting over?

Cities should make it easier for pedestrians to get to and from their cars, says U.S. mayor. "We're a recreational vehicle that doesn't really matter, and I don't spend my time doing that kind of stuff," he says. "Or maybe we should be out in the street in front of a Greyhound bus"

"We've been working really, really hard, but we knew that the technology would not be as hard to develop as an attitude about what's important," he says. "I'm happy, really, I am happy to talk about this technology as much as you want," he adds.

In the next 20 years, all human population growth on this planet will be in cities. Cars were not meant for parallel parking; they're wonderful machines to go between cities. The Greeks went from the theater of Dionysus to the Parthenon in their sandals. You do it in your sneakers.

CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta says people are starting to eat like us, and live like us. Gupta: We're harming ourselves around the world, as well as harming the animals. He says we need to spend time with Mother Nature, where there are trees for our good.

CNN's Jim Boulden talks about the plight of chimpanzees in the developing world. He started a program called Roots and Shoots to raise awareness of the animals' plight. "Roots make a firm foundation. Shoots seem tiny, but to reach the sun they can break through brick walls"
CNN's John Defterios is the host of a new series on CNN.com, "This Is Life With Defterius" The series, which premieres tonight at 9pm ET on CNN, focuses on the role of young people in the world.

Roots and Shoots is already in 60-plus countries, with about 5,000 active groups. The philosophy is very simple. We do not believe in violence. No violence, no bombs, no guns. That's not the way to solve problems.

CNN's John Defterios talks to young people in the U.S. about the need for change in the world. He says it's important for young people to learn how to deal with the challenges they face in life. Defterio: "We can do this. We can make a difference in this world"

"We can see a whole area desolated, and it can be brought back to bloom again," says Nelson Mandela. "If you look back through human history, you see that every evil has been overcome by good," he says. "We are all part of the same human family," he adds.

CNN's John Defterios has been working on a new series on CNN.com called "This Is Life" He says the series will look at how the internet has changed the way we see the world. The series will also look at the impact of technology on the way the world is viewed.

When he was at school, we were defined as man, the toolmaker. We now know that at Gombe alone, there are nine different ways in which chimpanzees use different objects for different purposes. And because it seems that these patterns are passed from one generation to the next, through observation, imitation and practice -- that is a definition of human culture.

Chimpanzees are capable of true compassion and altruism. They show emotions, similar to those we feel. They're fighting to develop their own way of living in a world that isn't contaminated. They have a sense of humor, and these are the kind of things which traditionally have been thought of as human.

CNN's John Defterios talks about the impact of deforestation in Africa. He says people are losing their homes, livelihoods and livelihoods because of clear-cutting. "We see the desert spreading; we see massive hunger and we see population growth in areas where there are more people living"

"We are abusing this great power we have to be wise stewards, and we're destroying the world," he says. "We can talk about the distant past, plan for the distant future, discuss ideas with each other, so that the ideas can grow from the accumulated wisdom of a group"

I really believe that the human body is very, very smart, and we can't counteract something the body is saying to do. It's different when a bacteria comes into the body -- that's a foreign object -- we want that out. So even to go from there, it's possible, although far-fetched, that in the future we could almost think of cancer being used as a therapy.

"It's really an honor and a privilege to be here," says Dr. Michael Schubert. Schupert has been studying the effects of heavy metals on the nervous system. He found that they can inhibit the growth of cells in the brain.

Cancer is a direct result of damage to an organ. The body is trying to repair the damage. Stem cells have the ability to differentiate into any type of tissue. It's almost as if the body has originated this ingenious response, but can't control it.

Cancer doesn't seem to originate in skeletal muscles, but metastases do. "It's almost as if we're getting back to this starting point. We're removing the cancer cells, but we're revealing the previous damage that the body has tried to fix" "If somehow we can cause these cells to differentiate ... it would be a repair process"

Skeletal -- metastasis to skeletal muscle -- is very rare. No one seemed to be asking why. So I decided to ask why. Some of my hypotheses are that when you first think about skeletal muscle, there's a lot of blood vessels going to skeletal Muscle.

Cancer is a complex system -- and there's something called the chemokine network. Without angiogenesis, the tumor remains the size of a pinpoint and it's not harmful. When skeletal muscle is injured, that's what causes chemokines, the "go signs" for the tumors.

There are so many possibilities for why tumors don't go to skeletal muscle. skeletal muscle has a factor in it called "MyoD" that causes cells to differentiate into muscle cells. MyoD has been tested on a lot of different cell types and been shown to convert this variety of cell types into skeletal Muscle cells.

RSW: "They just brought us there to hustle this group, you know, to create a project" RSW: Luckily, I'm old enough that I can complain I can't travel. "I don't have my own plane yet," he says.

Mullis: "I've never really gone out looking for work. And I realized when I'd come into the meetings with these corrugated metal and chain link stuff, and people would just look at me like I'd just landed from Mars" "It's one of the great dilemmas in creativity: how to do work that's big enough and not.

When he was 14 his parents bought him a chemistry set and he decided to make water. He bought a tiny little bungalow in Santa Monica and for like 50 grand I built a house around it. "I just found out the world ain't going to last that long, this guy was telling us the other day"

Every day is a new thing for me. I approach each project with a new insecurity, almost like the first project I ever did, and I get the sweats, I'm not sure where I'm going, I wouldn't do it. When Bilbao was finished and I saw all the mistakes, I saw ... they weren't mistakes; I saw everything that I would have changed.

Disney Hall will be finished in 2003 -- September, October -- and I'm hoping Kyu, and Herbie, and Yo-Yo and all those guys come play with us at that place. Richard Koshalek is probably one of the main reasons that Disney Hall came to me. He's been a cheerleader for quite a long time.

The building was designed by Portuguese architect Alvaro Siza, who is considered the Portuguese main guy in architecture. Siza's early work had a resemblance to the architect's own early work, he says. "I had an explosion. And the glass -- luckily I turned around -- I had it all in my back and I was about 15 feet away," he recalls.

I like the idea of collaboration with people like that because it pushes you. I've done it with Claes Oldenburg and with Richard Serra, who doesn't think architecture is art. It's like jazz: you improvise, you work together, you play off each other.

Richard Rogers: "The surprise of Bilbao was in its context to the city" "If you can get a bunch of people who respect each other's work and play off each other, you might be able to create models for how to build sections of the city without resorting to the one architect"

"If you don't meet the budgets, you're not going to get much work," he says. "It's like gravity. And it's like saying all that, it means your work is good somehow" "There wasn't a leak in the building," he adds. "I was clean. I was clean"

Wright's fame was built on his work in L.A. for a while. Wright is also a software engineer. He is trying to find a way of making the computer into a personal mode of expression. He says he has no plans to return to architecture.

The artist says he's trying to find a personal way of using the computer. He says the computer makes possible much more than what most people think. The artist's work will be on display at the Whitney Biennial next week, and also at Bitforms Gallery in Chelsea.

With orgasm you get a spike of dopamine. Dopamine's associated with romantic love, and you can just fall in love with somebody who you're just having casual sex with. You can feel deep attachment to a long-term partner while you feel intense romantic love for somebody else.

Over 100 million prescriptions of antidepressants are written every year in the United States. These drugs are going generic. They are seeping around the world. I know one girl who's been on these antidepressants, SSRIs, serotonin-enhancing antidepressants -- since she was 13.

"A world without love is a deadly place" "I'm an identical twin; I am interested in why we're all alike" "You can list what you don't like about them, but then you sweep that aside and focus on what you do"

Researchers have found that mystery elevates dopamine in the brain, pushing you over the threshold to fall in love. You gravitate to certain people, actually, with somewhat complementary brain systems. In trying to understand romantic love, I decided I would read poetry from all over the world. I just want to give you one very short poem from eighth-century China.

A man invited a girl to go on a rickshaw ride with him. He figured that this would drive up the dopamine, and she'd fall in love with him, he says. The sex drive, romantic love and attachment to a long-term partner are embedded in the human brain.

Love is an intense craving to be with a particular person, not just sexually, but emotionally. The motor in the brain begins to crank, and you want this person. The whole point of this is to pull two people together strongly enough to begin to rear babies as a team.

Psychologist says he was "stunned" when he learned that love is not an emotion, but a drive. He asked his patients: "What percentage of the day and night do you think about this person?" They replied: "All day. All night. I can never stop thinking about him"

Love is one of the most powerful brain systems on Earth for both great joy and great sorrow. W.H. Auden called it an "intolerable neural itch," and indeed, that's what it is. In over 175 societies, people have left their evidence of this powerful brain system.

Love evolved to enable you to focus your mating energy on just one individual at a time, thereby conserving mating time and energy. Women are moving back into the job market, and they are very slowly closing that gap between men and women in terms of economic power.

For millions of years, on the grasslands of Africa, women commuted to work to gather their vegetables. With the beginning of plow agriculture, men's roles became extremely powerful. Women lost their ancient jobs as collectors, but with the industrial revolution and the post-industrial revolution they're moving back into the job market.

Women's verbal ability goes up in the middle of the menstrual cycle, when estrogen levels peak. Even at menstruation, they're better than the average man. "To have a great writer is to have another government," Solzhenitsyn once said.

Men tend to be more creative. Women tend to have a more linear mind. Men tend to think in terms of the future. Women think about the past. Men think in the present. Women see the past and future. Men see the present and future, women see future.

Women start sooner at sex, have more partners, express less remorse for the partners that they do, marry later, have fewer children, leave bad marriages in order to get good ones. The 21st century is going to be the century of what they call the "symmetrical marriage," or the "pure marriage"

The older you get, the less likely you are to divorce. The divorce rate right now is stable in America, and it's actually beginning to decline. Green chemistry is replacing our industrial chemistry with nature's recipe book. It's not easy, because life uses only a subset of the elements.

Vaccines can't be refrigerated because the "cold chain" gets broken. Bruce Rosner found a way to dry out vaccines -- encase them in the same sort of sugar capsules as the tardigrade has within its cells. This is a session about water -- learning about organisms that can do without water.

Christopher Anderson: "I came this close to changing species at that moment" "We have to grow the capacity of this planet to create more and more opportunities for life," he says. "That means, you know, net fertility farming," Anderson adds.

Janine Krieg: Life creates conditions conducive to life. Krieg's new book, "Biomimicry," looks at what life might teach us in technology and in design. She says we have to find a way to meet our needs, while making of this place an Eden. "We want a biologist to sit at the design table to help us, in real time, become inspired," she says.

Researchers are trying to stop the build-up of minerals inside of pipes. They are using an organism to do your wastewater treatment is an old, old technology called "domestication" "Domestication is learning something, learning an idea, from an organism and then applying it," he says.

Al Gore: Engineers realized that the answers to their questions are everywhere. He says they just needed to change the lenses with which they saw the world. Gore: It's not slavishly mimicking, it's taking the design principles, the genius of the natural world.

Computer scientists have learned an enormous amount from living things, on the software side. "How does life make things? This is the opposite; this is how we make things" "How do we redesign the world that we make, the human-made world? More importantly, what should we ask in the next 10 years?"

Life adds information to matter. It gives it information. And its shape is what gives it the function of being able to tumble through air so easily. And how does life make things disappear into systems? Because life doesn't really deal in things; there are no things in the natural world divorced from their systems.

CNN's John Sutter looks at a process that makes tough ceramics out of seawater. Sutter: Imagine being able to make all of our hard materials that way. The process is being mimicked at Sandia National Labs, he says.

We Feel Fine scans the world's newly-posted blog entries for occurrences of the phrases "I feel" or "I am feeling" The color of each particle corresponds to the type of feeling inside, so that happy, positive feelings are brightly colored. And sad, negative feelings are darkly colored.

The six words represent the six movements of We Feel Fine. There's also Murmurs, Montage, Mobs, Metrics and Mounds. You can click any of these to go out and visit the blog from which it was collected.

Mobs provide statistical breakdowns of the population of the world's feelings in the last few hours. "Better" is the most frequent feeling right now, followed by "good," "bad," "guilty," "right," "down," "sick" and so on.

The final movement is called Mounds. Mounds visualizes the entire dataset as large, gelatinous blobs which kind of jiggle. You can see the little pink cursor moving along, representing our position. There's also a search capability, if you're interested in finding out about a certain population.

Each ant experiences a stream of contacts with other ants. The pattern of these interactions determines whether the ant comes back out. The rate at which ants come back depends on all the little things that happen to an ant as it goes out and does its task outside.

In a small colony, an ant is likely to meet another forager every three seconds. In a larger colony, the ant will meet fewer foragers. This pattern of interaction allows the ants to make more offspring. This is the way the ants make their own offspring.

An ant starts as an egg, then it's a larva. Then they're pupae, then they come out as adult ants. They go out, they get the food, they dig the nest, and the queen never comes out again. They make a midden, a pile of refuse.

An ant colony grows to a size of about 10 or 12 thousand ants when the colony is five. colony size changes as a function of colony age, in years. When extra food becomes available, extra ants are allocated to collect the food.

There are about 10,000 species of ants. They all live in colonies consisting of one or a few queens, and then all the ants you see walking around are sterile female workers. An ant starts out somewhere near the queen. When we dig up nests we find they're about as deep as the colony is wide.

At any time about half the ants in the colony are just doing nothing. The queen's in there somewhere; she just lays eggs. The larvae, and they consume most of the food. The foragers come in with food, they just drop it into the upper chamber.

No ant directs the behavior of any other ant. The queen just lays the eggs. There's no management. No queen tells anybody what to do. No ant can send chemical messages through a network of chambers to tell the ants outside what they should do.

The different tasks are interdependent. The same ant doesn't do the same task over and over its whole whole life. If I put out extra food, everybody else -- the midden workers stop doing midden work and go get the food, they become foragers. If there's more patrolling to do, the nest maintenance workers will switch to patrol.

The ants in the older colony that seem to be more stable are not any older than the ant in the younger colony. It's not due to the experience of older, wiser ants. Instead, something about the organization must be changing as the colony gets older. The obvious thing that's changing is its size.

Ants are using a network of antennal contact. When one ant touches another, it's smelling it, and it can tell, for example, whether the other ant is a nest mate. Ants cover themselves and each other, through grooming, with a layer of grease, which carries a colony-specific odor.

Players create content in the game that is automatically sent up to a server and redistributed to all the other players transparently. The computer is procedurally animating this creature. It's looking at whatever I've designed. It will actually bring it to life. But that's not what I want to talk about today.

This is the first stage of the game. The game is supposed to be played out over time. It's a game that lets the player control a character. The player controls the character and the environment around him or her. The goal is to create a world that the player can control.

This is more about putting the player in the role of George Lucas. Things like the buildings, the vehicles, the architecture, civilizations were all designed by the player up to this point. I want them, after they've played this game, to have extracted an entire world that they're now interacting with.

In the game, the player can pump more CO2 into the atmosphere. Over time, this is going to heat up the planet. At some point it's going to get so hot the oceans will evaporate. The game is the sequel to "An Inconvenient Truth," in about two minutes.

African fractal geometry wasn't invented until the 1970s. Some African fractals are, as far as I'm concerned, just pure intuition. Some of these things, I'd wander around the streets of Dakar asking people, "What's the algorithm? What's the rule for making this?"

All over Africa, you see this board game called Owari. It's called Mancala here on the East Coast, Bao in Kenya, Sogo elsewhere. And the folks in Ghana knew about these self-organizing patterns and would use them strategically. So this is very conscious knowledge.

The most complex example of an algorithmic approach to fractals that I found was actually not in geometry, it was in a symbolic code, and this was Bamana sand divination. The same divination system is found all over Africa. You can find it on the East Coast as well as the West Coast.

Superstring theory is a new approach to unify the laws of physics. The theory has nothing to do at first sight with the idea of extra dimensions. But when we study superstring theory, we find that it resurrects the idea in a sparkling, new form.

The universe is built up of a huge number of tiny filaments of vibrating energy, vibrating in different frequencies. Theory of string theory doesn't work in a universe with four dimensions of space, nor five, nor six. It doesn't even work if the universe is small enough to hide the extra dimensions. So where do we go? There are about 20 numbers that really describe our universe.

String theory suggests that those 20 numbers have to do with the extra dimensions. If those numbers had any other values than the known ones, the universe, as we know it, wouldn't exist. This is an example of something known as a Calabi-Yau shape -- name isn't all that important.

In string theory, all the numbers are reflections of the way strings can vibrate. If we could calculate the allowed vibrational patterns, we should be able to calculate those 20 numbers. Pygmy: "I can't go back to my area -- it's more than 1,000 kilometers [away] I stayed after they looted everything" "I'm not going to the east, because I don't know Swahili. I stay. If I go, I will be killed," he says.

From 14 to 17 he was assisting poachers in the Congo. He now works at Makerere University in the capital, Kinshasa. He says the war in Congo has killed millions of Congolese because of mineral extraction. But he says he has been able to save his life and that of his staff.

"We have to meet and to talk to them about what is the regulation of the parks," he says. "We don't think so. We have to do it, because to let our animals advance is not acceptable" "We are trying to protect our people and our land," he adds. "And we are not going to give up."

I had only this equipment -- my satellite phone, my computer and a plastic solar panel -- that I hide it in the forest. I don't know how many people I had on my address. They started suspecting that what we do on the morning, and the afternoon, it's on the news.

"I was sending news, doing whatever, to the U.N., to our institution in New York," he says. "They didn't -- they was not looking on me. And I had mine on my pocket" "This is not local population, this is rebels. They are now happy sending the news that they have protected the Okapi with the war"

The AI isn't good enough to simulate a full human body. The body yes, but not all the motor skills that we have. We do have one unintentional dancer actually, the last thing I'm going to show you. He's actually a better dancer than I am, I have to say.

A new way of simulating the human body is being developed at Oxford University. The idea is to simulate the nervous system of a person. It's not quite there yet, but we're working on it, says researcher. The technology will be used to make computer games and movies.

Researchers used artificial evolution to simulate the nervous system that controls walking in humans. They created a neural network based on that part of the spine that we have in our spine. The tricky bit is now to put an AI controller in it that actually makes it work. The results were surprising.

The technology is simulating humans. It's simulated humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. At the beginning, it can't walk at all, but it will get better and better over time. After generation 20, it actually walks in a straight line without falling over.

The first thing the team had to work on was to create the human body, basically. It's very simple to add things like hair, clothes, etc., but what we've done here is use a very simple visualization, so you can concentrate on the movement.

It's one of the most successful games of all time. The reason for that is that there's no intelligence in it. The character now has motor skills in the upper body -- nothing in the legs yet, in this particular one. It falls over, but it falls over like a rag doll.

At the moment, you only have empty computer graphics in games. But what you'll see is that all the animations in this game are very repetitive. This is the first time the public sees this as well, because we have been in stealth mode.

Virtual stuntmen are being developed for film studios and games developers. The first product will be released in a couple of weeks. The virtual stuntman looks the same and is always reacting to his surroundings. The technology is expected to be available in the next few months.

The characters are actually not real characters. They are a graphical visualization of a character in midair. The realism we're achieving with this is good enough to be used in films. An animation studio in London is using our software and experimenting with it right now.

This is a real-life version of a stunt where a stuntman falls off a cliff. The stuntman is being controlled by a computer, which then animates the fall in real-time. This is the first time we've shown how this technique can be used in real time.

The technology could be used in video games, sports games and film. The first thing is going to be virtual stuntmen. Several studios are using this software now to produce virtual stuntman. It took about altogether just two hours, pretty much, to create the simulation.

Technology could be used to help surgeons who work on children with cerebral palsy. The degree of interactivity you're going to get is totally different, I think, from what you're getting right now. I've also had some meals that make me want to dry heave.

The author of "The Year of Living Biblically" has written a book on religion. He says he has a son and wants to teach him about the Bible. "I think it's the defining issue of our time," he says of religion.

"I decided to take the Bible to its logical conclusion," says author. "I just like to dive right in and become sort of a human being" "I wanted to follow the rules of the Bible," he says. "It's not just a list, it's a set of rules."

The author spent a year trying to be a better person. He tried to follow the Bible's laws of good and evil. He also spent a lot of time at airport security to keep his wife from kissing him. The book, "My Outsourced Life," is published by Harper Collins.

The Bible says that if you smile, you will become happier. "Cognitive dissonance" is a big part of the Bible. "You change your behavior, and you change your mind" is another. "I was able to stone one adulterer," he says.

CNN's John Sutter writes about his experience of stoning. Sutter: "It was the best month of my life, because I just sat back and I read books and watched movies" He asks: "How can the Bible be so barbaric in some places, and so incredibly wise in others?"

CNN's John Sutter meets with creationists at a museum in Kentucky. Sutter: "They were not stupid people at all. It's just that their faith is so strong in this literal interpretation of the Bible" "It was a wonderful experience. They really did a fantastic job," Sutter says of the museum.

CNN's John Sutter talks to CNN iReport about his year in the U.S. Sutter: "I started the year as an agnostic, and by the end of the year, I became what a reverent agnostic" "There's something important and beautiful about the idea of sacredness," he says.

CNN's Christiane Amanpour meets with Red Letter Christians, who say Jesus never talked about homosexuality. Amanpour: "I was shocked learning how much of my life is governed by irrational forces" Amanpour says Jim Wallis and Tony Campolo are inspiring leaders, even though she disagrees with some of their views.

"I tried to follow everything in the Bible. And I failed miserably. Because you can't. You have to pick and choose," he says. The key is to choose the right rituals, the ones that are not harmful. Rituals by themselves are not to be dismissed.

Scientists hope to find life in the universe in the next 10 years. If they do, they will be able to spread out into space. This could lead to the creation of a new planet, Europa, to live on. This would be a huge step forward for the future of science.

Most of the real estate in the solar system is very cold and very far from the Sun. The asteroids are a substantial amount of real estate, but not very large. Europa is one of the moons of Jupiter, where we see a very level ice surface. It's probably the most likely place for life to originate.

Life originated on Europa, and it was sitting in the ocean for billions of years. It's quite likely that it would move out of the ocean onto the surface, just as it did on the Earth. If life could be established out there, it would have all the essentials -- chemistry and sunlight.

Life on the surface of Jupiter's moon, Europa, is unlikely, but it could have come, says Neil deGrasse Tyson. The surface of Europa is 25 times fainter than it is in the United States, he says. Tyson: If there's life there, it would have to have a thick skin to protect itself from losing water.

The Sun is the only object in the universe that's close enough and bright enough actually to be detectable. The universe is full of all kinds of wonderful things radiating in the radio spectrum, much brighter than the Sun. So, the same thing could be true for this kind of life, which I'm talking about, on cold objects.

Life on Europa, or further out, anywhere where you can live on a cold surface, must be provided with reflectors. The further out you go in this, away from the Sun, the more powerful this reflection will be. So, in fact, you can look for these creatures with telescopes from the Earth.

The poem was told by an anonymous Kwakiutl Indian of southern Alaska to a missionary in 1896. Anthropologists have found evidence of romantic love in 170 societies. But love isn't always a happy experience. Almost nobody gets out of love alive.

Researchers have put 37 people who are madly in love into a functional MRI brain scanner. They found activity in a tiny, little factory near the base of the brain called the ventral tegmental area. The same brain region is active also when you feel the rush of cocaine.

Researchers found activity in the brain region associated with intense romantic love. The brain system for wanting, for motivation, for craving, for focus becomes more active when you can't get what you want. In this case, life's greatest prize: an appropriate mate.

Researchers found activity in a brain region associated with calculating gains and losses. The brain region becomes active when you're willing to take enormous risks for huge gains and huge losses. When you've been rejected in love, you're engulfed with feelings of romantic love.

"Romantic love is one of the most addictive substances on Earth" "There's not an animal on this planet that will copulate with anything that comes along" "If you're stuck in a box, you're not going to be as picky about who you have sex with"

"Love at first sight" is a real phenomenon, says Dr. Andrew Wexler. He says the brain area associated with love is still active 25 years later. "You can know every single ingredient in a chocolate cake, and then you can still feel that joy"

Psychologists don't know why we fall in love with one person rather than another. A new dating site asks people to rate their levels of dopamine, serotonin, estrogen and testosterone. 3.7 million people have taken the questionnaire in the U.S., and 600,000 in 33 countries.

Women get intimacy from face-to-face talking. Men get it from side-by-side doing. Faulkner said, "The past is not dead, it's not even past" "Love is in us. It's deeply embedded in the brain," he says.

After 1,300 years, these two lovers still touch and kiss from their tomb. The ancient writer of Ecclesiastes wrote, he said, there's every activity under heaven. There's a time to be born, and there's atime to die. Our challenge is to understand each other.

The first happy life is the pleasant life, says Seligman. The second is a life of engagement: a life in your work, your parenting, your love, your leisure. The third is the meaningful life, which includes family, friends, work and play.

The pleasant life, your experience of positive emotion, is about 50 percent heritable. Positive emotion habituates. American women said to Len, when he dated them, "You're no fun. You don't have positive emotion. Get lost."

When we find a fossil, we mark it. We mark it with a GPS fix, and we also take a digital photograph of the specimen. It's extremely time-consuming, labor-intensive and it is something that is going to involve a lot more people, to begin to piece together our past.

Two million years ago, Homo erectus lived in a region of Africa known as the Great Rift Valley. It is believed that the area is the only place in the world where the remains of this species can still be found. The area is thought to have been covered by a river that ran through it.

When I was 12, a very exciting expedition was in place on the west side of Lake Turkana, when they found essentially the skeleton of this Homo erectus. We are one species of about five and a half thousand mammalian species that exist on planet Earth today. I was very lucky to have been brought up in Kenya.

Homo erectus was the first human ancestor to leave Africa and begin its spread across the globe. He had a body very similar to our own, and he was on the threshold of becoming human. Homo erectus left Africa 90,000 generations ago. We evolved essentially from an African stock.

Human ancestors only survive on planet Earth for about a million years at a time. We have a much larger brain than our ape ancestors. We've got buggies to Mars; we've mapped the human genome; and recently even created synthetic life.

CNN's John Sutter talks about a project that scans the world's newly posted blog entries every two or three minutes. The project, "We Feel Fine," searches for occurrences of the phrases "I feel" and "I am feeling" The program also tries to identify demographic information about the author.

Dots represent some of the English-speaking world's feelings from the last few hours. Each dot is a single sentence stated by a single blogger. The color of each dot corresponds to the type of feeling inside, so the bright ones are happy, and the dark ones are sad.

"We Feel Fine" collects very, very small-scale personal stories. Weather causes the feelings to assume the physical traits of the weather they represent. "I feel like I'm diagonally parked in a parallel universe," one character says.

CNN's John Sutter spent nine days in Barrow, Alaska, photographing an Eskimo whaling camp. Sutter's new project is called "The Whale Hunt" Sutter: "I've become interested in diving much more deeply into a single story"

"The Whale Hunt" is a collection of 3,214 photographs taken by the photographer. The photographer used the photos to create a framework for the story. "I'm interested in collecting my own stories, stories from the Internet, and then stories from life, which is kind of a new area of work," he says.

This is the Arctic Ocean, and the butchering of the second whale, seven days later. You can see a timeline, showing you the exciting moments throughout the story. The Wheel provides a slightly more playful version of the same, so these are also all the photographs organized chronologically.

architectural practice SHoP is working on a large-scale camera obscura in a public park. The computer revolution, the technocratic, technological revolution, has allowed us to jettison normal-shaped buildings, traditionally shaped buildings, in favor of non-orthogonal buildings.

David Rockwell's work is not to create a technological solution, it's to seduce you into something that you can do. His Nobu restaurant in New York is supposed to take you from the clutter of New York City to the simplicity of Japan and the elegance of Japanese tradition. His Pod restaurant, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, is white.

The World Trade Center is a symbol of how technology has transformed culture, says TED Talk host. The next 5,000 days, it's not just going to be the Web but only better, says Google's Larry Page. "It will know us, and that's good. And again, the price of that will be transparency," he says.

CNN's John Sutter talks about the "one machine" that is the Internet. Sutter: "There's a unity of some sort that's starting to emerge" He says the Web is the "OS" of the Internet, and all screens look into the One.

The Internet, the Web as we know it, is already less than 5,000 days old. And it turned out that this machine happens to be the most reliable. It has not crashed; it's running uninterrupted. And there's almost no other machine that we've ever made.

The Web is running at seven terabytes per second, compared to the Library of Congress' twenty terabytes. A quadrillion transistors is almost the same as the number of neurons in your brain. By 2040, the total processing power of this machine will exceed a totalprocessing power of humanity, in raw bits.

Every screen in the world is looking into the one machine. The second thing is that -- some people call this the cloud, and you're kind of touching the cloud with this. And thirdly, we're going to become completely codependent upon it.

The Web is like a black hole that's sucking up everything into it. Every item, every artifact that we make, will have embedded in it some little sliver of Web-ness and connection. We have, basically, an Internet of things. Everything is connected to the Web.

In 5,000 days, all this stuff has come. The media wants to be liquid. So that the laws of media, such as the fact that copies have no value, the value's in the uncopiable things. The more you have, the more you get.

In the first stage of the Internet, computers were connected by links. In the second stage, pages were resolved into links. The third stage is where we link the data. "If I told you it was all coming for free, you would say, this is simply -- you're dreaming," he says.

Every person, every item will have a something that will be very specific, and will link to a specific representation of that idea or item. Every idea is basically being supported -- or every item, or every noun -- is being supported by the entire Web. So something will resolve down to the information about a particular person.

A semantic Web, Web 3.0, giant global graph -- we're trying out what we want to call this thing. But what's it's doing is sharing data. So you have to be open to having your data shared. And all these things that are going to be on this are not just pages, they are things.

If you allow Google to, it will tell you your search history. The closer it is, the better. "I am open, and being transparent to that will require total transparency," he says. "We're so dependent on this that I don't even try to remember things"

The brain processes information using 100,000 times less energy than we do right now with this computer technology that we have. The brain uses as much energy as your laptop computer: it's just 10 watts. So what we are doing with computers with the energy consumed by 1,200 houses, the brain is doing with theEnergy consumed by your laptop.

The brain is a huge network of neurons. They send pulses of electricity to each other. This process is called a synapse. In the brain, this process is very dynamic and adaptive. It's not like in the human brain, where it's very rigid.

CNN's Jim Boulden explains how computers work. He says the devices we use are similar to the ones we use in our brains. They are called transistors, he says, and they work in a similar way to neurons. The difference is that the transistors are smaller, so they can move more quickly.

In 2007, a transistor was big enough that several electrons can flow through the channel simultaneously, side by side. In 2015, the transistor is going to become so small, that it corresponds to only one electron at a time. The current will turn on and off at random, even when it's supposed to be on.

The way brains work is they break up that data into little pieces that are represented by pulses and different neurons. So you have all these pieces of data distributed throughout the network. The way that you process that data to get a result is that you translate this pattern of activity into a new pattern.

Scientists have created a chip that can send images back to the brain. The process is similar to that used to stream video over the Internet. The chip was designed by a team of neurobiologists at the University of Cambridge. It will soon be as easy to ask a computer a question as asking a person.

When Kareem moves his head to the right, you will see this blue activity there; it represents regions where the contrast is increasing in the image, that's where it's going from dark to light. And you also see this yellow activity, which represents region where contrast is decreasing; it'sGoing from light to dark. And these four types of information -- your optic nerve has about a million fibers in it, and 900,000 of those fibers send these four kinds of information.

The secret to productivity in so many fields -- and in origami -- is letting dead people do your work for you. Origami revolves around crease patterns. They have to obey four simple laws. The first law is two-colorability. You can color any crease pattern with just two colors without ever having the same color meeting.

The laws of quantum mechanics can be written down on a napkin. They govern all of chemistry, all of life and all of history. In origami, to obey these laws, we can take simple patterns and make them complex. The most powerful tools in origami have related to how we get parts of creatures.

Most people think they know what origami is, but they don't know what it means. We take an idea, combine it with a square, and you get an origami figure. From that, I somehow have to get to a folded shape that has a part for every bit of the subject, a flap for every leg.

How to make a single flap. Fold a square in half, fold it in half and fold it again, until it gets long and narrow, and then we'll say at the end of that, that's a flap. There's other ways of making flaps.

In the 1990s, origami artists discovered these principles and realized we could make arbitrarily complicated figures just by packing circles. So we figured out these rules whereby you pack circles, you decorate the patterns of circles with lines according to more rules. That gives you the folds. Those folds fold into a base. You shape the base. And it's so simple that a computer could do it.

A computer program called TreeMaker calculates the crease pattern of a stick figure. The program is free and runs on all the major platforms -- even Windows. It can be used to fold insects, spiders, things with legs and wings, and antennae.

Toes have become an origami meme, because everyone's doing it. And you can do more than just insects. Everything you'll see here, except the car, is origami. And sometimes you create high art, and sometimes you pay the bills by doing some commercial work.

origami has applications in medicine, in science, in space, in the body, consumer electronics and more. One of the earliest was this pattern, this folded pattern, studied by Koryo Miura, a Japanese engineer. Engineers at Lawrence Livermore National Lab had an idea for a telescope much larger.

In the twentieth century, a Japanese folder named Yoshizawa came along, and he created tens of thousands of new designs. The Livermore engineers, wanting to make use of the work of dead people, or perhaps live origamists, said, "Let's see if someone else is doing this sort of thing"

The Japan Aerospace [Exploration] Agency flew a solar sail, and you can see that the sail expands out. The problem that's being solved here is something that needs to be big and sheet-like at its destination, but small for the journey. The algorithms that we developed to do insects turned out to be the solution for airbags.

The airbag-flattening algorithm came from all the developments of circle packing and the mathematical theory that was really developed just to create insects -- things with legs. The thing is, that this often happens in math and science. When you get math involved, problems that you solve for aesthetic value only, or to create something beautiful, turn out to have an application in the real world.

Galaxies themselves are not strewn randomly in space; they tend to cluster. Galaxies in the Coma cluster are moving at extremely high speeds. The galaxy and every other galaxy appears to be embedded in a cloud of this invisible dark matter.

There appears to be about ten times as much mass here in the form of this invisible or dark matter as there is in the ordinary matter. "I'm just putting this big, blue blob on there, OK, to try to remind you that it's there," he says.

Physicists have been turning their attention to the universe on the largest scale. They extrapolate backwards and say the galaxy is up here. Is there any other ray of light that could make into the observer's eye from that galaxy? Yes! The rays would lie on a cone.

Many of the images you are seeing are earlier from the Hubble Space Telescope. The speed with which galaxies within clusters are orbiting is much too large; it must be embedded in dark matter. So to understand the evidence for dark energy, we need to discuss something that Stephen Hawking referred to in the previous session.

Physicists and astronomers set out to measure the rate at which the expansion of space was slowing down. The startling answer was that space is expanding at a faster rate today than it was a few billion years ago. No one was predicting ahead of time this is what's going to be found.

"There are really two mysteries out there as to what makes up most of the universe," Hawking says. "Dark matter and dark energy are completely different things," he adds. "We don't have any, you know, really persuasive argument for dark energy," he says.

Dark matter is a very weakly interacting, new particle. It doesn't interact with the electromagnetic spectrum, which is what we use to detect things. Dark matter particles can come through the building, through the Earth -- they're so non-interacting. The Large Hadron Collider, a particle physics accelerator, will be turning on later this year.

New physics could be missing energy, so it will be hard to tell the difference. Dark matter dominates the gravitational effects in the universe on a large scale. Ground-based telescopes are being designed specifically to address the questions of dark matter and dark energy.

Molecular programmers are trying to build computers out of DNA. They are using DNA because it is cheap and easy to use. The question is, how does a program know when to stop? And how do you know if a program will ever stop?

The process is similar to folding a piece of paper into an origami-like shape. The DNA strands are mixed with water to form a pattern. The pattern is then drawn on the surface of the water to create the shape of a human hair.

The shape of an electron is one of the symmetries of this E8 shape. The direction it's twisting as it moves is what particle we see. This quantum weirdness was first described by Erwin Schrödinger and his cat. The way the shape twists is what the elementary particles are, themselves.

Schrödinger is dead in one branch of reality, but alive in the other. These realities are experienced separately by each individual. The mathematics of quantum mechanics tells us this is how the world works at tiny scales. It can be summed up in a single sentence: Everything that can happen, does.

The Large Hadron Collider at CERN in Geneva has a circumference of 17 miles. A beam of protons and antiprotons are accelerated to near the speed of light and brought together in a collision. This energy is immediately converted into a spray of subatomic particles.

The electromagnetic force interacts with electrically charged matter via particles called photons. The strong force acts between quarks which carry a different kind of charge, called color charge. There's the force of gravity, which interacts with matter via its mass and spin. A particle that hasn't been seen yet, but we're pretty sure exists, is the Higgs particle.

Electric charge is actually a combination of two other charges: hypercharge and weak charge. Electrons have an electric charge, a negative one, and quarks have electric charges in thirds. The Higgs particle breaks the symmetry of this electroweak pattern and makes the weak force very weak.

The electromagnetic and weak forces are described by this pattern of particle charges in two-dimensional space. If a particle and an antiparticle collide, it creates a burst of energy and a total charge of zero. The charges of all known particles can be plotted in a four-dimensional charge space, and projected down to two dimensions.

The way the universe works at these tiny scales is very beautiful. We want to find all the particles and forces that make a complete picture of our universe. And we want to use this picture to predict new particles that we'll see when experiments reach higher energies.

Physicists look for larger, more symmetric patterns that include the established pattern as a subset. The larger pattern allows us to predict the existence of particles that have never been seen. The geometry of this shape could describe everything about how the universe works at the tiniest scales.

The pattern of this shape living in eight-dimensional charge space is exquisitely beautiful. It summarizes thousands of possible interactions between these elementary particles, each of which is just a facet of this complicated shape. There are 20 gaps where new particles should be, two of which have been filled by the Pati-Salam particles.

The politics become easier as the decade progresses if you're building on a foundation of security and economic development. The mentality of politics has to shift from zero-sum to positive-sum before you can get a productive politics. In order to build prosperity, we need security in place.

The Security Council is responsible for providing the peacekeepers who build the security. The second actor, different cast of guys, is the donors. The donors provide post-conflict aid. Typically in the past, the donors have been interested in the first couple of years, then they got bored.

40 percent of all post-conflict situations, historically, have reverted back to conflict within a decade. During conflict economic policy typically deteriorates. Governments snatch short-term opportunities and, by the end of the conflict, the chickens have come home to roost.

In a post-conflict situation, needs are everywhere, but the capacity to implement change is very limited. So we have to be disciplined and focus on things that are critical. Jobs, health, and clean government are the three critical priorities.

Post-conflict situations often revert to conflict because young men have nothing to do. The construction sector has a vital role, obviously, in reconstruction. But any activity open to international trade is basically going to be uncompetitive in a post-Conflict situation.

During conflict people are doing destruction. There isn't any construction going on. And so the sector shrivels away. When you try and expand it, because it's shriveled away, you encounter a lot of bottlenecks. The first thing that is prioritized is politics.

There has been a sort of a schizophrenia in the donor community, as to how to build basic services in post-conflict sectors. On the one hand it pays lip service to the idea of rebuild an effective state in the image of Scandinavia in the 1950s. Neither of those approaches is sensible.

Short-term peacekeepers would be co-branded as being done by the post-conflict government, in the country. The government would be funding it, it would beCo-branding these services. The typical post-Conflict government is so short of money that it needs our money just to be on a life-support system.

Focus on the construction sector would have produced both jobs and security. The emphasis on clean government would have gradually squeezed out the political crooks. The focus on the basic service delivery would have rescued basic services from their catastrophic levels. Gradually it would shift from a politics of plunder to a Politics of hope.

He imagined an integrated transportation system in which a passenger could embark on a train in London and disembark from a ship in New York. Brunel was using design thinking to solve problems and to create world-changing innovations.

Conversion Sound has developed a high quality, ultra-low-cost digital hearing aid for the developing world. In the West we rely on highly trained technicians to fit these hearing aids. In places like India, those technicians simply don't exist. So it took a team working in India with patients and community health workers to understand how a PDA might replace those technicians.

Lenses are being used to replace lenses that are damaged by the sun. They are now being used in a new way to make them more affordable. The idea is that they can be used to make people's lives better by making them more productive.

Designers have been working on a new way of working with patients. The idea is to reduce the time it takes to care for a patient. The project is being led by the London School of Economics and Social Sciences. It is the first of its kind in the UK and aims to be a national model.

The power of spectroscopy was actually realized by Pink Floyd already in 1973. The number one high resolution, most precise spectrograph on this planet is called HARPS. HARPS is actually used to detect extrasolar planets and sound waves in the atmospheres of stars.

The spectrum of the Sun has 24,000 spectral lines. About 15 percent of these lines are not yet identified. Astronomers can study line-of-sight velocities of cosmic objects. They can also study chemical composition and physical parameters of stars, galaxies, nebulae.

Osmium is a heavy element produced in thermonuclear explosions of supernovae. It's the only place where you can produce, actually, osmium. We use this weak feature to measure the composition of gold in the atmosphere of the Sun.

Spectroscopy can probably answer the question, "Is there anybody out there?" There is interaction of galaxies. And sometimes they just capture stars. They actually said that one of the stars you see in the spectra is an alien. It comes from a different galaxy.

The Doppler Effect is used to discover extrasolar planets. The precision which we need to discover a Jupiter-like planet around a sun-like star is something like 28.4 meters per second. We need nine centimeters per second to detect an Earth- like planet.

Scientists are trying to detect life in the atmosphere of an extrasolar planet. If there is too much uranium or potassium or thorium, there would be no life on the planet. "It's exactly the same game. A very tiny feature. We are actually trying to measure this profile and to detect thorium"

Water, methane, carbon dioxide have been detected in the spectrum of a planet outside the solar system. The slope which is coming, which we call a Red Edge, is a detection of vegetated area. The one way to discover about aliens is to tune your radio telescope and listen to the signals.

SETI is a project to find alien life on another planet. The project has been going since 2000 and is reviewing the spectra of about 300 stars with extrasolar planets. If you see strange chemical elements in the spectrum of a planet host star, it can be a signal from a civilization.

In about five years we will discover planets like Earth, around sun-like stars, the same distance as the Earth from the Sun. And then we will need another 10, 15 years with space projects to get the spectra of Earth-like planets like the one I showed you.

By 2050, twice the number of us are going to be living in cities. Half the food produced in the USA is currently thrown away. Nineteen million hectares of rainforest are lost every year to create new arable land. It takes about 10 calories to produce every calorie of food that we consume in the West.

A billion of us are obese, while a further billion starve. 80 percent of global trade in food now is controlled by just five multinational corporations. So how did we get here? And more importantly, what are we going to do about it?

Every day for a city the size of London, enough food has to be produced, transported, bought and sold, cooked, eaten, disposed of. The whole spiritual and physical life of these cities was dominated by the grain and the harvest that sustained them.

The streets and public spaces were the only places where food was bought and sold. Poultry was coming in from East Anglia and so on, to the northeast. Fish was, of course, coming in by river as well. You can actually see how it was physically shaped by food.

Cities used to be constrained by geography; they used to have to get their food through very difficult physical means. After the trains came cars, and really this marks the end of this process. It's the final emancipation of the city from any apparent relationship with nature at all.

Food used to be a social event, buying and selling food. Now it's anonymous. We used to cook; now we just add water, or a little bit of an egg if you're making a cake or something. We don't smell food to see if it's okay to eat.

Food is a fundamental ordering principle of Utopia, says philosopher. Utopian was actually a word that Thomas Moore used deliberately. It can either mean a good place, or no place, he says. We live in a world shaped by food, and if we realize that, we can use food as a really powerful tool.

Food is at the center of family life, being celebrated, being enjoyed, people taking time for it. But you can't have scenes like this unless you have people like this. It's people who think about food, who think ahead, who plan. We need these people.

Sitopia is a project that aims to reconnect people with nature. It's a re-conceptualization of the way food shapes our lives. The best image I know of this is from 650 years ago. Ambrogio Lorenzetti's "Allegory of Good Government" is about relationship between city and countryside.

"We need to realize that the world is also what we eat," says CNN's John Sutter. "It's within these tribes that societies get built, that important things happen," he says. Sutter: "What we're really here to talk about is the how."

People form tribes. They always have, they always will. Not all tribes are the same, and what makes the difference is the culture. You're all a member of tribes. CNN's John Sutter talks about the culture of Stage One. Stage One produces people who do horrible things, Sutter says. Sutter: It's not enough to simply write people off. He says we need to move on to Stage Two.
