The company is moving from Stage Three to Stage Four. The company is based outside Las Vegas. The CEO says the company is looking for ways to improve its business. He says they are looking for new ways to make their business more profitable.

Desmond Tutu set up a process to involve the thousands and perhaps millions of tribes in the country, to bring everyone together. No one had ever done anything like this before. People, at the time, feared that South Africa would end up going the way that Rwanda has gone.

The Declaration of Independence is written at Stage Two, the author says. The phrase that sticks in many of our minds is things about inalienable rights, he says. "Life is great" is oriented only by our values, no other guidance, he adds.

Two percent of people are at Stage One, 25 percent at Stage Two. Martin Luther King's most famous line was at Stage Three. Only two percent, only two percent of tribes get to Stage Five. And those are the ones that change the world.

The light that falls onto our eyes is determined by multiple things in the world, not only the color of objects. The same image could have an infinite number of possible real-world sources. The light that fall onto your eye is meaningless, because it could mean literally anything.

The brain evolved the mechanisms for finding patterns, finding relationships in information, and associating those relationships with a behavioral meaning, a significance. It's what we do with that information that matters. The brain can redefine normality, even at the simplest thing the brain does, which is color.

The right side of the brain's visual field is under red illumination; the left side is under green. One is simply the flipping of the other. The brain is seeing that same information as if the right one was still under red light, and the left one was under green light.

An illusion of light and dark surrounds is based on what your behavior has been in the past. The illusion is created when two identical tiles are placed in a dark and a light surround. If they're under the same light reflecting the same amount of light to your eye, then they must be equally reflective.

phthalmologist: The physical reality is that those two tiles are the same. What's true for color is also true for complex perceptions of motion, he says. The four blue tiles on the left are gray. The seven yellow tiles are also gray. And how many people think it's the orange one?

Even the beautiful bumblebee, with its mere one million brain cells, sees illusions, says scientist. Even our most sophisticated computers can't do the most complicated things, he says. In my lab we work on bumblebees, because we can completely control their experience, and see how it alters their brain.

The bees go back and forth between this hive and the arena, via this tube. They land on the flower, stick their tongue in there, called a proboscis, and drink sugar water. They learn not to go to the blue, but to go where the other bees go.

The brain evolved to see the world the way it was useful to see in the past. How we see is by continually redefining normality. One of the ways we do it in my lab and studio is we translate the light into sound. And they can navigate the world using their ears.

cognitive scientist says the brain creates, builds, a version of the universe, and projects it all around us like a bubble. Scientists are now scaling the project up to reach the human brain. 99 percent of what you see is not what comes in through the eyes, but what you infer about that room. It took the universe 11 billion years to build the brain, so it had to improve it a little bit.

From mouse to man, the neocortex expanded about a thousandfold in terms of the numbers of neurons. The neocortex in the human brain is evolving at an enormous speed. It's made up of little modules, G5 processors, like in a computer. But there are about a million of them.

There is a new theory of autism called the "intense world" Theory suggests that the neocortical columns are super-plastic. They are highly reactive, and so the autists are probably capable of building a symphony. The perception, the symphony that you create is going to be corrupted.

The most important design secret of the brain is diversity, says Dr. David Wheeler. Every neuron is different. It's the same in the forest. Every pine tree is different, and in the brain it is the same, he says. Wheeler: We have to embody all our data and knowledge into a working model.

Scientists have discovered that the circuitry of the brain does change. But the pattern of how the circuitry is designed does not. The equations that make neurons into electrical generators were discovered by two Cambridge Nobel Laureates. And we think this is species-specific, which could explain why we can't communicate across species.

The Blue Gene is a supercomputer that simulates the activity of the brain's neocortex. It is the first time scientists have been able to simulate brain activity using just a handful of equations. The computer is the size of 10,000 laptops and can simulate the brain in its entirety.

Scientists have trained a brain to see itself by stimulating its neocortical column. The next step is to project these brain coordinates into perceptual space. Scientists hope to create a hologram of the brain within 10 years. They hope to use this hologram to help diagnose and treat disorders.

The brain has a very small amount of bandwidth for processing sound, says Dr. David Wheeler. Wheeler: "You can't understand two people talking at once. You have to choose which one you're going to listen to" He says if you work in an open-plan office, the noise level is three times higher.

Most sound is accidental, even hostile, and it has a dramatic effect on sales. Music is the most powerful sound there is, often inappropriately deployed. We stand on street corners, shouting over noise like this, pretending it doesn't exist. Or start at the bottom and say what outcomes we want.

The habit of suppressing sound has meant that our relationship with sound has become largely unconscious. Hundreds of dragonflies were spotted in the Maldives. They are a species of Globe Skimmer. They need fresh water to breed. They come every year to the Maldivian archipelago. They can be seen in the capital, Malé.

India is built entirely of coral reefs. On top of the coral reefs are sand banks. When it rains, the rainwater soaks down into the soil. There is no surface fresh water in India. There are no ponds, streams, rivers, lakes, nothing like that.

The phenomenon is a widespread phenomenon throughout South Asia, including the Maldives. In India there is plenty of water, so, dragonflies, yeah, of course. But in Maldives, no fresh water. So, what on Earth is going on?

Maldives is a long archipelago. It stretches about 500 miles, of course it's India here. It's pretty obvious, they're coming from India. But they are coming 400 miles across the ocean, against the wind. How on Earth are they doing that?

I wanted to know about their seasonality, what time of year, this is when they first arrive, but how long are they around for? Does that give any clues? So, I started a very rigorous scientific process. I got on my bicycle, and I cycled around the island of Malé. It's about five kilometers around, counting the dragonflies as I go.

The dragonflies are actually coming from India on the northeast monsoon, but at an altitude at 1,000 to 2,000 meters up in the air. The larvae have to develop very quickly. There is nothing for them in Maldives. They're making it all the way across to East Africa.

The blue whale is one of the best places in the world to see blue whales. The species can fly for thousands of kilometers. They are breeding in the rains of Africa. They only take six weeks, instead of 11 months, they're six weeks.

The summer monsoon is a time of maximum heat, evaporation, clouds and rainfall in southern Africa. The sun is overhead, the wind is always converging to where the rain is falling, so the air is drawn towards it to replace the air that's rising.

This is a circuit of about 16,000 kilometers, four generations, for a two inch long insect. It is the only truly regular transoceanic crossing of any insect. But dragonflies are not the only creatures that make the crossing. There is more to the story. This is a rather special bird.

The Amur Falcon breeds in Amurland, an area along the Amur River. The whole population moves south. They have a refueling stop in northeastern India. They come to the latitude of about Mumbai or Goa. And then they strike out across the ocean, down to Kenya.

Several birds of prey make the crossing from India to Africa. They make use of exactly the same winds. They travel at the same altitude. One of these met an unfortunate end 21 years ago, off the coast of Goa, in 1988.

Shakespeare's famous line 'Juliet is the sun' is a metaphor for the sun. metaphors are a way of mixing and matching metaphors to create a more vivid understanding of a thing. In the summer India heats up, gets very hot, so the dragonflies use the same winds.

Metaphor lives a secret life all around us. We utter about six metaphors a minute. We all have synesthetic abilities. People with colored hearing actually see colors when they hear the sounds of words or letters. Metaphor is not just the detection of patterns; it is the creation of patterns.

Metaphorical thinking is essential to how we understand ourselves and others. Many of the metaphors we use everyday are synesthetic. The test shows that we cannot ignore the literal meaning of words even when the literalmeaning gives the wrong answer. The participants took longer to reject metaphors as false than they did to reject literally false sentences.
"Some jobs are jails" is a metaphor for "the market" "The market" means "the price of something" " The market" is the price of a thing. "The price of the thing" is "the value of that thing"

We cannot ignore the analogies that are triggered by metaphor. Metaphor matters because it opens the door to discovery. We compare what we know with what we don't know. The only way to find out about the latter is to investigate the former.

"All Shook Up" is a great love song. It's also a great example of how whenever we deal with anything abstract -- ideas, emotions, feelings, concepts, thoughts -- we inevitably resort to metaphor. Metaphor shakes things up, giving us everything from Shakespeare to scientific discovery in the process.

Fusion is the process of joining hydrogen and helium together to make helium. It's been known since the 1920s, but has only just been discovered. The process is very complex and takes a long time to work out. But it is possible to do it with a small nucleus.

Deuterium and tritium goes together makes helium 5. Helium splits out, and a neutron comes out and lots of energy comes out. If you can get something to about 150 million degrees, things will be rattling around so fast that every time they collide in just the right configuration.

We have a few tens of years of fossil fuel left. We don't have enough uranium to power the world. We need fast-breeding technology to make more fuel. We will have to rely on nuclear power. We have to use nuclear power to make electricity. We can't rely on coal.

"We have to hold something at 150 million degrees. And, in fact, we've done this. We hold it with a magnetic field" "We have 30 million years worth of fusion fuel in sea water" "I ate the disliked ones first, because the ones you like, you want to save"

Solar Impulse is a project to fly around the world in a solar powered airplane, using absolutely no fuel. The idea is that nobody ever could say in the future that it's impossible to do it for cars, for heating systems, for computers, and so on.

With 200 square meters of solar power on our plane, we can produce the same energy than 200 little lightbulbs. That means a Christmas tree, a big Christmas tree. People will tell you it's impossible, and that's exactly why we try to do it.

The goal is to take off, end of this year for the first test, but mainly next year, spring or summer, without additional help. The same time we load the batteries, we run the engines, and when we get at the maximum height, we arrive at the beginning of the night. There will be just one goal, just one: reach the next sunrise before the batteries are empty.

When Lindbergh crossed the Atlantic, the payload was just sufficient for one person and some fuel. 20 years later there were 200 people in every airplane crossing the Atlantic. The success will not come if we "just," quote, unquote, fly around the world in a solar-powered airplane.

A new study shows that some of the neurons in the brain that control movement are activated when someone else is doing the same thing. It's almost as though the brain is performing a virtual reality simulation of the other person's action. This is why all the people who believe in this type of spirit are welcome to join the SolarImpulse team.

University of California, San Francisco, professor explains how the human brain evolved. He says the brain developed a sophisticated mirror neuron system, which allowed you to emulate and imitate other people's actions. This made evolution suddenly Lamarckian, instead of Darwinian, he says.

There are mirror neurons, just as there are mirror neuron for action, there are Mirror neurons for touch. If somebody touches me, my hand, neuron in the somatosensory cortex in the sensory region of the brain fires. But the same neuron, in some cases, will fire when I simply watch another person being touched.

You are connected not just via Facebook and Internet, you're actually quite literally connected by your neurons. There is no real distinctiveness of your consciousness from somebody else's consciousness. If the arm has been removed and you have a phantom, you watch somebody else being touched, you feel it in your phantom.

The brain is made up of 100 billion neurons. Each neuron makes something like 1,000 to 10,000 contacts with other neurons in the brain. The number of permutations and combinations of brain activity exceeds the number of elementary particles in the universe. The mirror neuron system underlies the interface allowing you to rethink about consciousness.

I'm sort of anti-fashion because I don't show the surface, I show what's within. The fashionistas don't really like me because it doesn't matter if Kate Moss is wearing it or if I'm wearing it, it looks the same. The process, in itself, shows how exquisite they are.

Nature is my greatest inspiration, says the architect. His new X-ray room is made of lead and steel and weighs 1,250 kilograms. The walls are 700 millimeters thick of solid dense concrete. The only exercise he gets is opening and closing it.

The artist uses a 1980s drum scanner, which was designed in the days when everyone shot photographs on film. Boeing sent him a 747 in containers and he sent them back an X-ray. The process takes three months solid X-rays of 500 separate components.

The artist used a recently deceased body to create the image. The coloring adds another level to the X-rays, he says. The work is not accurately colored to how it is in real life, he adds. But he says he likes to use whatever takes his fancy.

The most difficult things to X-ray are the lightest things, the most delicate things. The first shot I ever did was of a soda can, which was to promote a brand that we all know. The second shot I did was my shoes I was wearing on the day.

The X-ray shows how beautiful nature can be. The problem with using living people is that you get exposed to radiation. To avoid that, to avoid that -- I have to avoid it somehow -- is I use dead people. I will show how the capillary action works, how it feeds.

The thicker the object, the more radiation it needs, and the more time it needs. The longer the exposure goes on for the more detail you get, the better the image. "I travel beyond the surface and show something for what it's worth," he says.

This year is the 50th anniversary of Issigonis's Mini, which is one of my favorite cars. I'm going to be displaying it in the Victoria and Albert Museum as a light box. I see my projects in my sleep. And I know what they're going to look like in X-ray and I'm not far off.

The Sardinians pray, the Seventh-Day Adventists pray and the Okinawans have ancestor veneration. But when you're in a hurry or stressed out, that triggers something called the inflammatory response. When you slow down for 15 minutes a day you turn that inflammatory state into a more anti-inflammatory state.

These people know their sense of purpose. They have strategies to keep from overeating. They all belong to a faith-based community. They were either born into or they proactively surrounded themselves with the right people. They put their families first. They don't drink too much.

Only about one out of 5,000 people in America live to be 100. Exercise programs usually start in January; they're usually done by October. Only about 10 percent of how long the average person lives, within certain biological limits, is dictated by our genes. To make it to age 100, you not only have to have a very good lifestyle, you also have to win the genetic lottery.

A 65-year-old person is aging at a rate of about 125 times faster than a 12-year old person. The capacity of the human body is about 90 years, a little bit more for women. Life expectancy in this country is only 78.

Blue Zones aim to find the optimal lifestyle of longevity. The first Blue Zone was found on the island of Sardinia. Sardinian men live the longest, with 10 times more centenarians than Americans. The Sardinian diet is mostly plant-based, accentuated with foods that can carry into the fields.

Sardinia has the longest disability-free life expectancy in the world. Five times as many centenarians as we have in America. One fifth the rate of colon and breast cancer, big killers here in the U.S. And one sixth the rates of cardiovascular disease.

Okinawa has a plant-based diet, full of vegetables with lots of color in them. They eat off of smaller plates, so they tend to eat fewer calories at every sitting. Instead of serving family style, they serve at the counter, put the food away, and then bring it to the table.

Okinawa has a system where you automatically have a half a dozen friends. If you're in a Moai you're expected to share the bounty if you encounter luck. In the Okinawan language there is not even a word for retirement. The National Institute on Aging gave us a questionnaire to give these centenarians.

Geographic editor wanted me to find America's Blue Zone. America's longest-lived population among the Seventh-Day Adventists concentrated in and around Loma Linda, California. Adventists are conservative Methodists. They celebrate their Sabbath from sunset on Friday till sunset on Saturday.

In America, life expectancy for the average woman is 80. But for an Adventist woman, their life expectancy is 89. And the difference is even more pronounced among men, who are expected to live about 11 years longer than their American counterparts. The Blue Zone project followed about 70,000 people for 30 years.

Adventists tend to hang out with other Adventists. At an Adventist party you don't see people swilling Jim Beam or rolling a joint. They're talking about their next nature walk, exchanging recipes, and yes, they pray. This is a culture that has yielded Ellsworth Whareham.

The king cobra is a species of snake that lives in India. It is one of the largest snakes in the world. It can grow up to 12 feet in length. The king cobras feed on other snakes. They can also eat other snakes' eggs.

The king cobra is a keystone species in the rainforests of Brazil. Scientists are trying to learn as much as they can about the snake to help protect its habitat. The snakes are the first species on Earth to be so prolific to threaten our own survival.

The promise of regenerative medicine is a single promise, says Anthony Atala. Atala: "Our main goal, of course, is first, to do no harm" "We started implanting some of these structures over 14 years ago," he says.

Salamanders have this amazing capacity to regenerate. Human body is constantly regenerating. Your bones regenerate every 10 years. Your skin regenerates every two weeks. Your body has many organs and every single organ in your body has a cell population that's ready to take over.

At the time of injury or disease, the body's first reaction is to seal itself off from the rest of the body. The challenge occurs when there is an injury. One of the ways that we do that is by using smart biomaterials. This is the first time an organ was ever transplanted.

The maximum efficient distance for regeneration is only about one centimeter. The scaffold is acting only as a cell delivery vehicle. It's allowing the cells to regenerate new tissue, and once the tissue is regenerated the scaffold goes away. The kidney was indeed the first organ ever to be regenerated to the human.

In 1954, 55 years ago, scientists first created an engineered blood vessel. Today, they use the same technique to create a scaffold. The scaffold has the same conditions as a human body, 37 degrees centigrade, 95 percent oxygen.

Hollow organs have a much higher degree of complexity, because you're asking these organs to act on demand. We take a very small piece of the bladder, less than half the size of a postage stamp. We then tease the tissue apart into its two individual cell components, muscle, and these bladder specialized cells.

In the last decade the number of patients waiting for a transplant has doubled. But we have a major shortage of organs. The material is actually being coated with the cells. When we did the first clinical trial for these patients we actually created the scaffold specifically for each patient.

The most complex solid organs are the vascularized, highly vascularized organs, such as the heart, the liver, the kidneys. The actual number of transplants has remained almost entirely flat. The number of organ transplants in the U.S. is expected to rise in the coming years.

Researchers use decellularized organs to create functional livers. They use very mild detergents to take all the cell elements out of the organs. They then perfuse the outside of the liver with the patient's own liver cells.

90 percent of the patients on the transplant wait list are waiting for a kidney, 90 percent. We are able to reproduce the functionality of the liver structure, experimentally. We stack these wafers together, using the kidney cells. And then you can see these miniature kidneys that we've engineered.

We prefer organ-specific cells. If we cannot use stem cells from your body then we'd like to use donor stem cells. We prefer cells that will not reject and will not form tumors. Some of the work you saw today was performed by over 700 researchers at our institute across a 20-year period.

Every 30 seconds a patient dies from diseases that could be treated with tissue regeneration or replacement, says Dr. Richard Branson. Branson: "We've made absolutely sure that we do everything we can in the laboratory before we ever launch these technologies to patients"

The body has the ability to regulate the amount of blood vessels that are present at any given time. When those excess vessels are no longer needed, the body prunes them back to baseline. The body does this through an elaborate and elegant system of checks and balances, stimulators and inhibitors of angiogenesis.

There are more than 70 major diseases affecting more than a billion people worldwide. All share abnormal angiogenesis as their common denominator. Excessive angiogenic drives disease, and we see this in cancer, blindness, arthritis, obesity, Alzheimer's disease.

The body's ability to balance angiogenesis, when it's working properly, prevents blood vessels from feeding cancers. Without a blood supply, most of these cancers will never become dangerous. Once those vessels invade the cancer, it can expand, and the same vessels allow cancer cells to exit into the circulation as metastases.

Antiangiogenic therapy has been used to treat cancer in dogs, dolphins and horses. The treatment has a 60 percent response rate and improved survival for pets that were about to be euthanized. The smallest blood vessels are called capillaries. We've got 19 billion of them in our bodies.

I'm a Himba and Namibian. A Himba is one of the 29 ethnic groups in Namibia. We live a very traditional lifestyle. I grew up herding, looking after our livestock -- goats, sheep and cattle.

"We lived under apartheid regime. When he was growing up in Botswana, Soweto was sent off to school by his father. DNC has helped men reclaim their abilities to manage their peoples and their rights to own and manage wildlife. Namibia has got 2.1 million people, but it is only twice the size of California.

Namibia has the largest concentration of black rhino -- free-roaming black rhinos -- in the world. Namibia is now part of the global village. The natural plain has multiplied, like zebras, springboks and everything. The leopard is now in big numbers but they are now far away from our village.

Namibia has 60 conservancies that manage and protect over 13 million hectares of land in Namibia. Conservancies are legally instituted institutions by the government, and these are run by the communities themselves. In 2008, conservancy generated 5.7 million dollars. Namibia's new economy is based on the respect of natural resources.

Skeptic magazine editor says we are pattern-seeking primates. We find patterns, we make connections, and that's called association learning, he says. He calls this process "patternicity" -- that is, the tendency to find meaningful patterns in both meaningful and meaningless noise.

The problem is that patternicities will occur whenever the cost of making a Type I error is less than the cost to make a Type II error. If you think that the rustle in the grass is a dangerous predator and it turns out it's just the wind, you've made an error in cognition.

Cognitive priming is a technique used to prime the brain to see patterns. The pattern detection device in the anterior cingulate cortex can be easily fooled. Some people see a Dalmatian dog, while others see a cow or a horse.

Jennifer Whitson: People that are put in a condition of feeling out of control are more likely to see something in this, which is allegedly patternless. In other words, the propensity to find these patterns goes up when there's a lack of control.

Swiss psychologist Peter Brugger found more meaningful patterns were perceived on the right hemisphere, via the left visual field, than the left hemisphere. Brugger and his colleague, Christine Mohr, gave subjects L-DOPA. An increase of dopamine caused subjects to see more patterns than those that did not receive dopamine.

Dopamine changes our signal-to-noise ratio. If it's too low, you're more likely to make too many Type II errors. If you're too skeptical, you'll miss the really interesting good ideas. It's a distinction perhaps we might make between two Nobel laureates.

What you're thinking about a lot influences what you tend to see. If we can give you conflicting data, again, your ACC is going to be going into hyperdrive. The ADE 651 was sold to the Iraqi government for 40,000 dollars apiece.

YouTube compares every video uploaded to the site to see if there's a match. The scale and the speed of this system is truly breathtaking. Most rights owners, instead of blocking, will allow the copy to be published. And then they benefit through the exposure, advertising and sales.

The video's inspired over 26,000 dollars in donations to end domestic violence. The "JK Wedding [Entrance] Dance" became so popular that NBC parodied it on the season finale of "The Office" It's not just amateurs borrowing from big studios, but sometimes big studios borrowing back.

YouTube's Content ID system addresses all of these cases. But the system only works through the participation of rights owners. YouTube's Content ID system identifies when copyrighted material is uploaded to the site. A fan saw Chris Brown's "Forever" video on TV and uploaded it to YouTube. Within seconds of attempting to upload the video, the copy was detected, giving Sony the choice of what to do next.

The whales live in an amazing acoustic environment. They've evolved over tens of millions of years to take advantage of this. We need to be very attentive and vigilant to thinking about where things that we do may unintentionally prevent them from being able to achieve their important activities.

Many mammals have to produce contact calls when, say, a mother and calf are apart. The signature whistle which dolphins use to stay in touch, each individual here has a radically different call. They can use this ability to learn calls in order to develop more complicated and more distinctive calls.

When a male dolphin leaves Mom, it will often join up with another male and form an alliance, which may last for decades. As these two animals form a social bond, their distinctive whistles actually converge and become very similar. The average interval between times that a boat is passing within a hundred meters of a dolphin group is six minutes.

CNN's John Sutter says we need to be more aware of the impact of noise in the ocean. Sutter: "We need to make sure that we don't lose the sound of the ocean" He says we should also be aware that the ocean is not the only place where noise is emitted.

The ocean has properties that allow low-frequency sound to basically move globally. The acoustic transit time for each of these paths is about three hours. Blue whales and fin whales produce very low- frequencies that can travel over very long ranges. They form songs, and they appear to play a role in reproduction.

Humpbacks make a sound that's a little higher in frequency, broader-band and more complicated. They can produce loud clicks and listen for echoes from the sea floor in order to orient. This means that humpback song is a form of animal culture, just like music for humans would be.

Listen to a recording made by Chris Clark, 0.2 miles away from a humpback. You can hear the full frequency range. You sound very nearby. The next recording you're going to hear was made of the same humpback song 50 miles away.

The loudness of a whale call is louder than noise at a range of a thousand kilometers. Human ships are the main source of noise in the frequency range where whales communicate. If this signal is used for males and females to find each other and they're dispersed, imagine the impact this could have on the recovery of endangered populations.

Right whale mothers and calves use calls to stay in touch with one another. As we've put more noise into the oceans, these whales have had to shift. whales can compensate for noise by calling louder or by shifting their call out of the noise band. It's an amazing shift, induced by humans over this large scale.

The International Maritime Organization of the United Nations has formed a group whose job is to establish guidelines for quieting ships. If you actually insulate and isolate the machinery of the ship from the hull, you can reduce that noise by 99 percent. If this group can establish standards, and if the shipbuilding industry adopts them for building new ships, we can now see a gradual decline in this potential problem.

Sally Kohn: We're about to start a new era of social science. She says we'll be able to use data to predict and prevent epidemics. Kohn says we can use this data to improve health and well-being for all.

Inventor of the theory of social contagion explains how ideas and behaviors spread through social networks. The diffusion-of-innovation curve can be understood by looking at a network of 105 people. The dots are the people, and the lines represent friendship relationships.

Nicholas Christakis: Not all positions in the network are the same. He says sexually transmitted diseases will spread across sexual ties. Christakis asks audience: Who would you rather be if a deadly germ was spreading through the network, A or B? He says A is more central, and this can be formalized mathematically.

Mapping human social networks is not always possible. It can be expensive, not feasible, unethical, or, frankly, just not possible to do such a thing. How can we figure out who the central people are in a network without actually mapping the network? And you get a network that looks like this.

Every dot is a person. Your friends have more friends than you do, and this is known as the friendship paradox. The friends of randomly chosen people have higher degree, and are more central than the random people themselves. The researchers tested this idea with an outbreak of H1N1 flu at Harvard College.

Using this technique, we could get more than a month-and-a-half warning about a flu epidemic in a particular population. The first evidence you saw of a blip above zero in adoption of the innovation would be evidence of an impending epidemic. Or you could see the first time the two curves diverged, as shown on the left.

Using a visualization of the flu, the size of the dots is proportional to how many of your friends have the flu. The slope of the epidemic curve is approaching now, in November. The same insights can also be exploited in other ways, for example, in the use of targeting specific people.

The first treaty of Fort Laramie was made, clearly marking the boundaries of the Lakota Nation. The Homestead Act, signed by President Lincoln, unleashed a flood of white settlers into Native lands. The following is a time line of treaties made, treaties broken and massacres disguised as battles.

In 1868, the U.S. government signed a treaty with the Lakota tribe. The treaty gave the Lakotas the right to use their land for hunting. In 1871, the treaty was amended to give the Lakote the right of self-determination.

The Pine Ridge Reservation is located about 75 miles southeast of the Black Hills in South Dakota. The Fort Laramie Treaty called for at least three-quarters of the tribe to sign away land. That clause was obviously ignored. The great Lakota warrior and chief named Crazy Horse surrendered at Fort Robinson.

The Wounded Knee Massacre is considered the end of the Indian wars. More Medals of Honor were given for the indiscriminate slaughter of women and children than for any battle in World War One, World War Two, Korea, Vietnam, Iraq or Afghanistan. Pine Ridge is ground zero for Native issues in the US.

In 1900, the US Indian population was less than 250,000, compared to an estimated eight million in 1492. In 1980, the longest-running court case in US history, the Sioux Nation versus the United States, was ruled upon.

At least 60 percent of the homes on the reservation are infested with black mold. Thirty-nine percent of homes on Pine Ridge have no electricity. Frequently, grandparents are raising their grandchildren because parents, due to alcoholism, domestic violence and general apathy, cannot raise them.

The United States continues on a daily basis to violate the terms of the 1851 and 1868 Fort Laramie Treaties with the Lakota. The "fix," as it's called, may be much more difficult for the dominant society than, say, a $50 check.

Mammography relies on differences in the appearance of the tumor from the background tissue. MBI exploits the different molecular behavior of tumors, and therefore, it's impervious to breast density. The patient receives an injection of a radio tracer that's taken up by rapidly proliferating tumor cells.

Mammogram shows faint tumor, edges of which are blurred by dense tissue. MBI image shows that tumor much more clearly, as well as a second tumor, which profoundly influence that patient's surgical options. Of the tumors that we found, mammography found only 25 percent of those tumors.

The Sahara Forest Project aims to transform a desert area into an open space for people. The more vegetation we lose, the more that's likely to exacerbate climate change. The Namibian fog-basking beetle has evolved a way of harvesting its own fresh water in a desert.

The beetle is able to harvest moisture in the air and channel it down to its mouth. The Seawater Greenhouse condenses humidity as freshwater in a process that is effectively identical to the beetle. The combination of that and the elevated humidity had quite a dramatic effect on the local area.

The Seawater Greenhouse uses solar-tracking mirrors to focus the sun's heat to create electricity. The idea is to use the heat to grow crops that would not be possible to grow in direct sunlight. The project is being led by the University of California, Berkeley.

The Sahara Forest Project is a model for how we could create zero-carbon food and renewable energy. Karl Schwarzschild was a German Jew in World War I, working on the Russian front. He was reading Einstein's recently published general theory of relativity. Schwarzschild surmised an exact mathematical solution that described something very extraordinary. Space itself would curve like a waterfall flowing down the throat of a hole.

Einstein always thought black holes were a mathematical oddity. He did not believe they existed in nature. He thought nature would protect us from their formation. It was decades before the term "black hole" was coined and people realized that black holes are real astrophysical objects.

If a black hole were to eclipse the Milky Way, we would see a shadow of that black hole against the hundred billion stars in the galaxy. It would be like a near-death experience where you see the light at the end of the tunnel, but it's a total death experience.

Gravitational waves are waves that travel at the speed of light. They are created when two black holes orbit around each other. They leave behind a ringing of space, an actual wave on space-time. If you were standing near enough, your ear would resonate with the sound.

The universe is not a silent movie because the universe isn't silent. The sound you're hearing is the light black hole banging on space each time it gets close. At home it sounds kind of anticlimactic. But if you were to float by in space and you heard this, you want to get moving.

LIGO and LISA are being built on Earth to detect deviations in the squeezing and stretching of space. LISA will be able to see super-massive black holes millions of times the mass of the Sun. LIGO will be at advanced sensitivity within the next few years -- to pick this up.

"I learned that it all changes in an instant. September 11 created a security model in a lot of people's heads," he says. "Strong feelings can create a model. Eventually, the new model will replace the old model," he adds.

Psychiatrists can create a model instantaneously, because they're very emotive. There's often no right or wrong here. It's a model we just accept pretty much by faith. Some of us have a burglar alarm system at home and some of us don't.

The smoking debate took 40 years -- and that was an easy one. In 1982, there was a short epidemic of Tylenol poisonings in the United States. In the long term, both feeling and reality are important. For the first time in our species, feeling chases model, model chases reality.

The tamper-proof drug industry was invented after a spate of copycat attacks. The RFID bracelet on the baby now has a corresponding one on the mother, so if anyone other than the mother takes the baby out of the maternity ward, an alarm goes off. A lot of times, these trade-offs are about more than just security.

Security is two different things: it's a feeling, and it's reality. We make these trade-offs again and again, multiple times a day. We often won't even notice them. They're just part of being alive; we all do it. Every species does it.

We tend to exaggerate spectacular and rare risks and downplay common risks. We've developed this ability because it makes evolutionary sense. The answer is, we respond to the feeling of security and not the reality. Most of the time, feeling and reality are the same.

The unknown is perceived to be riskier than the familiar. People underestimate risks in situations they do control and overestimate them in ones they don't. If a risk is thrust upon you -- terrorism is a good example -- you'll overplay it. There are a bunch of other of these cognitive biases, that affect our risk decisions.

When something is so common, it's no longer news. Car crashes, domestic violence -- those are the risks you worry about. One in a million, one in a billion -- they're both almost never. And what these cognitive biases do is they act as filters between us and reality.

Security is a trade-off between security and feeling secure. If you don't understand the risks, you're likely to get the trade-offs wrong. Security theater is exposed when it's obvious that it's not working properly. Maybe it's what the CIA is supposed to do for us.

There aren't enough examples of failures. Feeling and model are in our head, reality is the outside world; it doesn't change, it's real. In a primitive and simple world, there's really no reason for a model. You need models to understand a lot of the risks we face.

This model is an intelligent representation of reality. It's limited by our cognitive biases. But it has the ability to override our feelings. Models can come from the media, from our elected officials ... We get them from religion, from culture, teachers, elders.

A lot of models come from science. Health models are a great example. The question is not whether this makes us safer, but whether it's worth the trade-off. We change light bulbs without even thinking about it. Our model of security around electricity is something we were born into.

When swine flu first appeared, the initial news caused a lot of overreaction. As the novelty wore off and the months went by, there was some amount of tolerance; people got used to it. When the vaccine appeared last winter, a surprising number of people refused to get it.

Security decisions have a variety of people involved. The question is: Was it worth it? The history of the past 50 years shows how a model changes and how an industry fights against a model it doesn't like. When I was a kid, no one wore a seat belt. Nowadays no kid will let you drive if you're not wearing a seatbelt.

We tend to accept data that confirms our beliefs and reject data that contradicts our beliefs. Global warming is a great example. We're terrible at models that span 80 years. New models that extend long periods of time are hard. We can have both models in our head simultaneously.

At early times, the universe was also very, very smooth. Conditions near the Big Bang are very different than the conditions of the air in this room. Things were a lot denser. The gravitational pull of things was a lot stronger near theBig Bang.

Ludwig Boltzmann, an Austrian physicist in the 19th century, helped us understand entropy. Entropy is the number of ways we can rearrange the constituents of a system so that macroscopically it looks the same. It's a clue that the early universe is not chosen randomly.

Boltzmann: The fact that you are born, and then you die, always in that order, that's because entropy is increasing. He says the early universe was very, very smooth. "The arrow of time cannot be completely understood until the beginnings of the history of the universe are reduced still further," he says.

In 1998 we learned something crucial about the universe that we didn't know before. We learned that it's accelerating. The universe is not only expanding. It is a perpetual impulse that pushes galaxies apart from each other. This has crucial implications for what the universe is going to do in the future.

There are approximately a hundred billion galaxies in the observable universe. Space may be finite or infinite, but because the universe is accelerating, there are parts of it we cannot see and never will see. Even though time goes on forever, space is limited to us. The energy of empty space brings to life quantum fluctuations.

Boltzmann studied the possibility of high entropy in the universe. He thought that space and time were explained by Isaac Newton. Boltzmann then went onto invent two very modern-sounding ideas -- the multiverse and the anthropic principle.

We live in the part of the universe where we are not affected by the universe's fluctuations. This is the part where we live in a state of thermal equilibrium. In this state, we are able to process information and talk to each other.

The universe is expanding for the last 10 billion years or so. It's cooling off. If the dark energy remains around, the stars around us will use up their nuclear fuel. They will fall into black holes. The universe that we tell you about, versus the universe that really exists.

We will live in a universe with nothing in it but black holes. That universe will last 10 to the 100 years -- a lot longer than our little universe has lived. Even black holes don't last forever. They will evaporate, and we will be left with nothing but empty space.

The Big Bang is a brute fact about the universe that you should accept and stop asking questions. Maybe the universe comes out of a universal chicken. Maybe there is something that naturally, through the growth of the laws of physics, gives rise to universe like ours in low entropy configurations.

"It's exciting to think we may finally know the answer" to why the universe is the way it is. "It reminds us that we are a part of nature and we need to take care of it" "Nothing in the universe wears out" "It's all about sex"

Radio astronomers study radio waves from space using sensitive antennas and receivers. And just like the signals that we send and receive here on Earth, we can convert these transmissions into sound. So today, I'm going to tell you a short story of the history of the universe through listening.

Alexander Graham Bell was working with Thomas Watson on the invention of the telephone. A half-mile long wire was thrown across the rooftops of several houses in Boston. The line carried the telephone signals that would later make Bell a household name. But like any long length of charged wire, it also inadvertently became an antenna.

50 years after Watson's encounter with the Sun, Bell and Watson's technology has completely transformed global communications. But whilst we have an overwhelmingly vivid visual understanding of space, we have no sense of what space sounds like. Bell employed an engineer to study those noises, to try and find out where they came from.

Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson were using the horn antenna at Bell's Holmdel laboratory to study the Milky Way. They were really listening to the galaxy in high fidelity. The Indus people left behind artifacts with writing on them. The Indus script is undeciphered. We don't know what any of these symbols mean. The symbols are most commonly found on seals. But one large sign board was found buried near the gate of a city.

Deciphering the script is not just an intellectual puzzle; it's become a question that's become deeply intertwined with the politics and the cultural history of South Asia. The script has become a battleground of sorts between three different groups of people. Some people believe that the Indus script represents an ancient Indo-European language.

The Indus script is the last major undeciphered script in the ancient world. Most of the text that we have is extremely short. All knowledge of the English language and the English alphabet has been lost. But deciphering the script is a very challenging task.

CNN's John Defterios has been working on a project to decipher the Indus Valley Civilisation. He says the process is complicated, but the results are worth the effort. Defterio: "It's a very exciting project. It's a really exciting time for me"

The Indus script shows a pattern of letters and symbols. If you were to predict the next letter, you would say it would be A. This is because the letters start with the same symbol. It could also be that the letters are connected by a series of letters.

The computer learned a statistical model of which symbols tend to occur together. The computer was successful in 75 percent of the cases in predicting the correct symbol. There's also practical use for this particular procedure. It could be really useful as we try to decipher the script by generating more data.

The Indus script falls within the range of the linguistic scripts. Language has an intermediate level of entropy; it's neither too rigid, nor is it too random. The DNA sequence from the human genome and instrumental music occupy the middle range.

The Indus script shares an important property of language. The same sentence written in English and Dutch uses the same letters of the alphabet. The computer found several texts that have very unusual patterns. They were found in present day Iraq and Iran.

The Indus Valley people used the same script to write their language. They used it to communicate with other people in the region. The question is, how did they do it? And how do we use it to write our own language? That's the challenge.

In the case of the Indus script, the problem is the reverse. You have to figure out the sounds of each of these pictures such that the entire sequence makes sense. The Indus civilization was roughly contemporaneous with the much better known Egyptian and the Mesopotamian civilizations. In Dravidian languages, the word for fish is "meen" which happens to sound just like theword for star.

The Mayans started speaking to us in the 20th century, but the Indus civilization remains silent. The decipherment of these two scripts enabled these civilizations to speak to us again directly. If we decipher the script, we would enable them to speak again.

Tasmanian devil population has been undergoing a really extremely fast decline. Concern that the species could go extinct in the wild within 20 to 30 years. The disease was first sighted in the northeast of Tasmania in 1996 and has spread across Tasmania like a huge wave.

In the area where she comes from, more than 90 percent of the Tasmanian devil population has already died of this disease. Scientists around the world were intrigued by this cancer. But they now know that this cancer is not spread by a virus. In fact, the infectious agent of disease is something altogether more sinister.

Cancer occurs when a single cell in your body acquires a set of random mutations in important genes. Once established, natural selection actually favors the continued growth of cancer. Cancer could be thought of as a strange, short-lived, self-destructive life form -- an evolutionary dead end.

Jonas is a Tasmanian devil with a large tumor on his face. Jonas and his tumor were as different from each other as you and the person sitting next to you. Jonas' tumor did not arise from cells of his own body. The tumor in Jonas probably first arose from the cells of a female Tasmanian devils.

The Tasmanian devil cancer is perhaps the ultimate cancer. It spreads through the population, has mutations that allow it to evade the immune system. It's the only cancer that we know of that's threatening an entire species with extinction. But if this can happen in Tasmanian devils, why hasn't it happened in humans?

Cancer cells that are affecting Kimbo are also found affecting dogs in New York City, in mountain villages in the Himalayas and in Outback Australia. Genetic profiling tells that it may be tens of thousands of years old. It may have first arisen from the cells of a wolf that lived alongside the Neanderthals.

Cancer is an inevitable outcome of the ability of our cells to divide and to adapt to their environments. But that does not mean that we should give up hope in the fight against cancer. Let's prevent the Tasmanian devil from being the first animal to go extinct from cancer.

Bombers used to have to drop bombs from a height of thousands of feet. Now they can do it from a distance of just a few hundred feet. The technology is called the Norden Mark 15 bombsight. It has all kinds of levers and ball-bearings.

Norden's bombsight allowed the U.S. military to hit targets at 20,000 feet. The project cost $1.5 billion, half the amount spent on the Manhattan Project. "It was like manna from heaven," Norden says of his invention.

The U.S. military buys 90,000 of these Norden bombsights at a cost of $14,000 each. They trained 50,000 bombardiers on how to use them. The bombsight can drop a bomb into a pickle barrel at 20,000 ft.

The Norden bombsight was used in the Second World War. It was designed to fly at low altitude. But in real life, it can't do that. The Norden bomb was used to make bombs for the war effort. It can't fly at high altitudes.

The Norden bombsight was designed by Carl Norden, a Swiss engineer. The Nazis used the bombsight during the Second World War. The bombsight didn't work very well; only 10 percent of the bombs landed. The Pentagon says it can now put a bomb inside a pickle barrel at 20,000 ft.

Carl Norden was born in 1880. His mission was to get rid of all the Scud missile launchers. After the war was over, he asked: How many Scuds did we actually destroy? And the answer was not a single one. The issue was they didn't know where the Scuds were.

The CIA has used drones to kill 2,000 suspected Pakistani and Taliban militants. "We think we're now at 95 percent accuracy when it comes to drone strikes. That is one of the most extraordinary records in the history of modern warfare"

On August 6, 1945, a B-29 bomber called the Enola Gay flew over Japan and, using a Norden bombsight, dropped a very large thermonuclear device on the city of Hiroshima. Meanwhile, back in New York, no one told Carl Norden that his bombsight was used over Hiroshima.

Cancer is like a "post-it" note: it remembers that it's cancer. Scientists are trying to make a molecule that prevents the Post-it note from sticking. The molecule, called JQ1, was developed at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.

The drug is used to treat multiple myeloma, an incurable form of cancer. The drug is made from a type of fat that can be removed from the body. It's being tested in the U.S. and Europe, but is still in development.

In the early 2000s, a study found that countries with a higher proportion of trustworthy people are more prosperous. In his lab, he tempts people with virtue and vice by using money. "If you're so virtuous, show me the money," he says.

In a test of trust, two people give money to each other. The money is then transferred to the second person. The second person receives the money. The first person is left with the money, and the money is returned to the first person.

Researchers found that the more money the second person received, the more their brain produced oxytocin. Researchers used an inhaler to measure the level of oxytocins in the brain. Researchers found that those on the drug showed more trust than those on a placebo.

Oxytocin infusion increases generosity in unilateral monetary transfers by 80 percent. We showed it increases donations to charity by 50 percent. Non-pharmacologic ways to raise oxytocin include massage, dancing and praying. People willingly open up their wallets and share money with strangers. But why do they do this?

Adam Smith was a moral philosopher, and he was right on why we're moral. He said we're social creatures, so we share the emotions of others. Knowing that molecule is valuable, because it tells us how to turn up this behavior and what turns it off.

A man bought a necklace for his wife at a gas station and couldn't find it. The store owner offered a $200 reward to find the owner. The man said he couldn't do it because he had a job interview in 15 minutes and had to go. "I wanted to go further than to say our brains make us moral," he says.

Oxytocin makes us feel what other people feel. It's so easy to cause people's brains to release oxytocin. We have found that people who release more Oxytocin are happier. And they're happier because they have better relationships of all types.

The Transition is a light sport aircraft that can carry 110 lbs. It is the first of its kind to be approved by the FAA. The aircraft can be flown by a pilot with as little as 20 hours of flight time. The FAA has given the company an exemption for the aircraft to be certified.

CNN's John Defterios takes a behind-the-scenes look at the U.S. Air Force's new high-tech plane. He says the plane is designed to be used for off-road driving, not just flying. The plane has a continuously-variable transmission and a liquid-based cooling system.

The Terrafugia Transition has an automated wing-folding mechanism. The wings are fully capable of handling any of the loads you would see in flight. The first deliveries to the, about a hundred, people who have reserved an airplane should begin at the end of next year.

The Transition will cost in line with other small airplanes. There are thousands of local airstrips that don't see nearly as many aircraft operations a day as they could. Instead of paying to keep your airplane in a hanger, park it in your garage.

The Terrafugia Transition is a two-seat, single-engine airplane that works just like any other small airplane. So why is it that we move the particular ways we do? Maybe we don't all quite move the same way. Maybe there's variation in the population. And maybe those who move better than others have more chance of getting their children into the next generation.

The brain is there and evolved to control movement. The fundamental idea is you want to plan your movements so as to minimize the negative consequence of the noise. There are many diseases which effect movement. And hopefully if we understand how we control movement, we can apply that to robotic technology.

The brain is a very complex organ, says the evolutionary psychologist. He says it's important to understand how movement plays a key role in the development of the brain. "You have to study vision with the realization of how the movement system is going to use vision," he says.

I believe movement is the most important function of the brain -- don't let anyone tell you that it's not true. How well are we doing understanding how the brain controls movement? And the answer is we're doing extremely poorly; it's a very hard problem. I think if IBM's Deep Blue played anyone in this room, it would win every time.

Robot can pour water into a glass, but it doesn't do it with anything like the agility of a human. Robot can also stack 12 cups against the clock in real time, but that's another three-year program. There is no generalization at all from one task to another in robotics.

In my group, what we try to do is reverse engineer how humans control movement. And it sounds like an easy problem. You send a command down, it causes muscles to contract. Your arm or body moves, and you get sensory feedback from vision, from skin, from muscles and so on.

CNN's Richard Quest explains how the brain works. He says the brain has to deal with a lot of noise and uncertainty. Quest: "You want to generate beliefs about the world. So we're going to represent a belief with a number between zero and one"

Bayesian decision theory gives you the mathematics of the optimal way to combine your prior knowledge with your sensory evidence to generate new beliefs. "I'm not going to explain what that formula is, but it's very beautiful. And it has real beauty and real explanatory power," he says.

The brain is designed to produce adaptable and complex movements. We learn about the world but also learn about how noisy our own sensory apparatus is. The brain makes predictions of the sensory feedback it's going to get in the future. It profoundly changes your perceptions by what you do.

You might have a little predictor, a neural simulator, of the physics of your body and your senses. As you send a movement command down, you tap a copy of that off and run it into your neural simulator to anticipate the sensory consequences of your actions. If I've got a good predictor, it predicts the same thing.

The human body is made up of a series of muscles. These muscles are used to move objects in a certain way. In this video, we see how these muscles work together to create the sensation of a tickle. We also see how they react to different types of light and sound.

Neuroscientist says the brain's making precise predictions and subtracting them off from the sensations. He says the tickle sensation on the palm comes and goes, and you need large numbers of subjects with these stars making them significant. He hypothesizes that when one child hits another, they generate the movement command.

The game is very simple. We use a motor to apply force down to player one's fingers for three seconds and then it stops. And that player's been told, remember the experience of that force and use your other finger to apply the same force to the other person's finger.

There is a 70 percent escalation in force on each go. So it really suggests that the brain is canceling the sensory consequences and underestimating the force it's producing. We all move the same way pretty much, so there's a big gap between the task and the movement system.

We store our information as DNA in our genomes and we pass this information on to our offspring. Life also has a kind of inheritable information. If we couple the first two -- the body and the metabolism -- we can come up with a system that could perhaps move and replicate.

We use this idea called self-assembly. I can mix some chemicals together in a test tube in my lab, and these chemicals will start to self-associate to form larger and larger structures. We can use these, as they say, to form the body of our protocell.

Scientists have blurred the line between non-living and living systems. But a living system must be able to use energy to maintain itself, like living systems do. Scientists have developed a new model of a protocell that can use energy in a dynamic way.

The system has a body, it has a metabolism, it can use energy, it moves around. It can sense its local environment and actually find resources in the environment to sustain itself. This is just a sack of chemicals that is able to have this interesting and complex lifelike behavior.

Scientists have been mixing together nonliving ingredients to make new structures in the lab. They hope the new structures might have some of the characteristics of living systems. The new structures could have something to tell us about the origin of life on the Earth.

The origin of life would have looked like this: junk that is present on the early Earth, 4.5 billion years ago. So the challenge then is to make some protocells with lifelike properties from this primordial ooze. These are also, these tar-fueled protocells, are also able to locate resources in their environment. They become very energetic, and able to find the resource in the environment.

Life has to be in non-equilibrium, in liquid form, in a form that can exploit energy from the Sun to maintain itself. Life also has to convert resources from the environment into building blocks so it can maintain and build itself. The next work is a sound-sensitive installation called "The Pygmies"

"Space Filler" is made up of fur embedded with thousands of tiny different sizes of fiber optics, which twinkle like the night sky. "The idea was to sort of contrast something very cold and distant and abstract like the universe into the familiar form of a teddy bear"

The "Uncle Phone" is a digital phone that can send messages to a recipient in seconds. The device was created to replace the traditional phone, which takes a long time to send a message. The phone was created after the Bamiyan Buddhas were blown up by the Taliban.

CyArk is a foundation dedicated to digital heritage preservation of world sites. To date, with the help of a global network of partners, we've completed close to fifty projects. The data can be used to develop 3D models that are very accurate and very detailed.

"We're losing our sites and the stories, and basically we're losing a piece of our collective memory," he says. "In order to continue our work, we need to develop new technology," he adds. "We need to be able to use the new technology to preserve our history and culture"

CyArk is a 3D scanning company based in the San Francisco Bay Area. The company has been working on a project to digitally preserve a Ugandan heritage site. The site was destroyed by a fire in March, but the data is now available to the public.

The brain is the place in which all of the more complex thought, decision making -- it's the last to mature in late adulthood. With two mirrors, the scanner calculates the beam's horizontal and vertical angles. The point is then recorded into a 3D visualization.

Human brain is one continuous processing unit, if you will. It's cells and it's wires all wired together. There's about 86 billion neurons in our brain. How they're distributed really contributes to their underlying function. And of course, since we can now start to map brain function, we can start to tie these into the individual cells.

Each neuron is connected via synapses to up to 10,000 other neurons in your brain. Each neuron itself is largely unique. The unique character of both individual neurons and neurons within a collection of the brain are driven by fundamental properties of their underlying biochemistry.

The project is seeking to look at this readout, understanding which of these 25,000 genes is turned on. The first thing that we do at the site of collection is we collect what's called an MR. imaging. We're also selecting for brains in which we can get the tissue.

The brain is removed from the skull, and then it's sliced into one-centimeter slices. These are frozen solid, and they're shipped to Seattle. The next thing we do is we collect what's called a diffusion tensor imaging. This maps the large cabling in the brain.

Scientists use old-fashioned technology to create detailed maps of a brain. They melt a microscope slide and then melt it onto a robot that applies stains to it. Scientists then use this to go back to another piece of that tissue and do what's called laser scanning microdissection.

We take tissue, we purify the RNA out of it using some basic technology, and then we put a florescent tag on it. We take that tagged material and we put it on to something called a microarray. Each one of these individual dots is actually a unique piece of the human genome.

The MR tool provides a common framework for people to understand where genes are turned on and off. The red levels are where a gene is turned on to a great degree. Green is the sort of cool areas where it's not turned on. Each gene gives us a fingerprint.

Scientists can now see where genes are turned on by drugs. Proteins are targets for drugs, so drugs bind to proteins and either turn them off. Scientists can scan through the entire genome and find other proteins that show a similar fingerprint. It's as interesting a side effect as it could be.

The human brain is very similar to the rest of the body, says Dr. David Wheeler. Wheeler: "It's important to show that we are not so different that we can't communicate with each other" He says the human brain has a lot of similarities with other parts of the world.

phthalmologist: "This is truly an unexplored, undiscovered continent" "These are things where genes are turned on in an individual cell type," he says. "It's this dark purple precipitate within the cell that's telling us a gene is turned on there" "I think these resources are incredibly valuable"

It takes this worm two days to age as much as the normal worm ages in one day. One gene is changed out of 20,000, and look at it. It's the same age, but it's not in the nursing home; it's going skiing.

Scientists have for a long time thought this just was never going to be possible. The daf-2 gene encodes a hormone receptor. Part of it's on the outside, and it's catching the hormone as it comes by. The other part is on the inside where it sends signals into the cell.

Daf-2 hormone receptor is very similar to the receptor for the hormone insulin and IGF-1. Insulin is a hormone that promotes the uptake of nutrients into your tissues after you eat a meal. IGF- 1 promotes growth. These functions were known for these hormones for a long time, but our studies suggested that maybe they had a third function that nobody knew about.

Hormone pathway in flies, mice and humans is an ancient one. People who lived to 90 or 100 were more likely to have daf-2 mutations. These changes made the gene not act as well as the normal gene would have acted.

In the daf-2 mutants, a whole lot of genes are switched on in the DNA that encode proteins that protect the cells and the tissues, and repair damage. The way that they're switched on is by a gene regulator protein called FOXO. FOXO turns on a number of genes, including antioxidant genes that help other proteins to function well.

The daf-2 mutant has genes that prevent FOXO from getting into the nucleus where the DNA is. This prevents the genes from being turned on, which is why the worm lives longer. Many of these genes, we've shown, actually contribute to the long lifespan of the mutant.

Scientists have found that certain forms of the FOXO gene have found to be more frequently present in people who live to be 90 or 100. FOXO genes can impact the lifespan of people. If they exist and you can find them, then maybe one could eventually do something about it.

Researchers are trying to develop drugs that will activate a protein that affects lifespan in people. mutations that damage the TOR gene -- just like the daf-2 mutations -- extend lifespan in worms and flies and mice. There's already a drug called rapamycin that binds to the TOR protein.

The drug would just bind to the protein itself and change its activity. If you stop taking the drug, the protein would go back to normal. There are other ways of activating FOXO that don't even involve insulin or IGF-1 that might even be safer.

There are some creatures on this planet that don't really do aging. Nobody knows if they really can live forever, or what keeps them from aging. mutations that damage one single gene called daf-2 doubled the lifespan of the little worm.

Cynthia Kenyon is the author of the book "The Power of Now" The book is based on Kenyon's observations of the human body. Kenyon: "I think, that may well be taken away by science is then replaced by something as wonderful as astrology"

Many Worlds theory is one of the most beautiful, fascinating, sometimes terrifying ideas from the quantum interpretation. Every single thing that makes us, every atom in us, has already created a myriad of different things. We have been mountains and apples and pulsars and others' knees.

We are all totally recyclable. We don't even have to be placed in different refuse sacs. Love does not die because of that thing. This is a terrible thing, even though I understand pain. It is basically momentum to energy where the four- vector is constant.

"The more the universe seems comprehensible, the more it seems pointless," says the author. "I'm glad the universe is pointless. You can make your own purpose," he says. "That's what I do. That's what the universe does."

Asteroid was 300 kilometers across -- 200 miles -- an enormous crater that excavated out vast amounts of earth. Video cameras were just starting to become popular, and parents would bring them to their kids' football games to film their kids playing football.

In 1908, a huge rock blew up over Siberia. The explosion caused a huge shock wave that wiped out hundreds of square miles of forest. The rock was about the size of the Macky Auditorium in New York City. It's not clear what caused the explosion, but it was huge.

20 megatons are very rare, but they are still a potential threat. If one of these things were to hit pretty much anywhere, it would cause a panic. The one over Tunguska was probably made of rock, and that's much more crumbly, so it blew up in the air. A chunk of rock six miles across, moving something like 50 times the speed of a rifle bullet, slammed into the Earth.

The asteroid Apophis blew up over Tunguska and hit Arizona 50,000 years ago. NASA has devoted money to this; the National Science Foundation and other countries are interested in doing this. We're building telescopes that are looking for the threat. If we see one heading toward us, we have to stop it.

Apophis is an asteroid that was discovered in 2004. It's going to pass by the Earth in April of 2029. The odds of it actually passing through this keyhole and hitting us next go-around are one in a million, roughly -- very, very low odds.

In 2005, NASA launched a probe called Deep Impact, which slammed a piece of itself into the nucleus of a comet. The purpose wasn't to push it out of the way; the purpose was to make a crater to excavate the material and see what was underneath the surface of this comet.

The B612 Foundation is a group of scientists and engineers and astronauts. B612 is a six-mile-wide rock that lived on an asteroid called B612. "The Little Prince" was based on the asteroid, which is located in the asteroid belt between Earth and Mars.

If we see an asteroid that's going to hit the Earth and we have enough time, we can hit it to move it into a better orbit. The gravity of the asteroid pulls on the probe, and the probe has a couple of tons of mass. You can even put in orbit around the Earth where we could mine it, although that's a whole other thing.

We invented something called an ion drive, which is a low-thrust engine. It generates the force a piece of paper would have on your hand. It can run for months and years, providing that very gentle push. Chemical rockets provide too much thrust, too much push.

The robot can be controlled by a computer or a person. It can also be moved by the user with almost no force. The robot is named Rezero after the dinosaur that hit the Yucatan Peninsula. It is not yet clear whether the robot will be used in the future.

All spiders make silk at some point in their life. Spiders use silk for many purposes, including the trailing safety dragline and wrapping eggs for reproduction. Even fossil spiders can make silk, as we can see from this impression of a spinneret on a fossil spider.

The frame and radii of this web is made up of one type of silk, while the capture spiral is a composite of two different silks. Inside each spider, there are hundreds of silk glands, sometimes thousands. They differ by size, shape, and sometimes even color.

Spider silk is almost entirely protein. It's used to make the frame and radii of an orb web, and also the safety trailing dragline. There's also aciniform silk, which is used to wrap prey, and major ampullate silk, used in web construction.

silk biologists try to relate sequences, these amino acid sequences, to the mechanical properties of the silk fibers. Dragline, or major ampullate silk, is the strongest of these fibers. The flagelliform fiber can actually stretch over twice its original length.

There are more than 40,000 species of spider. Some of them are orb-weaving, others are not. Spiders are able to make silk that is tough enough to catch and kill prey. The spider is able to do this by using a variety of different types of silk.

The strength, extensibility and toughness of spider silks have attracted a lot of interest. Silks could be incorporated into body and equipment armor that would be more lightweight and flexible than any armor available today. The next time you see a spider web, please, pause and look a little closer.

You'll be seeing one of the most high-performance materials known to man. (Applause) So what this figure shows is that spiders date back to almost 380 million years. To put that into perspective, this red vertical bar marks the divergence time of humans from chimpanzees, a mere seven million years ago.
