Why care if it is the brain stem or the cerebral cortex and how this is made? Three reasons. First, curiosity. Second, understanding society and culture. Third, medicine. It would be ridiculous to claim that we know how we make consciousness in our brains.

What is consciousness? What is a conscious mind? We could take a very simple view and say, well, it is that which we lose when we fall into deep sleep without dreams, or when we go under anesthesia. But there is something else that we are all experiencing in this room. We are not passive exhibitors of visual or auditory or tactile images. We have selves.

In order to have a conscious mind, you have a self within the conscious mind. A conscious mind is a mind with a self in it. We are only fully conscious when self comes to mind. We have a sense that it's everyone of us that is experiencing this -- not the person next to you.

If I scan my retina through the horizontal plane, what I get is the following. On the right side, my retina is perfectly symmetrical. But on my left retina there is a bump, which is marked there by the red arrow. And it corresponds to a little cyst that is located below. And that is exactly what causes the warping of my visual image.

The self is really the elusive problem. We generate brain maps of the body's interior and use them as the reference for all other maps. We have one body, not two, not three. There is just one reference point, which is the body.

The body has many parts, and things grow at different rates, and they have different sizes and different people; however, not so with the interior. The things that have to do with what is known as our internal milieu are, in fact, extremely maintained day after day. If you deviate too much in the parameters that are close to the midline of that life-permitting survival range, you go into disease or death.

If you damage the brain stem, you get complete paralysis, but your conscious mind is maintained. The brain stem provides the grounding for the self in a very tight interconnection with the body. The cerebral cortex provides the great spectacle of our minds with the profusion of images.

The brain stem is the main source of consciousness in humans. It's the same in other species, but they have different types of brain stem. The brain stem and the brain stem are the source of our self-consciousness. The self is the part of the brain that is connected to the body.

When a person gets a retinal degenerative disease like macular degeneration, he or she is blind. The prosthetic mimics the actions of the front-end circuitry and sends signals to the retina's output cells. A completely blind retina can now send out normal signals, signals that the brain can understand.

The encoder is replacing the retinal circuitry with a set of equations. An image comes in, and out comes streams of electrical pulses, just like a normal retina would produce. The equations are serving as sort of a codebook for the retina.

Researchers used a combination of an encoder and a transducer to reconstruct what a blind person's retina was seeing. With the standard method, patients can see high-contrast edges, they can see light, but it doesn't easily go further than that. With our approach, adding the code, it's much better. Not only can you tell that it's a baby's face, but you can also tell it is a baby.

There are many people worldwide who are blind or are facing blindness due to diseases of the retina, diseases like macular degeneration, and there's little that can be done for them. For the vast majority of patients, their best hope for regaining sight is through prosthetic devices. The problem is that current prosthetics don't work very well.

The World Bank estimates that a hospital in this setting in a low-income country can expect up to 18 power outages per month. compressed oxygen and other medical supplies are really a luxury, and can often be out of stock for months or even a year.

The power went out during a routine surgery in Malawi. The nurse was able to anesthetize her patient quickly. The surgeon was on call and scrubbed in with a headlamp to finish his case. 35 million surgeries are attempted every year without safe anesthesia, says CNN's John Sutter.

The Universal Anesthesia Machine is a machine that would work and anesthetize his patients no matter the circumstances that his hospital had to offer. The machine has a built-in oxygen concentrator that takes in room air and sends 95 percent pure oxygen up and across to the patient.

The machine is designed to stand up to the heat and the wear and tear that happens in these rural districts. It comes in at an eighth of the cost of the conventional machine that I showed you earlier. You do not need to be a highly trained, specialized anesthesiologist to use it.

Since 2010, we've done well over 2,000 surgeries with no clinically adverse events. This really seems like a cost-effective, scalable solution to a problem that's really pervasive. But we still want to be sure that this is the most effective and safe device that we can be putting into hospitals.

CNN's John Sutter talks about the role of place cells in the human brain. Place cells are the cells that tell the brain where to look. Sutter: Place cells help people remember where they are in the world. He says place cells can also be used to help people find their way out of trouble.

The hippocampus is the organ of memory in the human brain. It is particularly important for the ability to remember distances and directions of boundaries around you. The hippocampus fires when it detects boundaries or edges at particular distances. This is one way in which place cells determine where the animal is as it's exploring around.

Grid cells are found, again, on the inputs to the hippocampus, and they're a bit like place cells. Each individual cell fires in a whole array of different locations which are laid out across the environment in an amazingly regular triangular grid. The electrical activity can pass from one of these cells to the next cell to keep track of where it is.

The human brain has about a hundred billion neurons in it. The neurons communicate with each other by sending little pulses or spikes of electricity via connections to each other. So it may be that the neural mechanisms for representing the space around us are also used for generating visual imagery.

Scientists have begun to understand how spatial memory works by recording from individual neurons in rats or mice. Nanotyrannus has juvenile bone and the bigger one has more mature bone. At the Museum of the Rockies where we work, I have four T. rexes, so I can cut a whole bunch of them. The biggest one had 12 teeth and the next smallest one had 13.

In the early 1900s, everyone wanted a bigger and better Tyrannosaur. By the 1970s, scientists were asking, "Where are all the little dinosaurs?" People assumed if they had little dinosaurs, they'd be easy to identify. But all they had were big dinosaurs.

In 1975, Dr. Peter Dodson at the University of Pennsylvania realized that dinosaurs grew kind of like birds do, which is different than the way reptiles grow. And it's kind of cool -- if you look at the cassowary, or any of the birds that have crests on their heads, they grow to about 80 percent adult size before the crest starts to grow.

Researchers found that if you were to take a baby and an adult and make an average of what it should look like, if it grew in sort of a linear fashion, it would have a crest about half the size of the adult. But the actual subadult had no crest at all.

Dinosaurs are very hard to cut open. They're very spongy. So they don't normally let you do that. So I have to cut them open. And that's sort of what I've been doing. And we want to look at these three.

Pachycephalosaurus has a big, thick dome on its head, and it's got some little bumps on the back of its head. And then Stygoloch, another dinosaur from the same time, has a little, tiny dome, and It's got a bunch of gnarly stuff on its nose.

Dracorex is the littlest one, Stygimoloch is the middle-size one, Pachycephalosaurus is the largest one. Scientists like to name things. The dome, that little dome, is growing really fast. It's inflating very fast.

The spikes on the back of the Stygimoloch are actually resorbing, which means they're getting smaller as that dome is getting bigger. Pachycephalosaurus has a solid dome and its little bumps on theback of its head were also resorbed.

Triceratops' horns curve backwards as they grow up, then grow forward as they get older. The adult Triceratops was also spongy, but the adult Torosaurus had mature bone. Torosaurus is a dinosaur that is found in this formation that looks like a Tricer atops, except it's bigger and it's called Torosaurus.

Triceratops and Torosaurus can't possibly be the same animal because one of them's bigger than the other one. But one of my graduate students, John Scannella, looked through our whole collection and he actually discovered that the hole starting to form in Triceratops is open in Torosaurus.

Sharks have more right to be fearful of us than we have of them, says Michael O'Leary. The importance of basking sharks to the coast communities is recognized through the language. In Kerry they were often known as "ainmhide Na seolta," "the monster with the sails"

Basking sharks are listed as vulnerable under the IUCN. They're the second-largest fish in the world. There's a ban on catching and even landing them, even landing ones caught accidentally. Some say it's not population decline, it might be a change in the distribution of plankton.

Basking sharks are harmless plankton-feeding animals. They are thought to be able to filter a cubic kilometer of water every hour. They can feed on 30 kilos of zoo plankton a day to survive. Scientists use a pole camera on the boat to actually film the shark.

The tags are attached to the shark and sent to a satellite. The satellite sends a signal to the tag, which is then sent to the ground. The tags can be used to track the shark's movements in the Irish Sea and the Atlantic Ocean.

Basking sharks were important to coastal communities, going back hundreds of years, especially around the Claddaghduff, Connemara region. subsistence farmers used to sail out on their hookers and open boats, sometimes way offshore to a place called the Sunfish Bank to kill the basking sharks.

Basking sharks have incredibly low diversity, according to a new study. The study found no genetic differentiation between any of the world's oceans of basking sharks. The whale shark's diversity is much greater, the study found. It's thought maybe it was a genetic bottleneck, thought to have been 12,000 years ago, that caused the low diversity.

There are only 8,000 basking sharks left in the world. The population is so small that it is at risk of extinction. The only source of sharks in Ireland is dead sharks washed up on the coast. Some are caught in nets, in trawls, which are banned.

CNN's John Defterios gives a look at the impact of climate change on North America. He says it could destroy the Great Bear Rainforest, the largest temperate rainforest in the world. It could also have huge impacts on the future of the agricultural heartland of North America, he says. Defterio: Join with the growing international community to get Canada to step up to its responsibilities.

The Alberta tar sands are the largest oil reserves on the planet outside of Saudi Arabia. They are home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world. The mining and the exploitation of that is creating devastation on a scale that the planet has never seen before.

The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of Canada's boreal forest. No tar sands mine has actually ever been denied approval, so it is essentially a rubber stamp. Oil produced from either method produces more greenhouse gas emissions than any other oil.

The tailings ponds range in size up to 9,000 acres. That's two-thirds the size of the entire island of Manhattan. The Athabasca River drains downstream to a range of aboriginal communities. In Fort Chipewyan, the 800 people there, are finding toxins in the food chain.

The boreal forest sequesters more carbon than any other terrestrial ecosystem. The boreal is home to almost 50 percent of the 800 bird species found in North America. It is also the last refuge for the largest herd of wild bison in the world.

The Great Bear Rainforest is considered to be the largest coastal temperate rainforest in the world. It is threatened by the massive amount of water being drawn from the Athabasca River. The pipeline would take natural gas from the Beaufort Sea through the heart of the rainforest.

The world does not need any more fossil fuels. We need to ensure that our best and greatest defense against global warming is protected. And we can do that by working together to protect our environment and the lives of the people who live in it.

The first time I saw the dark night sky, I was just flabbergasted at how many stars there were, and I felt tiny. Technology is allowing us to access the sky in ways that are impossible otherwise. 60-70% of the energy we use to light the outdoors is wasted by blotting out the stars. The Hubble space telescope allows us to see things that we are incapable of seeing with our naked eye.

The story of the fall of Belshazzar and the birth of the Persian empire is told in a new novel. The novel, "Cyrus," is based on the life of the Babylonian king, who declared himself king of the universe. The book is written by a team of highly skilled consultants.

In the Book of Chronicles, the king of the four quarters of the world tells the story of the return of the Jews from Babylon. The Jews were allowed to return to Jerusalem and to rebuild the temple. This is the central element, still, of the notion of return in Judaism.

Cyrus was the first great world empire. He set up a model of how you run a great multinational, multifaith, multicultural society. He left a dream of the Middle East as a unit, and a unit where people of different faiths could live together.

Cyrus was a central figure in Greek and European culture. He was the inspiration for the Founding Fathers of the U.S. The remains of his clay cylinder were discovered in Babylon in 1879. The discovery brought hope to those who believed in the scriptures.

CNN's John Sutter looks at the difference between the two accounts of the birth of God in the Bible. Sutter says the account of Marduk is more likely to be true than the one given by the Bible's writers. He says it's a remarkable example of two different ways of seeing the same thing.

The Cyrus cylinder was created in 1879 by the Shah of Iran. The cylinder is part of the Pahlavi dynasty's celebrations in Persepolis. The Shah invents an Iranian history that puts him in the center of a great tradition. It's an object with fascinating stories that are by no means over yet.

The Cyrus cylinder is a symbol of Iran's history and culture. The British Museum has loaned it to the National Museum of Tehran. The cylinder is seen by between one and two million people in the space of a few months. It's the subject of a huge debate about what this cylinder means.

The three things gay Americans seem to want most are to join the military, get married and start a family. The joke short circuits the emotional wiring behind the debate and it leaves the audience with the opportunity, through their laughter, to question its validity.

Comedy has been crossing country with remarkable speed way before the Internet, social media, even cable TV. First there were drums and then knock-knock jokes. When you get the viral appeal of a great joke with a powerful punchline, it can have a real world impact at changing a conversation.

Behavioral finance is extremely powerful. Overpopulation of relationships makes fights unavoidable. Property fights are the biggest trigger for all sibling fights. Over 95 percent of the fights among small children concern somebody touching, playing with, looking at the other person's stuff.

Children are born with a sense of right and wrong. They learn this through their siblings. They also learn to stand up for each other. This is how they learn to deal with conflict. It is also how they deal with the loss of their parents and siblings.

Siblings are among the richest harvests of the time we have here. Our parents leave us too early, our spouse and our children come along too late. Our siblings are the only ones who are with us for the entire ride.

When I was a boy, my brother and I would go to the park and play with our friends. We would often get into trouble because we were too young to know how to play with the other kids. One day, we decided to make a game out of it, but it turned out to be a nightmare for us.

Siblings can claim none of that uniqueness. They're interchangeable, fungible, a kind of household commodity. The only limitation would be in sperm, egg and economics. Animals wrestle with these same issues, too. But they have a more straight-forward way of dealing with things.

In day-to-day life, this translates into greater enjoyment and satisfaction. The most mentally sharp older adults are the ones who show this positivity effect the most.

Inside a superconductor there are no collisions, so there is no energy dissipation. This is a quantum effect. These are not particles, but they behave like particles. So, this is why we call this effect quantum levitation and quantum locking.

Superconductor doesn't like strands of magnetic field left inside, because their movements dissipate energy. Superconductor locks these strands, which are called fluxons, and it locks these fluxons in place. This is quantum locking -- actually locking -- three-dimensional locking of the superconductor.

Superconductivity is a quantum state of matter, and it occurs only below a certain critical temperature. The superconductor is only half a micron thick. It is able to levitate more than 70,000 times its own weight.

Superconductors can be used to create strong magnetic fields. They can also be used as power cables to transfer electricity. The phenomenon is called quantum levitation and quantum locking. The technology is still in its early stages, but it could be used in the future.

GPS signals are completely open. They have no encryption or authentication. They're wide open, vulnerable to a kind of spoofing attack. Researchers used a polarization filter to see what the beetles were looking at when they climbed on top of a ball. They found that the sun is a very important cue in the sky for the beetles. They then moved the sun with a mirror to a completely different position. The beetles then did a double dance and went back in the same direction they came from.

The beetles are looking at celestial cues in the sky, some of which you and I can't see. The dance is this transition behavior that allows them to reorient themselves. The beetle knows exactly where he's going. He knows exactly what the problem is, and he knows how to deal with it.

Dung beetles eat dung, and their larvae are also dung-feeders. When the ground is very hot, they dance more often, and when they do this particular dance, they wipe the bottom of their face. Researchers thought that maybe what they're doing is trying to get off the hot soil.

The Pachysoma dung beetle has a unique thermal behavior. The beetle climbs on top of a ball of dung and wipes its face. This is called stilting. The beetles climb onto the ball far less often when they have boots on.

Within South Africa, we've got about 800 species of dung beetles, and in Africa we have 2,000 species. In the world, there are about 6,000 dung beetle species. This is a different species in the same genus but exactly the same foraging behavior.

The dung beetle uses a technique called path integration to find its home. If it is displace it, the beetle will end up in the wrong place. The beetle then uses landmark orientation to try and find its burrow. But it fails to recognise the landmarks around it and ends up completely lost.

Oxitec has been working on the technology for the last 10 years. The company has done field trials in the Cayman Islands, Malaysia and Brazil. Oxitec says it has taken the mosquito population down by about 85 percent in about four months.

Comparing your rates of dying 50 degrees north -- that's the South, that's London and places -- by latitude, and 55 degrees -- the bad news is that's here, Glasgow. We are left with this missing space of increased deaths the further north you go. And vitamin D has had a great deal of press, and a lot of people get concerned about it.

Vitamin D is good for the heart, but not for the rest of the body. The higher a person's vitamin D level, the less likely they are to suffer from heart disease. Vitamin D is found in the body through the skin and in the blood.

The skin produces nitric oxide, which lowers blood pressure and stops angina. The molecule is a simple molecule, a nitrogen and an oxygen that are stuck together. It's hugely important for our low blood pressure, for neurotransmission, for many, many things.

dermatologist Morton Bast says sunlight can activate the production of nitric oxide in the skin of humans. Bast: "We couldn't reproduce in man the data we had shown in mice" Bast: Could the sun activate those stores into the circulation, and there in the circulation do its good things for your cardiovascular system?

Vitamin D is made by ultraviolet B rays and we wanted to separate our story from the vitamin D story. So we used ultraviolet A, which doesn't make vitamin D. When we put people under a lamp for the equivalent of about 30 minutes of sunshine in summer in Edinburgh, what we produced was a rise in circulating nitric oxide.

The study looked at the effect of ultraviolet light on the blood vessels. It found that when the sun shone on the skin, there was no change in blood flow. But when it shone on other parts of the body, the blood flow was affected.

The skin has large stores of nitric oxide as well as other forms. The sunlight releases this where it has generally beneficial effects. Australians have about a third less heart disease than we do. We think it probably accounts for a lot of the north-south health divide within Britain.

Sunlight is the major alterable risk factor for skin cancer, but deaths from heart disease are a hundred times higher than deaths from skin cancer. Within Britain, there is a gradient of health -- and this is what's called standardized mortality, basically your chances of dying. But it's not just Australia that has better health than Britain.

The United States has grown at 2.0 percent per year from 1891 to 2007. The vertical axis now is thousands of dollars in today's prices. Americans in the future can't expect to be twice as well off as their parents.

Two-percent growth quadruples your standard of living in 70 years. That means we'd go from 44,000 to 180,000. But we're not going to do that, and the reason is the headwinds. The first headwind is demographics. The next is education.

Growth rate of the bottom 99 percent of the income distribution was half a point slower than the averages in the 15 years before the financial crisis. By 1929, electric light was everywhere. Central Manhattan became possible. Electricity was also very helpful in liberating women.

In the late 19th century, the only source of heat in most homes was a big fireplace in the kitchen. By 1929, certainly by 1950, we had central heating everywhere. Before the motor vehicle, transportation depended entirely on the urban horse, which dropped 25 to 50 pounds of manure on the streets every day.

In 1885, the average North Carolina housewife walked 148 miles a year carrying 35 tons of water. By 1929, cities around the country had put in underground water pipes. Electrification, central heat, ownership of motor cars, they all went from zero to 100 percent.

By 1960 we had telephone bills, bank statements were being produced by computers. The 1980s brought us Bill Gates, DOS, ATM machines to replace bank tellers. There are four headwinds that are just hitting the American economy in the face. They're demographics, education, debt and inequality.

Growth has been decoupled from jobs, and income of the typical worker is stagnating. So we need a lot of innovation to offset this decline. If innovation is less powerful, invents less great, wonderful things, growth is going to be even lower than half of history.

Worldwide incomes have grown at a faster rate in the past decade than ever in history. The new machine age is more about knowledge creation than just physical production. The New Yorker is trying to make cartoons say something besides funny and something about us. The humor is self-reflective and makes us think about our assumptions. The New Yorker focuses on our obsessions, our narcissism, our foils and our foibles.

consciousness is a biological phenomenon like photosynthesis, digestion, mitosis -- you know all the biological phenomena. Once you accept that, most, though not all, of the hard problems about consciousness simply evaporate. It's embarrassing how influential behaviorism was, but I'll get to that.

consciousness is a necessary condition on anything being important in our lives that we're conscious. consciousness consists of all those states of feeling or sentience or awareness. The distinction between reality and illusion is the distinction between how things consciously seem to us and how they really are. consciousness is real and irreducible. You cannot get rid of it by showing that it's an illusion in a way that you can with other standard illusions. Since we don't know how our brains do it, we're not in a position, so far, to build a conscious machine.

Eleanor was diagnosed with schizophrenia after hearing a voice in her head. The voice told her she had low self-worth, anxiety and fears about the future. She was referred to a psychiatrist who interpreted everything she said through a lens of latent insanity. The voices became increasingly hostile and menacing.

Eleanor's mental health status had been a catalyst for discrimination, verbal abuse, and physical and sexual assault. She was so tormented by the voices that she attempted to drill a hole in her head in order to get them out. Eleanor says her voices were not her enemies but a source of insight into solvable emotional problems.

The voices were closely related to aspects of myself, and carried overwhelming emotions. The most hostile and aggressive voices actually represented the parts of me that had been hurt most profoundly. The voices took the place of this pain and gave words to it, and possibly one of the greatest revelations was when I realized that the most hostile voices were the parts that needed the greatest compassion.

The International Hearing Voices Movement was founded by Professor Marius Romme and Dr. Sandra Escher. The movement locates voice hearing as a survival strategy, a sane reaction to insane circumstances, not as an aberrant symptom of schizophrenia to be endured. In the last 20 years the movement has established hearing voices networks in 26 countries across five continents.

Dan Cohen: Why do we try to convince other people to believe things they don't want to believe, and is that even a nice thing to do? Cohen: There are three models for arguments. The first model -- let's call it the dialectical model -- is we think of arguments as war; you know what that's like. Cohen: Think of a mathematician's argument.

Philosopher Philippe Cousteau: Argument as war is the dominant model of argument. But arguments are also performances in front of juries, he says. "I like to think that I'm actually pretty good at arguing," he says of his debating skills.

The war metaphor has, I think, deforming effects on how we argue. It elevates tactics over substance. It magnifies the us-versus-them aspect of it. And finally -- this is really the worst thing -- arguments don't seem to get us anywhere.

If argument is war, then there's an implicit equation of learning with losing, he says. "I've gotten better at arguing. I have a new belief. And it's not just any belief; it's well-articulated, examined"

The argument-as-war metaphor is just ... it's a monster. It's just taken up habitation in our mind, and there's no magic bullet that's going to kill it. What we need is new exit strategies for arguments. We need to think of new kinds of arguments.

CNN's John Sutter talks about how to think of new kinds of arguments. Sutter: Can you imagine an argument in which you are the arguer, but you're also in the audience, watching yourself argue? He says if you can, you have imagined a good argument.

Jinsop created a five-senses graph to show how different experiences affect the five senses. The scale is from zero to 10, with sound, touch, smell and taste at the top. Jinsop: "Anytime I had a memorable experience in my life, I would record it on this graph"

In the years that I gathered data, only one experience came close to being the perfect one. That is, of course, sex. Respondents said that great sex hits all of the five senses at an extreme level. Not even as intense an experience as riding a motorbike comes close.

The five senses theory is a useful tool in evaluating different experiences in my life. I realize the five senses isn't the only thing that makes life interesting. There's also the six emotions and that elusive x-factor. Maybe that could be the topic of my next talk. Until then, please have fun using theFive senses in your own lives.

The Akan of people of Ghana and Cote d'Ivoire developed Adinkra symbols 400 years ago. In the rainforests of the Democratic Republic of Congo, the men pound out a cloth out of a special tree. In South Africa, Ndebele women use these symbols and other geometric patterns to paint their homes.

African designers struggle with all forms of design because they are more apt to look outward for influence and inspiration. King Ibrahim Njoya of the Bamum Kingdom of Cameroon developed Shü-mom at the age of 25. The Vai people of Liberia had a long tradition of literacy before first contact with Europeans in the 1800s.

Derek Ockelford is the founder and director of design school in Ghana. He says Africa has had a long tradition of writing, but this is not such a well-known fact. The school offers a two-year diploma to talented students who have successfully completed their high school education.

Derek Paravicini taught himself to play the piano when he was four years old. His father, Nic, tried to teach him, but he was always pushing him out of the way. After a few months, Derek realized that all the sounds you hear in the world out there is something that you can copy on the keyboard.

CNN's John Defterios meets the young pianist who has taken the world by storm. The pair have been playing together since the age of two. Defterius: "I think we're going to have a lot of fun with this"

By the age of 11, Derek was playing things like "Flight of the Bumblebee" in the usual key. The ability to hear every note, and instantly, through all those hours and hours of practice, reproduce those on the keyboard, is the basis of all your ability.

Derek's memory is truly amazing, and every concert we do, we ask the audience to participate, by suggesting a piece Derek might like to play. And sure enough, she sang, or as Derek called it, warbled, to him for his first few years of life.

In America, they've coined this term, "the human iPod" for Derek. Derek, you're so much more than an iPod, says David Bowie. Derek's nanny dragged this little keyboard out of the loft, never thinking really that anything much would come of it.

I am the only architect in the world making buildings out of paper like this cardboard tube, and this exhibition is the first one I did using paper tubes. We stayed there for six years without paying any rent. Then I completed the Pompidou Center in Metz. It's a very popular museum now, and I created a big monument for the government.

In 1994, there was a big disaster in Rwanda, Africa. Over two million people became refugees. They're so poor, and they are freezing with blankets during the rainy season. In the shelters built by the U.N., they were just providing a plastic sheet, and the refugees had to cut the trees.

The church was built out of beer crates. It was meant to stay there for three years, but actually it stayed there 10 years because people loved it. Then, in Taiwan, they had a big earthquake, and we proposed to donate this church, so we dismantled them.

In 1999, in Turkey, the big earthquake, I went there to use the local material to build a shelter. In 2004, in Sri Lanka, after the Sumatra earthquake and tsunami, I rebuilt Islamic fishermen's villages. And in 2008, in Chengdu, Sichuan area in China, nearly 70,000 people were killed because of the corruption.

In 1990, Mr. Berlusconi brought G8 summit, and our former prime minister came, so they helped us to collect money. I got half a million euros from the Japanese government to rebuild this temporary auditorium. In 2010 in Haiti, there was a big earthquake, but it's impossible to fly over. So I went to Santo Domingo, next-door country, to build 50 units of shelter out of local paper tubes.

The building is made out of paper tubes. It was designed to look like a cathedral. The idea was to make it look like the inside of a church. It's a very small building, but it's very important to the community.

Sleep disruption in severe mental illness has been largely ignored. New research shows that mental illness and sleep are physically linked within the brain. Sleep disruption in depression, schizophrenia and bipolar is also being studied. The results of a recent study on schizophrenia were quite extraordinary.

Sleep is the golden chain that ties health and our bodies together. The neural networks that predispose you to normal sleep and give you normal sleep are overlapping. We're beginning to understand how both sleep and mental illness are generated and regulated within the brain. We can think of the sleep centers in the brain as a new therapeutic target.

Sleep is important for your concentration, attention, decision-making, creativity, social skills, health. If you get sleep, it reduces your mood changes, your stress, your impulsivity, and your tendency to drink and take drugs. An understanding of the neuroscience of sleep is really informing the way we think about some of the causes of mental illness.

Sleep is an incredibly important part of our biology, and neuroscientists are beginning to explain why it's so very important. We use Thomas Edison's light bulb to invade the night, and we occupied the dark, and in the process of this occupation, we've treated sleep as an illness, almost.

Some areas of the brain are actually more active during the sleep state than during the wake state. Sleep arises from a whole raft of different interactions within the brain. The biological clock tells us when it's good to be up and when it is good to sleep.

Aristotle suggested that we restore, replace, and rebuild during the night. The energy saving of sleeping is about 110 calories a night, he says. Sleep and memory consolidation is also very important, he adds. But sleep-deprive individuals, the ability to learn that task is smashed.

If you live to 90, 36 percent of your life will have been spent asleep. A night of sleep is estimated to give us a three-fold advantage. Sleep is not an indulgence. It's not even an upgrade from economy to first class.

The body clock is locked onto the same light-dark cycle as the rest of us. The quality of sleep that you get as a night shift worker is usually very poor. It's been estimated that 31 percent of drivers will fall asleep at the wheel at least once in their life.

When you're tired and you lack sleep, you have poor memory, poor creativity, increased impulsiveness, and overall poor judgment. If you are a tired brain, the brain is craving things to wake it up. Caffeine represents the stimulant of choice across the Western world.

Sleep loss seems to give rise to the release of the hormone ghrelin, the hunger hormone. The brain says, "I need carbohydrates," and what it does is seek out carbohydrates and particularly sugars. There's a link between tiredness and the metabolic predisposition for weight gain.

Stress increases cardiovascular disease as a result of raising blood pressure. If you need an alarm clock to get you out of bed in the morning, if you are taking a long time to get up, or if you're grumpy, chances are you are sleep-deprived.

Light exposure in the morning is very good at setting the biological clock to the light-dark cycle. Turn off all of those things that are also going to excite the brain. Try not to drink caffeine too late in the day, ideally not after lunch.

Early to bed, early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise, Descartes said. But there is no evidence that getting up early and going to bed early gives you more wealth at all, he said. 'Listen to your body. Do you need that much or do you need more?'

"I fell in love with mathematics from the earliest of ages. Maths is beautiful. It's natural. It is written in the mathematical language," Descartes said. Numbers are the musical notes with which the symphony of the universe is written, he says.

One is not prime. Seven is prime because it's 1 x 7, but we can't break it down into any smaller chunks, or as we call them, factors. When I say 2 ^ 5, I'm talking about five little number twos next to each other all multiplied together.

The vast bulk of massive primes we've ever found are of that form: two to a prime number, take away one. A random odd number is a lot harder to test. The world's biggest prime: (2 ^ 31) - 1. It's over two billion.

In 1876, a mathematician called Lucas proved that (2 ^ 127) - 1 is a prime number. But he didn't know what the factors were. 40 years later, Frank Nelson Cole calculated 67 powers of two. He took away one and wrote that number on the board.

Frank Nelson Cole delivers the only talk in the history of mathematics with no words. It took him, by his estimate, "three years of Sundays" to find the prime factors of (2 ^ 67) - 1. The room went berserk when he wrote down these two large prime numbers.

Curtis Cooper held the record for the largest ever prime, only to see it snatched away by a rival university. Currently the largest prime number we know, is 2 ^ 57,885,161. If you typed it out on a computer and saved it as a text file, that's 22 meg.

If written out as a book, this number would run the length of the Harry Potter novels and half again. Large prime numbers are a great way of testing the speed and accuracy of computer chips. The discovery of that prime is similar to the work people are doing in unraveling RNA sequences.

The CubeStormer II can take a randomly shuffled Rubik's Cube and solve it in five seconds. It's a metaphor for the time in which we live, when human minds and machines can conquer together. It is true, you can now download onto your smartphone an app that would beat most grandmasters at chess.

Lebanese TV presenter and author Yannick Bourdain organized a marathon to raise money for charity. Bourdain: "I needed something to take me out of my pain, an objective to look forward to" Bourdain was inspired by the discovery of the Higgs boson, a particle that gives all particles their mass.

"When you walk the talk, people believe you," says Lina Khatib. "It was honesty and transparency that brought us together," she says. "For every disaster we had, the marathon found ways to bring people together"

The United We Run is a five-kilometer race in Lebanon. It was started in 2005 after the assassination of the country's prime minister. The event has become a platform for peace and unity in the country. It has been attended by over 33,000 people from 85 countries.

The first annual all-women-and-girls race for empowerment has just taken place. Themes have included runs for the environment, breast cancer, for the love of Lebanon, or just simply to run. The event has become such a respected event in the region that government officials have asked the organization to help them structure a similar event.

Researchers claim to be able to activate a memory in the brain at the speed of light. They label a memory, and then activate it with a switch. XL: This is way more difficult than, let's say, finding a needle in a haystack.

The hippocampus is a brain region implicated in processing memories that we hold near and dear. Scientists attached a switch to the cells of the hippocampus to control its activity. The switch was then injected into the brain of mice to activate a memory. The hippocampus is an ideal target to try and find and maybe reactivate a memory, the researchers say.

Scientists are trying to use light to activate or inactivate brain cells. Light travels at the speed of light, so brain cells would have to respond to a light-sensitive switch. The technique that lets them do that is optogenetics.

Optogenetics gave us this light switch that we can use to turn brain cells on or off. The name of that switch is channelrhodopsin, seen here as these green dots attached to this brain cell. The memory of that person and the awful, emotional undertones that color in that memory, are largely mediated by separate brain systems.

Xu: We were looking at this mouse here trying to activate a memory for the first time using our technique. The moment we turned on the laser, like you see now, all of a sudden the mouse entered this freezing mode.XL: While watching this, Steve and I are as shocked as the mouse itself.

Researchers in the U.S. have created a way to control memory using a video clip. They can play back the clip and alter the contents of the memory at any time. The research is called Project Inception and was published in the journal Nature. The researchers are still working with mice, but the results are encouraging.

Lasers can reactivate a memory using lasers just like they did before. If we present new information and allow this new information to incorporate into this old memory, this will change the memory. XL: These ideas probably remind you of "Total Recall," "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," or of "Inception"

Xu Liu: We're living in a time where it's possible to pluck questions from the tree of science fiction and to ground them in experimental reality. XL: One group in our lab was able to find the brain cells that make up a fear memory and converted them into a pleasurable memory.

People who experienced a lot of stress in the previous year had a 43 percent increased risk of dying. But that was only true for the people who also believed that stress is harmful for your health. Researchers estimated that 182,000 Americans died prematurely, not from stress, but from the belief that Stress is bad for you.

The experimenter has been trained to harass you during the test. The evaluators are trained to give you discouraging, non-verbal feedback. The experimenter is also trained to make you do the test backwards from 996 in increments of seven. The test is designed to test your ability to count backwards.

Harvard University study looked at how people's stress response changed when they viewed it as helpful. Participants who viewed their stress response as helpful were less stressed out, less anxious, more confident. In a typical stress response, your heart rate goes up, and your blood vessels constrict like this.

Stress makes you social, which is good for your health. The hormone oxytocin is involved in the social aspect of stress. It's a neuro-hormone and is released when you hug someone. It can also cause stress-induced heart attacks.

Oxytocin makes you crave physical contact with your friends and family. It fine-tunes your brain's social instincts. It even makes you more willing to help and support the people you care about. Some people have even suggested we should snort oxytocin to become more compassionate.

The body releases the hormone oxytocin when it is under stress. The hormone helps the heart and other parts of the body recover from stress. It also increases the body's ability to fight off infections and other illnesses. It is thought to have a protective effect on the cardiovascular system.

Researchers found that caring for others did not increase the risk of dying. Caring for others can help you cope with stress, says Dr. Chris Anderson. "Stress gives us access to our hearts," he says. "When you choose to view your stress response as helpful, you create the biology of courage"

CNN's John Defterios talks to Kelly Wallace about her new book, "Rewilding" The book is based on a study of 30,000 adults in the U.S. who were asked how much stress they'd experienced in the last year. Wallace: "Go after what it is that creates meaning in your life and then trust yourself"

Wolves were reintroduced to Yellowstone National Park in 1995. The number of songbirds, of migratory birds, started to increase greatly. The deer started avoiding certain parts of the park, the places where they could be trapped most easily. The height of the trees quintupled in just six years.

Wolves have changed the landscape of Yellowstone National Park. The number of beavers in the area has also increased. The effect has been seen in the riverbeds, which have become more stable. The park is now home to more than 100 species of wildlife.

CNN's John Defterios looks at the role of whales in changing the environment. He says they are responsible for sequestering tens of millions of tons of carbon from the atmosphere. Defterio: "They make, in my view, a powerful case for the reintroduction of missing species"

Rewilding is the rewilding of human life, says the author. It is not an alternative to civilization, he says. We can enjoy the benefits of advanced technology, but have access to a richer and wilder life of adventure when we want.

Why are some trees able to withstand the force of the wind, while others can't? The answer may be that they are more resistant to wind than other trees. The answer could be found in the roots of some of the world's oldest trees, such as the oak.

CNN's John Sutter talks to the family of a man who died in a plane crash. He says the man's story shows that change doesn't always happen in one direction. Sutter: "An ounce of hope is worth a ton of despair"

Local Projects is a media design firm that works with museums and public spaces. Their latest engagement is the Cleveland Museum of Art, which they've created an engagement called Gallery One for. The entire project is predicated on this act of love which is listening itself, says Jake Barton.

An algorithm allows you to browse the actual museum's collection using facial recognition. You can actually see all 3,000 artworks all at the same time, and you can actually author your own individual walking tours of the museum. The 9/11 Memorial and Museum will open next year.

CNN's John Sutter is the founder of StoryCorps, a storytelling platform. Sutter: "We can't have just a historian or a curator narrating in the third person about an event like that" "We need people who are going to make their way through the actual museum itself"

JB: "We tell the stories of being inside the towers through that same audio collage" "We project directly onto these moments of twisted steel all of the experiences from people who literally excavated on top of the pile itself" "You can hear oral histories -- so people who were actually working the so-called bucket brigades as you're seeing literally the thousands of experiences"

The 9/11 Memorial Museum in New York is celebrating its 10th anniversary this year. The museum has created an oral history archive of the day's events. The oral histories are mixed with interviews with people like Donald Rumsfeld, Bill Clinton and Rudy Giuliani.

The memorial is organized into blocks of color with names scrambled for privacy. You can see the way that the geography of the event is reflected inside of the memorial. And you can search for an individual name, or in this case an employer, on the memorial itself.

When he was five, I went to school and I learned braille. When I was in high school, I got my first Philips reel-to-reel tape recorder. I could have family and friends read me material, and I could then read it back as many times as I needed.

Lois Doery, who has been a friend of the family for more than 30 years, died on Monday. Doery helped her son, Gerard, learn to read and write with a tape recorder in his room at Monash University in Melbourne, Australia.

In 1974, Ray Kurzweil developed a machine that could read books. He died in a plane crash in 2005, but his work lives on in the machine. The machine is now being used to read books for the first time.
Roxanne Jones is a journalist and author. She is best known for her book, "The Secret Life of the American Mind" She has been blind since the age of three. Jones: "I can't wait to get back to work"

phthalmologist says technology that fascinated him in 1987 is now on his iPhone and on yours as well. "I find reading with machines a very lonely process," he says. The condition is known as retrolental fibroplasia, and it's now very rare in the developed world.

There are hundreds of thousands of accessible books in the United States, Britain, Canada, Australia, etc., but they can't be transported to the 60 countries in our world where English is the first and second language. A group of countries and the World Blind Union are advocating, a cross-border treaty.

The author of this article is a Jain who has lived in the U.S. for more than 20 years. She says she has been inspired by the work of the Jain community. The author also believes that the Jains have a special relationship with the earth.

The malaria parasite transforms itself like that seven times in its life cycle. It can hide in our bodies, undetected, unbeknownst to us, for days, for weeks, for months, for years, in some cases even decades. Only about 12 species of mosquitos carry most of the world's malaria.

Malaria occurs in some of the poorest and most remote places on Earth. If you're poor, you're more likely to live in rudimentary housing on marginal land that's poorly drained. You're less likely to have door screens or window screens, so you're getting bitten by mosquitos more.

Malaria poses a huge economic challenge, says Dr. David Perry. The people who have the most malaria in the world tend to care about it the least, he says. "Malaria is a normal problem of life," says Perry. "Why would you write about something so boring, so ordinary?"

Most of the world's malaria comes and goes on its own. A child in Malawi, for example, might have 12 episodes of malaria before the age of two. That's when Jesuit missionaries in Peru discovered the bark of the cinchona tree. Inside that bark was quinine, still an effective cure for malaria to this day.

The first concerted attack against malaria started in the 1950s. It was the brainchild of the U.S. State Department. They knew they had to focus on cheap, easy-to-use tools. But when those tools started to fail, and public opinion started to turn against those tools.

CNN's John Defterios says the fight against malaria is a big challenge. He says the best way to fight the disease is to make it easier for people to get it. Defterio: We need to make sure people don't have to get up in the middle of the night to get a mosquito net.

Only 20 percent of the bed nets that were first distributed were actually used. The same people who distributed the nets went back and asked the recipients, "Oh, did you use that net I gave you?" That's exactly what we did in the 1950s, and that effort backfired.

Malaria is unconquerable, but what if we attacked this disease according to the priorities of the people who lived with it? This is a question that's personally intrigued me for a long time. I grew up as the daughter of Indian immigrants visiting my cousins in India every summer. I was made to sleep under this hot, sweaty mosquito net every night.

James Lyne shows some of the cybercriminals' latest and nastiest creations. He shows how you can go online and buy a hacking service to knock your business competitor offline. James Lyne: If you want your business competitors to go down, well, they can.

Cybercriminals now have crime packs with business intelligence reporting dashboards to manage the distribution of their malicious code. For a small fee, they can upload it and make sure everything is good. You can email the cybercriminals and they'll tell you how to set up your illegal hacking server.

Malware is very boring otherwise. We can access your documents, your data. You can turn on the webcam. That can be very embarrassing. Or just to really prove a point, we can launch programs like my personal favorite, the Windows Calculator.

Computer viruses and trojans are designed to do everything from stealing data to watching you in your webcam to the theft of billions of dollars. Let's imagine that our attacker, called Evil Hacker just for comedy value, inserts something a little nasty. The browser crashes as it hits one of these exploit packs, and up pops fake antivirus.

A group of hackers we tracked for a year and actually found -- and this is a rare treat in our job. People now pay cybercriminals money to run viruses, which I find utterly bizarre. Chasing 250,000 pieces of malware a day is a massive challenge, and those numbers are only growing in proportion to my stress line.

Every second, eight new users are joining the Internet. Today, we will see 250,000 individual new computer viruses. Using the email address, the telephone number and the GPS data, on the left you see an advert for a BMW that one of our cybercriminals is selling.

Cybercriminals have locked down their profiles quite well. Our friends, our families and our colleagues can break our security even when we do the right things. We will see 30,000 new infected websites. By the end of the investigation, we had photos of the cybercriminals.

"This is how geeks party. This isn't an exact science, but it gets pretty accurate. Twenty-three percent of you have been to Starbucks recently and used the wireless network. Forty-six per cent of you I could link to a business, XYZ Employee network. Two hundred and thirty-four of you, well, I know where you live.

Technology is changing at a staggering rate, and that 250,000 pieces of malware won't stay the same for long. The cybercriminals I talked about, despite theft of millions of dollars, actually still haven't been arrested, and at this point possibly never will.

CNN's Richard Quest says attention is the gateway to the mind. Quest: "If you don't attend to something, you can't be aware of it" Quest: Some people have fancy models of attention, Posner's trinity model of attention.

"I have to play with your attention as a limited resource" "I could talk for a long time, tell you lots of things, and a portion of them may be true, but I think it's better if I tried to show that to you here live" "If I come down, I'm going to do a bit of shopping. Just hold still where you are"

phthalmologist has spent the last 20 years studying human behavior from a rather unorthodox way: picking pockets. For me, that would be the perfect superpower, actually kind of an evil way of approaching it. "You're like a buffet. Hard to tell where to start, so many great things," he says.

Poker player asks audience member to hold out his hand for him to feel a poker chip. He says: "I'll cheat if you give me a chance. Make it harder for me. Just use your hand. Thank you very much. I appreciate that"

Arnold: "The things right in front of us are often the hardest to see, the things that you look at every day that you're blinded to" "We're going to keep doing this till you catch it. I have faith in you. Squeeze firm. You're human, you're not slow. You'll get it eventually"
J: Do you remember what it was? J: Money. AR: Check your pocket. J: Is it still there? AR: Oh, there it was. Put it away. We're just shopping. I'm going to try to push it inside your hand.
phthalmologist: "I have no idea how that works. If I do it slowly it goes straight away, it lands by your pocket" J: "We have a couple of other things, a little bit of cash. I'm saving it for later"

phthalmologist: Attention is a powerful thing. How many of you still have your cell phones on you right now?phthalmologists: Can you remember the icon in the bottom right corner?phthalmic: Bring them out, check and see how accurate you were.

Bumblebees are one of the few kinds of bees in the world that are able to hold onto the flower and vibrate it. They do this by shaking their flight muscles at a frequency similar to the musical note C. Humans have been drawn to honeybees since early recorded history, mostly to harvest their honey.

More than one third of the world's crop production is dependent on bee pollination. Honeybees can be considered a super-organism, where the colony is the organism and it's comprised of 40,000 to 50,000 individual bee organisms.

Bees have been in decline in the United States since World War II. They are dying from multiple and interacting causes, says John Sutter. Sutter: "Bees are not out there pollinating our food intentionally. They're out there because they need to eat"

After World War II, we started using herbicides to kill off the weeds in our gardens. Many of these weeds are flowering plants that bees require for their survival. We stopped planting clover and alfalfa, which are natural fertilizers that fix nitrogen in the soil.

The neonicontinoids are a new class of insecticides. They move through the plant so that a crop pest, a leaf-eating insect, would get a lethal dose and die. In parts of the world where there are no bees, people are paid to do the business of pollination by hand.

All of our beautiful wild species of bees are at risk, including those tomato-pollinating bumblebees. Plant bee-friendly flowers, and don't contaminate these flowers, this bee food, with pesticides. Plant them in your front yard, in your lawns.

Maria Spivak: We need to plant flowering crop borders and hedge rows to disrupt the agricultural food desert. She says when bees have access to good nutrition, they're better able to engage their own natural defenses. "Let the small act of planting flowers and keeping them free of pesticides be the driver of large-scale change," she says.

The TED Talk graph shows the global impact of TED Talk ideas. The top 25 percent of TED Talks have a global impact, from New York to New Zealand. The graph is based on the idea of a "meme-ome" - a collection of ideas that are connected.

Every node is a talk, they're linked if they share similar ideas. The structure starts to emerge where we see a kind of fractal behavior of the words and the language that we use to describe the things that are important to us all around this world.

EB: You cannot get this kind of perspective from a simple tag search on YouTube. EB: How do we bubble stuff up to the surface that's maybe really creative and interesting? EB: Well, we can go back to the network structure of ideas to do that.

Sean Gourley: We took 24,000 TEDx Talks from around the world, 147 different countries. We wanted to find the mathematical structures that underly the ideas behind them. We're using these network motifs to find talks that are unique and creatively synthesizing a lot of different fields.

We've got ourselves in a world that's massively complex, and we've been using algorithms to kind of filter it down so we can navigate through it. And we wanted to do that so we could see how they connected with each other. And so, of course, if you're going to do this kind of stuff, you need a lot of data. So the data that you've got is a great thing called YouTube.

Growing leather is technically simpler than growing other animal products like meat. Growing leather is a gateway material, a beginning for the mainstream biofabrication industry. If we can succeed here, it brings our other consumer bioproducts like meat closer on the horizon.

This is real, genuine leather, without the sacrifice. It can be grown in the shape of a wallet, a handbag or a car seat. Because we make this material, we can control its properties in very interesting ways. This piece of leather is a mere seven tissue layers thick.

The future of animal products could be much more like this. We can mimic nature, but in some ways also improve upon it. We have been manufacturing with cell cultures for thousands of years. Perhaps biofabrication is a natural evolution of manufacturing for mankind.

TED speaker: We need to move past just killing animals as a resource to something more civilized and evolved. Animals are not just raw materials. They're living beings, and already our livestock is one of the largest users of land, fresh water and greenhouse gases. We can create a global parliament of mayors.

Democracy is in trouble, no question about that, and it comes in part from a deep dilemma in which it is embedded. Cities are not only the oldest of institutions, they're the most enduring. They are the places where we are born, grow up, are educated, work, marry, pray, play, and in time, die.

More than three out of four people live in urban institutions, urban places, in cities today. There are scores of international, inter-city, cross-border institutions in which cities are already working together to deal with climate change. Mayors are pragmatists, they're problem-solvers.

Mayor Nutter of Philadelphia said, we could never get away here in Philadelphia with the stuff that goes on in Washington. Their job is to get things done, and if they don't, they're out of a job. There isn't a left or a right way of doing.

Mayors are pragmatists and problem-solvers. They get things done. They are also what I like to call homeboys, or to include the women mayors, homies. They're part of the neighborhood. It's pretty hard to be a carpetbagger and be a mayor.

China and the U.S. are locked in all kinds of anger, resentment, and rivalry for number one. That's the difference, and the difference has to do with the character of cities themselves. Cities are profoundly multicultural, open, participatory, democratic, able to work with one another.

The road to global democracy doesn't run through states. It runs through cities. Cities are doing this, but not just one by one. They are sharing what they do, and they are making a difference by shared best practices. Unless we find a way to globalize democracy or democratize globalization, we will increasingly risk the failure to address transnational problems.

I believe it can be reborn in the global cosmopolis. We can create not a League of Nations, which failed. Not a United or a dis-United Nations, but United Cities of the World. I'd like to tell you about a legal case that I worked on.

Steve Titus was consumed with his civil case. He died of a stress-related heart attack days before he was to have his day in court. Titus is not the only person to be convicted based on somebody's false memory. In one project in the United States, information has been gathered on 300 innocent people.

Many people believe that memory works like a recording device. But decades of work in psychology has shown that this just isn't true. Our memories are constructive. They're reconstructive. You can go in there and change it, but so can other people.

CNN's John Sutter looks at how memories can be distorted. He says some people's memories of events in their lives can be altered. Sutter: "It's not unusual for people to have a memory of something they've never seen before"

In one study, researchers planted a false memory that when you were a kid, you nearly drowned and had to be rescued by a life guard. And in a study done in Canada, they planted the false memory of being attacked by a vicious animal, succeeding with about half of their subjects.

Scientists are being sued for simply speaking out on matters of great public controversy. The false memories aren't necessarily bad or unpleasant. Therapists can't ethically plant false memories in the mind of their patients. There's nothing to stop a parent from trying this out on their overweight or obese teenager.

DNA testing can reveal false memories, says Dr. Richard Branson. Branson: "What we need is a test that says, "What is x?" "Geneticists always say, you always get what you screen for," Branson says. "I know from my work how much fiction is already in there"

In Tana Toraja, the most important social moments in people's lives are not weddings or births, but funerals. Last year, on the Fourth of July, experiments at the Large Hadron Collider discovered the Higgs boson. The LHC has conclusively proved that this substance is real, because it is the stuff the Higgs bosons are made of. According to the laws of quantum mechanics, it is possible to have transitions between two states, even in the presence of an energy barrier separating the two states. Besides the known Higgs state, there could be a second state.

The intensity of the Higgs field is critical for the structure of matter. A bubble of the ultra-dense Higgs state could come into existence because of quantum tunneling. The bubble would then expand at the speed of light, invading all space. If space-time were filled by this HiggsState, all atomic matter would collapse.

The Higgs field is in a wobbly configuration that will eventually collapse. It is not likely to happen for at least the next 10 to the 100 years. The Higgs boson does not share the beauty, the symmetry, of the rest of the elementary particles.

Higgs boson mass could be around the critical value, near to a cosmic collapse of the Higgs field. This may be a hint that our universe is only a grain of sand in a giant beach, the multiverse. We think that this these "why" questions can give us clues about the fundamental principles of nature.

The social impact bond is a new business model for social change. The idea is to raise money from socially motivated investors. They pay for a set of services, and if those services are successful, then they improve outcomes. With those measured reductions in re-offending, government saves money.

Investors get a return of up to 13 percent on their investment. The government gets a return on its investment of £2.5 million. The money will be used to improve the quality of care given to children in care homes. It will also help to reduce the number of people in care who need to be re-sentenced.

There are now 13 social impact bonds in Britain, and amazing levels of interest in this idea all over the world. David Cameron's put 20 million pounds into a social outcomes fund to support this idea. Obama has suggested 300 million dollars in the U.S. budget for these kinds of ideas and structures.

We need human cells, but we need to find a way to keep them happy outside the body. We call it an organ-on-a-chip. Right here in my hand is a breathing, living human lung on a chip. And it's not just beautiful.

The chip is the smallest functional unit that represents the biochemistry, the function and the mechanical strain that the cells experience in our bodies. We use techniques from the computer chip manufacturing industry to make these structures at a scale relevant to both the cells and their environment. We could mimic infection, where we add bacterial cells into the lung.

Cells from the small airways in our lungs have these hairlike structures. These structures are called cilia, and they actually move the mucus out of the lung. Cilia and the clearance of mucus are also involved in awful diseases like cystic fibrosis.

Human cells in a gut on a chip can mimic many of the functions of the human intestine. The technology can also be used to create models of diseases such as irritable bowel syndrome. The goal is to be able to recreate sufficient functionality so that we can make better predictions of what's going to happen in humans.

Skin on a chip could test the safety of chemicals that we are exposed to on a daily basis in our environment. It could also use the organs on chips for applications in bioterrorism or radiation exposure. Organs on chips could also change the way we do clinical trials.

The Wyss Institute is developing an instrument that can link 10 or more organ chips together. The instrument creates an easy user interface, allowing researchers to take a chip and put it in a cartridge. The Wyss institute is also establishing important industry collaborations.

Francis is an architect from Burkina Faso. He wanted to open up better opportunities to other kids in his village. He raised 50,000 U.S. dollars to build a school. His people were shocked when they found out he was using clay.

The walls are totally made out of compressed clay blocks from Gando. The roof structure is made with cheap steel bars normally hiding inside concrete. The ceiling is made of both of them used together. The school is 12 years old, still in best condition.

The school extension in Gando was a huge success. The kids are happy, and they love it. The community is very proud. Even animals, like these donkeys, love our buildings. It has opened up opportunities to do more projects.

The name of the glacier these caves are formed in is the Sandy Glacier. As new snow lands on the glacier, it melts in the summer sun, and it forms little rivers of water on the flow along the ice. They start to melt and bore their way down through the glaciers, forming big networks of caves.

The cave is formed inside a block of ice the size of a small city that's slowly sliding down the mountain. Warm water from the top of the ice is boring its way down. Warm air from below the mountain actually rises up, gets into the cave, and melts the ceilings back.

When I was a child, I was told that when I died, I too would go up into the sky. I was scared, but it sounded better than being swallowed by the void. We all live in the shadow of a personal apocalypse, and that's frightening.

Psychologists call a bias a way in which we systematically get things wrong. Confront someone with the fact that they are going to die and they will believe just about any story that tells them it isn't true and they can, instead, live forever. It has been demonstrated in over 400 empirical studies.

Terror management theory: Reminding people of death biases them to believe, regardless of the evidence. Almost every culture in human history has had some myth or legend of an elixir of life or a fountain of youth. immortality stories have thousands of different manifestations, but there are just four basic forms that these immortality stories can take.

The idea that we can all be resurrected to live again is orthodox believe. The majority of people on Earth believe they have a soul, and the idea is central to many religions. The idea of cryonics is the idea that when you die, you can have yourself frozen.

By 2010, Detroit had become the poster child for an American city in crisis. Many people were beginning to write it off, as it had topped the list of American shrinking cities. Between 1950 and 2000, the region grows by 30 percent. But the migration leaves African-Americans in place.

Detroit is 139 square miles. Citywide, there are about 100,000 vacant parcels. Former models can move to Detroit, buy property, start successful businesses and restaurants. Some are banding together to take control of some of the vacant lots and start community gardens.

Detroit is under the control of an emergency manager, and just this July filed for Chapter 9 bankruptcy. The city itself wasn't necessarily too large, but the economy was too small. There are only 27 jobs per 100 people in Detroit, very different from a Denver or an Atlanta.

The industrial Internet is a world where machines are self-aware, predictive, reactive and social. Industrial machines are being equipped with a growing number of electronic sensors. Increasingly sophisticated analytics then sift through the data, providing insights that allow us to operate the machines in entirely new ways.

The Industrial Revolution brought us machines and factories, railways, electricity, air travel, and our lives have never been the same. Today, 10 percent of all flights cancellations and delays are due to unscheduled maintenance events. This results in eight billion dollars in costs for the airline industry globally every year.

New technology is reducing the time it takes to care for patients, says Dr. Andrew Weisman. He says it is also reducing the cost of health care. Weisman: By 2020, the Internet will account for over 50 percent of all digital information.

Industrial Internet will make life easier for workers of all skill levels. The worker of the future will be more like Iron Man than the Charlie Chaplin of "Modern Times" The new wave of innovation is fundamentally changing the way we work.

The industrial Internet could raise average income by 25 to 40 percent over the next 15 years, boosting growth to rates we haven't seen in a long time. In the U.S. alone, the Internet could add between 10 and 15 trillion dollars to global GDP.

Technology is beginning to transform industrial sectors that play a huge role in our economy and in our lives. We are just at the beginning of this transformation, and there will be barriers to break, obstacles to overcome. We will need a robust cybersecurity approach that protects sensitive information and intellectual property from cyberattacks.

There are over three million amputees every year who need a new or replacement knee. The Jaipur Foot Organization was looking for a better knee. D-Rev has developed a knee that acts like a human knee, mimics human gait, for 80 dollars retail. The key is to get this great invention to the people who most need it. D-Rev looked at three things that we really believe get technologies to customers, to users.

D-Rev's Jaipur Knee has the greatest range of motion of almost any other knee on the market. The knee is designed to be user-centric, not just for the end user, but also for the prosthetist who fits it.

The game of Monopoly is a game of power. The winner is the person with the most money at the end of the game. In this game, the winning player has more money than the losing player. The winning player also has more power over the other player.

The game of Monopoly can be used as a metaphor for understanding society and its hierarchical structure, says Paul Piff. Piff: As a person's levels of wealth increase, their feelings of compassion and empathy go down. "Their feelings of entitlement, of deservingness, and their ideology of self-interest increase"

Psychologists have found that wealthier people are more likely to moralize greed being good. The project is a joint project between the EPFL and the University of Venice Ca'Foscari. There's a lot of material available -- newspaper, printed books, thousands of printed books. The more you go in the past, the less information you will have.

At the Archivio di Stato, you have 80 kilometers of archives documenting every aspect of the life of Venice over more than 1,000 years. We are setting up a 10-year digitization program which has the objective of transforming this immense archive into a giant information system.

The information system can be searched in many ways. You can ask questions like, "Who lived in this palazzo in 1323?" How much cost a sea bream at the Realto market in 1434? What was the salary of a glass maker in Murano maybe over a decade?

The project aims to reconstruct a fully documented potential story of Venice's history. The challenge is qualifying, quantifying and representing uncertainty and inconsistency at each step of the process. The system should allow for that, because we have to deal with a new form of uncertainty, which is new for this type of giant databases.

The project is part of a larger effort to create a new generation of "digital humanists" in the humanities. The aim is to create an immersive system that allows people to dive and reconstruct the Venice of a given year. The project is currently being conducted in Geneva, Switzerland.

The National Science Foundation funded a project to create custom-crafted voices for people who had lost their voice later in life. The project is called VocaliD, or vocal I.D., for vocal identity. The voice is a combination of the source, which is the vibrations generated by your voice box, and the rest of the vocal tract.

Scientists have developed a way to combine the voice of a person with severe speech disorder to create a new type of voice.
