From Beijing to London, from California to India, from Brazil to Ethiopia, we do understand how to manage those two transformations, the structural and the climate. But, and it's a big but, the world as a whole is moving far too slowly. We're not cutting emissions in the way we should.

China is a sprawling urban area dependent on dirty fuel, particularly coal. We need leaders to step up. We can have better growth, better climate, a better world. If we make a mess of it, we, you and me, if we don't manage those transformations properly, it will be the worst of centuries.

Kenneth Cukier: Big data is important, and big data is new. The only way this planet is going to deal with its global challenges is because of the effective use of data, he says. In 1908, on the island of Crete, archaeologists discovered a clay disc. They dated it from 2000 B.C., so it's 4,000 years old.

Data has gone from a stock to a flow, from something stationary and static to something that is fluid and dynamic. The disc that was discovered off of Crete that's 4,000 years old, is heavy, it doesn't store a lot of information, and that information is unchangeable.

Researchers in Tokyo are using it as a potential anti-theft device in cars. The idea is that the car recognizes that a non-approved driver is behind the wheel. The car senses that the person slumps into that position and sets an internal alarm.

In the 1950s, a computer scientist at IBM liked to play checkers, so he wrote a computer program so he could play against the computer. He played. He won, because the computer only knew what a legal move was. But Arthur Samuel knew something else. He wrote a small sub-program alongside it operating in the background.

Machine learning is at the basis of many of the things that we do online. It will improve our lives, but there are problems that we need to be conscious of. The police may use big data for their purposes, a little bit like "Minority Report"

Big data and algorithms are going to challenge white collar, professional knowledge work in the 21st century. The Industrial Revolution wasn't very good if you were a horse. We are not very good at handling all the data that we can now collect. It's not just a problem for the National Security Agency.

Big data is going to transform how we live, how we work and how we think. It's a little bit like the challenge that was faced by primitive man and fire. Businesses collect lots of data, and they misuse it too, and we need to get better at this, and this will take time.
"I felt like I was in the middle of a war," says Palestinian photographer. "I was in a war zone and I was trying to get out of the war zone," she says. "It was like I had to fight my way out of it"

An EMT in New York told a man he was going to die and that there was nothing he could do for him. The man simply laid back and had a look of acceptance on his face. The patient simply laid there, and as I looked into his eyes, I saw inner peace and acceptance.

The dying need to know that their life had meaning, says Dr. John. "I wish I had spent more time with my children and grandchildren instead of being selfish with my time," he says. "There's a need for immortality within the hearts and thoughts of their loved ones, myself, my crew, or anyone around"
"I was afraid if I told them the truth, that they would die in fear," she says. "It's the littlest things that give you peace in those final moments," she adds. "Some of us won't make it."

There are 2.5 billion people in the world who don't have access to adequate sanitation. The United Nations estimates that every year, there are 1.5 million child deaths because of inadequate sanitation. To avoid open defecation, cities and cities build infrastructure, like pit latrines.

In schools, children defecate on the floors and then leave a trail outside the building and start defecating around the building. In some countries, like India, the lower castes are condemned to empty the pits, and they're further condemned by society. We have to rethink sanitation, and we've got to reinvent the sanitation infrastructure.

The idea is to create a system that can be used to collect waste. The waste can then be used in a variety of ways, such as as fertilizer. The idea is that the waste can be recycled and used for other purposes. The goal is to make the process easier for people.

CNN's Richard Quest says access to adequate sanitation is a basic human right. Quest: "We need to stop the practice of lower castes and lower-status people going down and being condemned to empty pits" "She deserves our support surely, because whether by subway, mule, or canoe, she is teaching us to walk the walk"

The Latin American Medical School opened in Havana, Cuba, in 1999. Students come from 83 countries in the Americas, Africa and Asia. They come from 100 ethnic groups, speak 50 different languages. More than half the students are young women.

Havana's Latin American Medical School is the largest medical school in the world. It has graduated 23,000 young doctors since its first class of 2005, with nearly 10,000 more in the pipeline. Doctors are concentrated in the cities, where only half the world's people live, not in shantytowns or South L.A.

The U.S. is the number one destination for medical students in the world. The students learn to work in teams, with a dose of humility. They also learn how to deal with the challenges of living in a poor country. They learn about the importance of community service, and how to help others.

Haitian medical students flew in from Cuba to help build health system in Haiti. ELAM's graduates are smart, strong and also dedicated. Dozens of new health centers have been built, staffed, in 35 cases, headed by ELAM graduates.

Haiti is one of the poorest countries in the world. Many of its doctors have left the country to work in the U.S. and other countries. They need to be able to return to their home countries and find work.

Women represent 50 percent of middle management and professional positions. But women at the top of organizations represent not even a third of that number. To move forward, we may have to find our way back to that pediatrician who would knock on my family's door on the South Side of Chicago.

Tonya Ehrlich: Why are there so many women mired in the middle and what has to happen to take them to the top? She says there's a notable absence of advice that relates to business, strategic and financial acumen. She says much of the advice is emphasizing personal actions that we need to take, like become more assertive.

Women make up 50 percent of the workforce in the U.S., but only 33 percent of senior positions. Expert: Traditional advice to women in 40 years hasn't closed the gender gap at the top. Women must show they understand their businesses, where they're headed, and their role in taking it there.

Only 37 percent of executives believe they have strategic alignment in place. For 63 percent of organizations, achieving their strategic financial goals is questionable. It's important for directors on boards to expect from their executives proportional pools of women. It is important for women and men to examine the mindsets we hold about careers and success.

The keyboardist has been playing music by George Frideric Handel for the past two years. He says he fell in love with the music and wanted to share it with as many people as possible. "It was an experience of being totally in awe of the music, and I had not felt that in a long time"

Daria van den Bercken plays music for children as young as seven years old. She says the children are always in a "state of wonder" about the music she plays. "They are in this constant state of wonder, and I do firmly believe that we can keep listening"

Every cell produces waste as a byproduct, and the clearance of that waste is the second basic problem that each organ has to solve. Galen proposed that while we're awake, our brain's motive force, its juice, would flow out to all the other parts of the body, animating them but leaving the brain all dried up.

The fluid and the waste from inside the brain don't just percolate their way randomly out to these pools of CSF. Instead, there is a specialized network of plumbing that organizes and facilitates this process. But our most surprising finding was that all of this, with all this fluid rushing through the brain, it's only happening in the sleeping brain. When the brain goes to sleep, the brain cells themselves seem to shrink, opening up spaces in between them.

New research shows that sleep clears amyloid-beta, a protein that's made in the brain all the time. In patients with Alzheimer's disease, the protein builds up and aggregates in the spaces between the brain's cells, instead of being cleared away. This buildup is thought to be one of the key steps in the development of the disease.

Sleep may be an elegant design solution to some of the brain's most basic needs, according to new research. "We're moving towards a new model of the state and society," says the author. "No taxation without representation," can now be updated to "No representation without a conversation," he adds.

David Frum: We need to talk about the future of democracy. He says it's not just a matter of voting once every couple of years. Frum says we need to find a way to build a democracy that works in the 21st century.

DemocracyOS is an open-source web application that is designed to become a bridge between citizens and their elected representatives. Users can get informed so every new project that gets introduced in Congress gets immediately translated and explained in plain language. And finally, you can vote how you would like your elected  representative to vote.

El Partido de la Red, or the Net Party, is a political party in Buenos Aires. The party was founded in August last year and ran for elections in October last year. It aims to change the way political parties make their decisions.

Argentina's Congress is launching for the first time in Argentina's history, a DemocracyOS. GG: Our political system can be transformed, and not by subverting it, but by rewiring it with the tools that Internet affords us now.

Glenn Greenwald: "I look at this as work that will never end until governments around the world are no longer able to subject entire populations to monitoring and surveillance" "To me, that's the way that privacy can be rejuvenated. That's the essence of journalism," he says.

LZ Granderson: People who say they don't care about their privacy are lying. He says they think they're doing nothing wrong and have no reason to be concerned. Granderson says people who are concerned about privacy should check their own accounts.

All of us have things that we don't want anyone else to know about. The reason is that when we're in a state where we can be monitored, our behavior changes. Human shame is a very powerful motivator, as is the desire to avoid it.

In "1984," Winston Smith describes the surveillance system that they faced. Smith: "You had to live, did live, from habit that became instinct, in the assumption that every sound you made was overheard" A society in which people can be monitored at all times is a society that breeds conformity and obedience and submission.

Voter turnout around the world peaked in the late '80s, and it has been declining at a pace that we have never seen before. In the last two years, two of the world's most consolidated, oldest democracies, the U.S. and France, held nationwide municipal elections.

Rio de Janeiro is one of the most unequal cities in the world. The Human Development Index of Leblon is higher than Norway, Switzerland or Sweden. Rio is a place where you can go from northern Europe to sub-Saharan Africa in 30 minutes.

The U.S. population has suffered from a general decrease in happiness for the past three decades. The American way of building cities has caused good quality public spaces to virtually disappear in many, many American cities. We need a participation revolution, and we need it fast.

Rio de Janeiro Mayor Eduardo Campos is the founder of Meu Rio. He says the city needs to do a better job of engaging its citizens. Campos: "We don't need to wait for governments to do this work for us"

Rio de Janeiro has no centralized intelligence system for solving missing persons cases. The Our Cities network hopes to share what we have learned with other people who want to create similar initiatives in their own cities. We have already started doing it in São Paulo with incredible results, and want to take it to cities around the world.

Handwashing with soap is one of the most cost-effective ways of saving children's lives. It can save over 600,000 children every year. Four out of five people don't wash their hands when they come out of the toilet.

In 90 percent of households in India, you will find soap. Even in countries where soap is the lowest, like Ethiopia, we are at 50 percent. Children pick up disease in the place that's supposed to love them and protect them.

Every second in Asia and Africa, 111 mothers will buy this bar to protect their family. The Lifebuoy brand was launched in 1894 in Victorian England to combat cholera. 6.6 million children never make it to their fifth birthday.

On October 15, we will celebrate Global Handwashing Day. The day is a celebration of the world's most important public health intervention. Most of these deaths are preventable, and that doesn't just make me sad, it makes me angry. The budget is not always there. The private sector can make a huge difference.

Diarrhea and pneumonia are among the top two killers of children under five. We run the world's largest handwashing program by any public health standards. We've reached over 183 million people in 16 countries. My team and I have the ambition to reach one billion by 2020.

Handwashing can reduce the risk of cancer by up to 50%. Hand washing has been shown to have a positive effect on cancer prevention. Hand washing can also help prevent the spread of the disease to other parts of the body, such as the lungs and liver.

MicroRNAs are small molecules that regulate gene expression. Unlike DNA, which is mainly fixed, microRNAs can vary depending on internal and environmental conditions. abnormal microRNA expression levels creates a unique, specific pattern for each type of cancer. This pattern reflects the progression of the disease, and whether it's responding to medication.

A new way to detect cancer is being developed. It uses a 3D-printed microchip that can detect cancer cells in real-time. The technology is being trialled in the U.S. and will be rolled out to other countries.

You don't need to have any symptoms to detect cancer. You only need one milliliter of blood and a relatively simple array of tools. Today, cancer detection happens mainly when symptoms appear. That is, at stage 3 or 4, and I believe that is too late.

"I want to dedicate the rest of my life to making Africa great," says Nelson Mandela. Mandela: "It's all because of leadership. One man, President Mugabe, is almost single-handedly responsible for having destroyed this country" "Africa needs a new generation of leaders," says Mandela.

In Africa, more than anywhere else in the world, the difference that just one good leader can make is much greater than anywhere  else. It's because in Africa, we have weak institutions, like the judiciary, the constitution, civil society and so forth.

African leaders make the most difference on the continent. The good news is that the quality of leadership in Africa has been improving. "For the first time Africa's growing, and in  fact it's the second fastest growing economic region in the world"

Africa has the fastest growing population in the world. By 2050, it will have the largest workforce in the globe. The continent needs to invest in its future and create jobs for the future. The next generation of leaders must do more than just talk.

Erick Rajaonary quit his job as a chartered accountant and started a company to manufacture fertilizer from the bat droppings. Today, Erick has built a business that generates several million dollars of revenue, and he employs 70 people full time and another 800 people during the season.

The African Leadership Academy has been running for the last 10 years. Over the next 50 years, it expects to create 6,000 transformative leaders for the continent. The academy will have 25 campuses in Africa, each with 10,000 leaders at a time.

Nelson Mandela once said, "Every now and then, a generation is called upon to be great. You can be that great generation" I believe that if we carefully identify and cultivate the next generation of African leaders, then this generation four that is coming up will be the greatest that Africa and indeed the entire world has ever seen.

GiveDirectly is the first organization dedicated to providing cash transfers to the poor. A sender can pay a 1.6 percent fee and with the click of a button send money directly to a recipient's account. GiveDirectly has sent cash to 35,000 people across rural Kenya and Uganda in one-time payments.

The more cash we give to the poor, and the more evidence we have that it works, the more we have to reconsider everything else we give. Organizations would have to prove that they're doing more good for the poor than the poor can do for themselves. The logic behind aid is too often, well, we do at least some good.

CNN's John Sutter talks about the idea of an unconditional cash transfer. Economists call it an unconditionalcash transfer, and it's exactly that: It's cash given with no strings attached. Governments in developing countries have been doing this for decades. Sutter: With more evidence and new technology, it's possible to make this a model for delivering aid.

In New Zealand, Dr. Lianne Parkin and her team tested an old tradition in her city. The tradition is that in the winter, in that city, you wear your socks on the outside of your boots. The results were quite graphic when they saw it, and it's true.

The Ig Nobel Prize for Literature is given out every year to people who have made a difference to the world. The winner is chosen by a panel of judges, and the winner is announced at the end of the year. The prize is given to the person who has made the greatest contribution to the field of literature.

You get an Ig Nobel prize. The design is different every year. Most prizes in the world also give their winners some cash, some money. The other thing you win is an invitation to come to the ceremony, which happens at Harvard University. It fits 1,100 people, it's jammed to the gills.

The winners are kept secret until that moment, even the Nobel laureates who will shake their hand don't know who they are until they're announced. A team of doctors in Europe published a series of papers about colonoscopies, one way or another. The child comes flying out through centrifugal force.

CNN's John Defterios goes to the bottom of the sea to find a new home for the crew of the Aquarius. The crew is trying to build a log cabin to live in for the rest of their lives. Defterio: "If we're going to explore the final frontier on this planet, we need to live there"

The team was able to study sharks and grouper in aggregations that they've never seen before. They were also able to commune with animals that are much larger than us, such as the endangered goliath grouper. "It's like seeing dogs and  cats behaving well together," says expedition leader.

Pulse Amplitude Modulated Fluorometer, or PAM, gauges the fluorescence of corals as it pertains to pollutants in the water and climate change-related issues. Scientists also used a prototype camera called the Edgertronic to capture slow-motion video.

CNN's John Defterios is on a mission to make the world a better place. He is using the internet to share his experiences with the world. Defterio: "We need to have an adventure in order to create miracles in the world"

"I like to get past the fur, the feathers and the scales. You just have to learn how to look past their disguise," he says. "As humans with hearts, we can all rejoice in the unity of life," he adds. "And who knows, maybe there will be underwater cities"

The Fotokite is a five kilogram device with an SLR under it. It is flown by the Kwikwasut'inuxw, a tribe from Vancouver, Canada. The ancient understanding that underneath their separate identities, all animals are one, has been a powerful inspiration to me.

"It's just difficult to come up with common sense laws to regulate flying cameras," he says. The other problem is regulations, or rather, the lack of good regulation. "It's a bit uncomfortable to fly, probably also for the operator," he adds.

The Fotokite is a quadrocopter with a dog leash. It's like a personal flying pet, says the project's creator. "It just always maintains a certain angle to you, and if I move around with it, it'll actually follow me naturally," he says.

Russian President Vladimir Putin has unveiled a camera that can be controlled from the air. Putin says the device is safe and easy to use. He says he plans to show the public how to use the camera on stage. The camera can also be used to take pictures of people in the sky.

CNN's John Sutter talks to a group of photographers who flew flying cameras as a hobby. Sutter: "You can really see the scale of this event — just the number of people, the colors, the banners" "I think, in the future, journalism and many other professions, there are flying cameras already quite commonly out there"

Cancer is about feelings and faith and losing and finding your identity, she says. It's about realizing that the most important things in life are not things at all, but relationships. "The only reason I did not kill him with my bare hands was because I could not lift my right arm"

The way to cope with trauma, with loss, with any life-changing experience is to find meaning. No one can tell us what our experience means. We have to decide what it means. Meaning can be quiet and introverted. Maybe we make one small decision about our lives that can bring about big change.
"I don't really have any friends," he says. "So what?" "I'm going to make friends" "And I will," he adds. "I will make friends with you" "You are my friend," she says, "and I will be your friend"

It's never too late to become someone other than simply a survivor. The three C's of the chaplain's job: Comfort, clarify and, when necessary, confront or challenge. Sometimes we just like the perks. Sometimes there's a payoff. But then we get stuck.

"I have seen this survivor identity have the most consequences is in the cancer community," he says. "People were leaving the bus before she even got to number two or number three," he adds. "I gave her a hug, and I said, "Get down off your cross"

"I didn't want to let that crucified self die. We have to let the old story go so that a new story, a truer story, can be told" "Maybe it would be the end of being trapped in our wounds and the beginning of amazing self- discovery" "I just want you all to know that we are on this bus together"

CNN's John Sutter talks about the power of working together. Sutter: "Each one of you is better than anybody else at something" "I grew up diagnosed as phobically shy, and, like at least 20 other people in this room, I was a stutterer"

CNN's John Defterios asks readers to become opportunity-makers. He says the world is calling out for us to have a collective mindset. "It calls on us, each of us, to a higher calling," he says. "I believe in doing that. It's especially important now"

"It's the unexpected things that you devise later on you never could have predicted," he says. "We open ourselves up to those opportunities, and in this room are key players who are uniquely positioned to do this," he adds. "It's not just the first opportunity that you do. It's after you've had that experience and you trust each other"

"The world is hungry for us to unite together as opportunity-makers," Obama says. "There's no greater opportunity or call for action for us now," he adds. "I am going to talk about gigantic trees that we put in nine strategic  pathways in the jungle"

CNN's John Defterios talks to the leaders of Colombia's guerrillas. He says the government wanted to demobilize as many of the rebels as possible. Defterio: "We didn't know very much about it. If you live in the cities, you don't really understand it"

He was recruited when he was 17, and sometime later, in his squadron, if you will, this beautiful girl was recruited, and they fell in love. But it turns out that love is very strictly forbidden in the lower ranks of the guerrilla, so their romance was discovered and they were separated. He walked for two days and two nights, and he got out, and the only thing he wanted was to see her.

The FARC guerrillas have been fighting in Colombia for more than 50 years. The Colombian government is trying to bring peace to the country. The government put up a Christmas tree in the capital, Bogota, to encourage demobilization. The FARC responded by saying they don't walk anymore and use rivers.

Most of the recruiting was being done in and around the river villages. We sent thousands of these down the rivers, and then picked them up later if they weren't. This generated, on average, a demobilization every six hours, so this was incredible.

"We are saving a place for you," the ad says. "I don't want to say in any way that it only has to do with what we do, but what I do know is that our work may have helped a lot of them start thinking about demobilization"

Housing crisis in Chile is one of the biggest in the world, with more than 220,000 people displaced. Housing crisis is a problem that can only be solved by building new homes, says housing minister. "The more complex the problem, the more the need for simplicity," says Hernández.

Designers are trying to give an answer to the "3S" menace, scale, speed, and scarcity. The key question is, which half of a good house do we do? They wanted to do with public money the half that families won't  be able to do individually.

We wanted to have the right light, with the right temperature, and the right air. It's a collection of floors, one on top of each other, with a core in the center. When you have an open atrium, you are able to see what others are doing from within.

Sustainability is nothing but the rigorous use of common sense. You don't require sophisticated programming. By 2030, out of the five billion people that will be living in cities, two billion are going to be under the line of poverty.

Alejandro Aravena: I don't know if you were able to read the subtitles, but you can tell from the body language that participatory design is not a hippie, romantic, let's-all-dream-together-about- the-future-of-the-city kind of thing. It is actually not even with the families trying to find the right answer.

Dre Urhahn: "Design's power of synthesis is trying to make a more efficient use of the scarcest resource in cities, which is not money but coordination" "We were able to save four million dollars, and  that is why the forest is today under construction," he says.

A Brazilian artist has painted a kite in the shape of a river. The artist wanted to show the effect of the river on the kite. The kite was painted in the same color as the river in the project's name. The project was a success.

Jeroen Koolhaas and his team spent almost an entire year painting a river in Vila Cruzeiro, Rio de Janeiro. During that time, another war broke out between the police and the drug gangs. They learned that during those times, people in communities really stick together during these times of hardship.

The project took almost two years to complete. More than 1,500 people put together and donated over 100,000 dollars. The city of Philadelphia thanked every single one of them and gave them a merit for their accomplishment. The project was funded through a crowd-funding campaign.

Houses are being plastered in Vila Cruzeiro, Brazil. The project was inspired by the idea that people should work together to build a community. The idea has spread to other parts of the world, including the U.S. and Holland.

Ethan Zuckerman: U.S. is leading the world in reforming marijuana policies. He says it's time to legally regulate and tax marijuana more or less like alcohol. Most politicians in my country want to roll back the Drug War now, he says.

In the late 19th century, when most of the drugs that are now illegal were legal, the principal consumers of opiates were middle-aged white women. The first drug prohibition laws in California and Nevada were driven by racist fears of Chinese transforming white women into opium-addicted sex slaves. The reason some drugs are legal and others not has almost nothing to do with science or health.

The U.S. has less than five percent of the world's population, but 25 percent of its prison population. "It's my country's history with alcohol prohibition and Al Capone, times 50," says John Sutter. Sutter: Legalizing marijuana would reduce crime, violence, corruption and black markets.

CNN's John Sutter: Will more people use marijuana? Maybe, but it's not going to be young people. He says people in their 40s and 60s and 80s may prefer a little marijuana to other drugs. Portugal treats addiction as a health issue, he says. Sutter says half of all people who were addicted to cigarettes have quit.

The obstacles to reform lie not just out there in the power of the prison industrial complex or other vested interests, but within each and every one of us. The War on Drugs gets justified as one great big child protection act, which any young person can tell you it's not. It's a subterfuge for advancing the realpolitik interests of the U.S.

Ethan Nadelmann: The Drug War did  nothing to protect their kids. The National: How can we use computers, cameras, microphones to represent the world in an alternative way, as much as possible? Vincent Moon: We wanted to create another type of intimacy using all those new technologies.

Filmmaker and music producer has spent five years traveling around the world to make his films. His films include music videos, documentaries and interviews with musicians and artists. He says he was traveling alone with a backpack, camera, microphones in it.

In Peru, they drink pisco sour. In Chechnya, I was there to research on Sufi rituals. I would publish them online for free under a Creative Commons license, but I would also give them to the people and I would let them do  what they want with it.

"I was still  keeping this idea in mind: What's the point? I was trying to get closer to a certain origin of it. We wanted to represent the music we love, the musicians we admired, as much as possible, far from the music industry"

"I think we are recording to regain a certain complexity," says the photographer. "The way we show the world is going to change the way we see this world" "I think you break it with your body, more than with your knowledge," he adds. "You walk into sacred rituals, private moments in a village"

Vincent van Gogh's new project, "Híbridos," is based in Brazil. Van Gogh: "I really believe Brazil, far from the cliches, is the greatest religious country in the world" He says Brazil is "the greatest country in terms of spirituality and in experimentations in spiritualities"

Naná Vasconcelos: The first patient to ever be treated with an antibiotic was a policeman in Oxford. He explains how antibiotics have been used in large quantities sub-therapeutically to make chicken and hogs grow faster. He says the massive use of antibiotics around the world has imposed such large selection pressure on bacteria.

The problem of antibiotic resistance is a global issue affecting both rich and poor countries. If I misuse antibiotics or I use antibiotics, not only am I affected but  others are affected as well. The costs I impose on others through global climate change go everywhere, and I don't necessarily take these costs into consideration.

We need to slow the pace of co-evolution with the bacteria. We have drug discovery processes, screening molecules, and FDA regulatory process. We might consider doing that for antibiotics as well. There are clean energy subsidies, which are to switch to fuels that don't pollute as much.

The cost of penicillin per day is about 10 cents. The government is now considering ways of subsidizing new antibiotics and development. Other alternative technologies that people are working on include bacteriophages, probiotics, quorum sensing, synbiotics.

The world depends on one drug, artemisinin drugs, essentially to treat malaria. If this were to become widespread, that puts at risk the single drug that we have to  treat malaria around the world. The alternative is a world in which even a blade of grass is a potentially lethal weapon.

My mother was diagnosed with stage IV breast cancer. She lost her address book and tried to find her doctor on the Internet. She was told she should be fired and sent back to her own country. She decided to stay and fight for her life.

"When it comes to medicine, having that trust is a must, and when that trust has been lost, then all that's left is fear" "What I saw behind every excuse was deep fear, and what I learned was that to become a doctor, we have to put on our white coats and hide behind it"

The more we know, the less we need to fear. We need to be afraid of what we don't know. The more we fear, the more we want to know. It's a vicious cycle. The fear of not knowing is the fear of knowing what we are doing.

People understand health care to be the individual interaction between them and their doctors. People want to know about their doctors first so that they can make an informed choice. In 1934, Dr. Sam Kuznets delivered a report to the U.S. Congress on the state of the economy. The report helped policy makers find a way out of the Great Depression. Kuznet's report was found to be so useful, it spread around the world.

GDP is a tool to help us measure economic performance. It's not a measure of our well-being. And it shouldn't be a guide to all decision making. We live in a world where GDP is the benchmark of success in a global economy.

The Social Progress Index is a measure of a person's well-being. The index is based on three questions: Do I have enough food, water and shelter? And do I have a chance to pursue my dreams and ambitions? The index was created to help people understand their needs and aspirations.

The Social Progress framework is based on 12 indicators. These include rights, freedom of choice, freedom from discrimination and access to the world's most advanced knowledge. New Zealand is the country with the highest social progress, according to the framework. It is followed by the United States, the UK, Australia and Canada.

The country with the least social progress, I'm sorry to say, is Chad. The highest ranked G7 country is Canada. The United States is considerably richer than New Zealand, but with a lower level of social progress. Senegal has a higher level of  social progress than Chad, but same level of GDP.

Gross domestic product (GDP) and social progress, according to a new report. The report shows that for poor countries, the curve is really steep. It shows that if poor countries can get a little bit of extra GDP, there's a lot of social progress bang for your GDP buck.

With more and more of the world's population living on this part of the curve, it means GDP is becoming less and less useful as a guide to our development. Earlier this year, with our friends from the Imazon  nonprofit here in Brazil, we launched the first subnational  Social Progress Index.

TEDx speaker: GDP has defined and shaped our lives for the last 80 years. You can create a Social Progress Index for any state, region, city or municipality. We did it for the Amazon region. With this detailed information, Imazon and other partners can work together to construct a development plan that will help really improve people's lives.

The ALS Association, they think by year end, it'll be 160 million dollars. YouTube has reported that over 150 countries have posted Ice Bucket Challenges for ALS. They had a clinical trial for a drug that they've been developing. It was on a three-year track for funding.

Some people, some Americans, think photographs like these best reflect how Obama really looks. 89 percent of these people voted for McCain. How could it be that when I look at a person, an object, or an event, I see something very different than somebody else does?

Social psychologist Dr. Michael Bociurkiw is fascinated by people who don't see eye to eye. He says perception is a subjective experience, and that's how we end up seeing through our own mind's eye. Researchers measured waist-to-hip ratio and asked people to walk to a finish line. People who were out of shape and unfit saw the distance to the finish line as significantly greater than people who were in better shape. People's states of their own body changed how they perceived the environment.

Survey: Unfit individuals saw the distance as farther, saw the finish line as farther away, than people who were in better shape. People who had committed to a manageable goal that they could accomplish in the near future and who believed that they were capable of meeting that goal saw the exercise as easier.

"Keep  your eyes on the prize" is an actual directive for how to look around your environment. People who used this strategy saw the finish line as 30 percent closer than people who looked around as they naturally would. "We thought this was great. We were really excited because it meant that this strategy helped make the exercise look easier"

People who kept their eyes on the prize actually moved 23 percent faster than people who looked around naturally. People who did the exercise required 17 percent less exertion than those who did it naturally. The exercise was moderately challenging but not impossible, like most exercises that improve our fitness.

What we think we see is actually filtered through our own mind's eye. We might see the world in a different way, and sometimes that might not line up with reality, but it doesn't mean that one of us is right and one of we is wrong.

The labor supply in Germany will go down in Germany, and will be much smaller in 2030. Germany will run into a major talent shortage very quickly. Technology will replace a lot of jobs, regular jobs. Even office workers are in jeopardy and might be replaced by robots, artificial intelligence, big data, or automation. The key question is not if technology replaces some of these jobs, but when, how fast, and to what extent.

Global workforce crisis consists of overall labor shortage plus a huge skill mismatch, plus a big cultural challenge. Right now, we are just at the turning point. Every company, but also every country, needs a people strategy, and to act on it immediately.

Deep learning is a single algorithm that can seem to do almost anything. In 2011, we had the first example of computers that can see better than people. In 2012, Google announced that they had a deep learning algorithm watch YouTube videos and crunched the data on 16,000 computers for a month.

Linguists call it borrowing, but we never give the words back, so I'm just going to be honest and call it stealing. Words in English are like Lego: If you use enough force, you can put any two of them together. Words like "heartbroken," "bookworm,"  "sandcastle" all are compounds.

Every language is just a group of people who agree to understand each other. Motel is a blend of "motor" and "hotel" Edutainment is a blending of "education" and 'entertainment" Commercial used to be an adjective  and now it's a noun.

Every word is a chance to express your idea and get  your meaning across. Mugwump is a perfectly  good word of English. Bulldozers bulldoze, butlers butle and burglers burgle. National Aeronautics and Space Administration becomes NASA.

There are two kinds of grammar, one inside your brain, the other inside your language. English has no age limit. Start making words today, send them to me, and I will put them in my online dictionary, Wordnik. The word "grammar" was invented by a professor at Boston University in 1958.

We used to have six billion hectares of forest -- 50 percent more than what we have now. In the last 100 years, we lost half of that. 12 percent of all the world's forests are in Brazil, most of that in the Amazon.

Deforestation was growing fast and accelerating at the end of the '90s and the beginning of the 2000s. We still have 80 percent of the forest cover. But we lost 15 percent in just 30 years. So now in Brazil,  we have this system, DETER, where every month, we get information on where deforestation is happening.

In the last 10 years, deforestation came down in Brazil 75 percent. Fifty million hectares of protected areas were created, which is an area the size of Spain. The indigenous people called this species pau brasil, and that's the reason why this land became "land of Brasil"

Violence in Congo is in large part driven by local bottom-up conflicts that international peace efforts have failed to help address. Violence is driven by illegal exploitation and trafficking of natural resources and sexual abuse of women and girls as a weapon of war.

The Democratic Republic of Congo is home to the largest and most expensive U.N. peacekeeping mission in the world. It is also home to some of the world's worst human rights abuses. In 2006, the country held the first free elections in its history, but violence continued.

U.N. peacekeepers have a dominant culture of conflict. They see conflict as the result of national and international tensions. It has led to a failure to address the root causes of conflict in the region. It is also the reason for the failure of peacekeeping efforts in Africa.

Violence in Congo is motivated not only by national and international causes, but also by longstanding bottom-up agendas. Many conflicts revolve around political, social and economic stakes that are distinctively local. This competition often results in localized fighting, for instance in one village or territory, and quite frequently, it escalates into generalized fighting.

Local conflicts fuel violence in most war and post-war environments. If we want international peacebuilding to work, conflicts must be resolved from the bottom up. In the rare cases where there have been comprehensive, bottom-up peacebuilding initiatives, these attempts have been successful.

International and Congolese actors should pay more attention to the resolution of land conflict. Local nongovernmental organizations, local authorities and civil society representatives should be the main actors in the bottom-up process. In the province of the Kivus, the Life and Peace Institute has set up inter-community forums to discuss the specifics of local conflicts.

I study monarchs because they get sick. They get sick like you. And I think what they do can tell us a lot about drugs that we can develop for humans. The parasites that monarchs get infected with are called ophryocystis elektroscirrha.

Scientists have found that monarchs can take up the chemicals and put it in their own bodies. This makes them toxic against their predators, such as birds. Scientists have also found that some milkweeds are medicinal, meaning they reduce the disease symptoms in the monarch butterflies.

Every year, thousands of Americans die of seasonal flu. Can the mothers lay their eggs on medicinal milkweed that will make their future offspring less sick? Scientists have done these experiments now over several years, and always get the same results. In indigenous cultures, traditional healers often look at animals to find new drugs.

The discovery that these animals can also use medication opens up completely new avenues. I think that maybe one day, we will be treating human diseases with drugs that were first discovered by butterflies, and that is an amazing opportunity worth pursuing. The problem with infectious diseases, as we all know, is that pathogens continue to evolve.

In high doses, it affects brain development, the immune system, hormonal systems and even the way our DNA is read and transcribed. Sixty-seven percent of the population had at least one ACE, and 12.6 percent, one in eight, had four or more ACEs.

High doses of adversity not only affect brain structure and function, they affect the developing immune system, developing hormonal systems, and even the way our DNA is read and transcribed. Life is never about the goals, it's about the journey. The only way to achieve all of your dreams is to fully enjoy every step of your journey. Some steps will be right on. Sometimes you will trip. But achieving a dream is a momentary sensation, and your life is not.

If every step becomes something to learn or something to celebrate, you will for sure enjoy the journey. Your overnight success story is always a result of everything you've done in your life through that moment. If it's right on, celebrate, because some people wait a lot to celebrate.

microbes have implications for all these different kinds of diseases, ranging from inflammatory  bowel disease to obesity, and perhaps even autism and depression. What microbes you have in your gut determine whether particular painkillers are toxic to your liver. They also determine whether or not other drugs will work for your heart condition.

NIH funded a $173 million project to map out all the A's, T's, G's, and C's in the human body. The map shows the oral, vaginal, skin, and fecal communities. Different parts of the map in different colors, almost like separate continents.

Each of us consists of about 10 trillion human cells, but we harbor as many as 100 trillion microbial cells. Each of us has about 20,000 human genes, but up to 20 million microbial genes. So whichever way we look at it, we're vastly outnumbered by our microbial symbionts.

In adults, microbial communities are relatively stable, so even if you live together with someone, you'll maintain your separate microbial identity over a period of weeks, months, even years. It turns out that our first microbial communities depend a lot on how we're born.

The Human Microbiome Project looks at the gut microbes of children and adults. In one video, a child gets antibiotics for an ear infection. Within weeks, the child has reached the healthy adult stool community. This raises questions about what happens when we intervene at different ages in child's life.

Microbes have been linked to a whole range of different diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease, heart disease, colon cancer, and even obesity. When we take the microbes from an obese mouse and transplant them into a genetically normal mouse, it becomes fatter than if it got them from a regular mouse.

Gates Foundation is funding a project to use microbes to treat malnutrition in Malawi. The project is the largest crowd-funded science project of its kind in the world. Over 8,000 people have signed up to take part in the project.

Scientists have been trying to find a way to stop illegal logging in the rainforest by using what's already in the forest. They hope to use stool from a healthy donor, that star down at the bottom, to transplant into patients with C. diff. Four of those patients are about to get a transplant from that healthy donor. Immediately, you have this radical change in the gut community.

Deforestation accounts for more greenhouse gas than all of the world's planes, trains, cars, trucks and ships combined. 90 percent of the logging that takes place in the rainforest is illegal, according to Interpol. The moment a sound of a chainsaw is heard in the forest, the device picks up the sound and sends an alert through the standard GSM network.

The device can listen to the sounds of the forest. It is able to hear chainsaw noises up to a kilometer in the distance. But if someone were to take them, it would make the area unprotected. The device is powered by a solar panel built from recycled industrial byproducts.

In Indonesia, the device picked up illegal chainsaw noises. It was able to get a real-time alert. The device also detected a cicada, a rhinoceros hornbill, and other birds. The tool is now being trialled in other parts of the world.

The project is based on the use of old cell phones in a gibbon reserve. People from around the world have been sending in their own old phones to be used in the project. The idea is to turn down the sound of the gibbons so they can't be heard by humans.

Twenty-five years ago, scientists at CERN created the World Wide Web. Since then, the Internet has transformed the way we communicate, do business, and even live. Today, when we send an email, we're not sending a letter. What you are sending, in many ways, is actually a postcard.

The business model of the Internet today really isn't compatible with privacy. To optimize the ads that are shown to us, companies have to know everything about us. If we want to have privacy online, what we have to do is we've got to go out and get it ourselves.

Scientists at the CERN nuclear research center in Switzerland have created a new way to send private emails. Called ProtonMail, the service encrypts emails before they leave the server. The project was inspired by the Edward Snowden leaks, which led to the creation of Protonmail.

ProtonMail lets users send encrypted messages without the server seeing them. The idea is to protect privacy without the need for ad revenue. ProtonMail is a free, open-source email service based in San Francisco. The company has raised more than half a million dollars in donations.

We need to build an Internet where privacy is not just an option, but the default. We need to protect our personal data, which tells us who we are and what we want to do. This is not an American or a European issue, it's a global issue.

As the web turns 25, it's very important for us to take a moment and think about the implications of this. We've lost privacy, yes, but what we've also lost is the idea of privacy itself. The more scary part about this is our data now lasts forever, so your data can and will outlive you.

Researchers estimate that just one cup of golden rice per day will save the lives of thousands of children. Golden rice is virulently opposed by activists who are against genetic modification. Every major scientific organization in the world has concluded that the crops currently on the market are safe to eat.

Pamela Ronald: What scares me most about the loud arguments and misinformation about plant genetics is that the poorest people who most need the technology may be denied access. The fear is that those incentives mean that the decision is not made on purely scientific grounds, and even if it was, there would be unintended consequences.

The flood-tolerant rice is distributed freely through Indian and Bangladeshi seed certification agencies. There are no commercial profits in this situation. The golden rice was developed through support of the Rockefeller Foundation. The rice is being freely distributed.

"The Red Circle and the Blue Curtain" is about the future of machine intelligence. "I like to think back further  to the ultimate cause. Look at these two highly distinguished gentlemen: We have Kanzi -- he's mastered 200 lexical tokens. And Ed Witten unleashed the second superstring revolution"

Human mind has evolved over 250,000 generations. Machine superintelligence is on the verge of a profound change in the substrate of thinking, says Andrew Keen. Keen: A.I. is nowhere near having the powerful, cross-domain ability to learn and plan as a human being has.

The ultimate limit to information processing in a machine substrate lies far outside the limits in biological tissue. A biological neuron fires at 200 hertz, 200 times a second. But even a present-day transistor operates at the Gigahertz. The potential for superintelligence lies dormant in matter.

The future of artificial intelligence is likely to be very different from what we think, says Ed Witten. Machine intelligence is the last invention that humanity will ever need to make, he says. Machines will then be better at inventing than we are, and they'll be doing so on digital timescales.

A superintelligence is a really strong optimization process. It's extremely good at using available means to achieve a state in which its goal is realized. This means that there is no necessary connection between being highly intelligent in this sense and having an objective that we humans would find worthwhile or meaningful.

Human beings in this model are threats, we could prevent the mathematical problem from being solved. If you create a powerful optimization process to maximize for objective x, you better make sure  that your definition of x incorporates everything you care about. This is a lesson that's also taught in many a myth. King Midas wishes that everything he touches be turned into gold.

CNN's John Sutter: How confident can we be that the A.I. couldn't find a bug? He says we should not be confident in our ability to keep a superintelligent genie locked up in its bottle forever. Sutter says the answer is to create superint intelligent A.i. such that even if it escapes, it is still safe because it shares our values.

Sam Kelly: Making superintelligent A.I. is a really hard challenge. He says we should work out a solution to the control problem in advance, so that we have it available by the time it is needed. Kelly: If  things turn out okay, that people a million years from now look back at this century and it might well be that they say that the one thing we did that really mattered was to get this thing right.

The brain is an amazing and complex organ. The brain is sending electrical messages back and forth, and chemical messages. Have you ever heard what your brain sounds like? GG: Let's try it out. So I'm going to turn this on for a second.

phthalmologist: "I'm going to find your ulnar nerve, which is probably right around here" "You don't know what you're signing up for when you come up" "So in a sense, she will take away your free will and you will no longer have any control over this hand"

Human-to-human interface is only done at major universities and large institutions. The equipment is so complex and so expensive that it's really only done in major universities. "This is going to feel like a -- (Laughter) You know, when you lose your free will, and someone else becomes your agent," he says.

One out of five of us, that's 20 percent of the entire world, will have a neurological disorder. And there are zero cures for these diseases. "What we should be doing is reaching back earlier in the eduction process and teaching students about neuroscience," he says.

Bacteria can be programmed to detect and treat diseases like cancer. Bacteria can grow in areas where the immune system has no access. Scientists have programmed bacteria to make a molecule that would change the color of your urine to indicate the presence of cancer. The technology could sensitively and specifically detect liver cancer.

Scientists have developed a way to create DNA programs that can be programmed into bacteria. The program allows bacteria to communicate and synchronize, as you're seeing in this movie. The technology is really powerful because it takes these phenomena that we normally have to experience through touch and it lets us capture them visually and non-invasively.

Scientists have developed a way to turn visible objects into visual microphones from a distance. Traditional microphones work by converting the motion of an internal diaphragm into an electrical signal. But sound causes all objects to vibrate. Those vibrations are just usually too subtle and too fast for us to see.

Abe Davis: A single frame of video may have hundreds of thousands of pixels in it. AD: If we combine all of the tiny motions that we see from across that entire image, then suddenly a thousandth of a pixel can start to add up to something pretty significant. He says even with the right algorithm, we were still missing a pretty important piece of the puzzle.

AD: "This was really significant, because it was the first time we recovered intelligible human speech from silent video of an object" AD: "We analyzed all of these experiments until we really understood the limits of our technique" "Once we understood those limits, we could figure out how to push them"

Scientists have developed a way to use vibrations in a video to capture objects in a way that will let us interact with them and see how they react to us. The technology could be used for surveillance, but it could also be used to learn more about the world.

A new technique allows scientists to simulate objects using just five seconds of video. The technique can be used to study objects in a variety of ways. The video below shows the first 21 days of a bee's life as it hatches into a larva.

Researchers are working on finding alternatives to control mites. They succeeded in breeding mite-resistant bees, but in that process, those bees started to lose traits like gentleness and their ability to store honey. To overcome that problem, these researchers are now collaborating with commercial beekeepers.

Bees pollinate one third of our food crops, and lately they've been having a hard time. The single greatest threat is a parasitic mite from Asia, Varroa destructor. This eventually destroys a hive because it weakens the immune system of the bees.

Bamboo has the tensile strength of steel, the compressive strength of concrete. It's lightweight, light enough to be lifted by just a few men, or, apparently, one woman. When my father built Green School in Bali, he chose bamboo for all of the buildings.

Bamboo has been in use across the tropical regions of the world for literally tens of thousands of years. Until recently, it was almost impossible to reliably protect bamboo from insects. Most people, especially in Asia, think that you couldn't be poor enough or rural enough to actually want to live in a bamboo house.

The house in Bali is built almost entirely from bamboo. It was designed by a team of local architects and designers. The bamboo is designed for curving, tapering, hollow poles. The living room overlooks the valley from the fourth floor.

The building is almost entirely handmade using hand-whittled bamboo pins. The bamboo floor is made of glossy and durable bamboo skin. The structural connections of our buildings are reinforced by steel joints, but we use a lot of hand- whittledamboo pins. There are thousands of pins in each floor.

With creativity and commitment, you can create beauty and comfort and safety and even luxury out of a material that will grow back. We made an air-conditioned, tented bed in the corner of her living room. Boxing off an area with tall walls just didn't feel right, so instead we made this giant woven pod.

Every affair will redefine a relationship, and every couple will determine what the legacy of the affair will be. The victim of an affair is not always the victim of the marriage. Betrayal in a relationship comes in many forms. Sexual betrayal is only one way to hurt a partner.

"I look at affairs from a dual perspective: hurt and betrayal on one side, growth and self-discovery on the other," he says. "Most of us are going to have two or three relationships or marriages," he adds. "Who knows what's really going on under the sheets there, right?"

The definition of infidelity keeps on expanding: sexting, watching porn, staying secretly active on dating apps. There is no universally agreed-upon definition of what even constitutes an infidelity. 95 percent of us will say that it is terribly wrong for our partner to lie about having an affair, but just about the same amount of us would do that if we were having one.

It's never been more difficult to keep a secret, and never has infidelity exacted such a psychological toll. When marriage was an economic enterprise, infidelity threatened our economic security. But now that marriage is a romantic arrangement, inf fidelity threatens our emotional security. Infidelity shatters the grand ambition of love.

"I thought I knew who I was. Now, I question everything" "We are entitled to pursue our desires," says author. "We have never been more inclined to stray" "It's the way of the world now," says writer.

If divorce carried all the shame, today, choosing to stay when you can leave is the new shame. The vast majority of people that I actually work with are not at all chronic philanderers. They are often people who are deeply monogamous in their beliefs, and at least for their partner.

At the heart of an affair, you will often find a longing and a yearning for an emotional connection. Affairs are an act of betrayal, and they are also an expression of longing and loss. Some affairs are an attempt to beat back deadness, in an antidote to death.

An affair is less about sex, and more about desire: desire for attention, desire to feel special. The very structure of an affair, the fact that you can never have your lover, keeps you wanting. Some affairs are death knells for relationships that were already dying on the vine. But others will jolt us into new possibilities.

Couples will have depths of conversations with honesty and openness that they haven't had in decades. Infidelity has a tenacity that marriage can only envy. We know from trauma that healing begins when the perpetrator acknowledges their wrongdoing. When they are done well, they are remixable, adaptable and they are powerful.

Roman Mars: People are passionate about flags, you know? That's the way it is. I put this picture online, and sure enough, someone left a comment that said, "You can take that Scottish Saltire and shove it up your ass." That hurts me just to look at it.

Ted Kaye is a flag expert and editor of a scholarly journal on flag studies. Kaye's first city flag was a beaut: white field, two horizontal blue stripes, and four six-pointed red stars down the middle. The blue stripes represent the water, the river and the lake.

The Chicago flag has become a symbol of the city's pride. The flag is made up of five colors: red, white, blue, green and black. It was designed to represent the city, not just the city itself. The Chicago flag was created by a group of artists in the 1960s.

The flag represents the city rising from the ashes after the devastating fires of the 1850s. The main component of the San Francisco flag is a phoenix. Behind the phoenix, the background is mostly white, and then it has a substantial gold border around it.

Most country flags are OK, but not US city flags, says CNN's John Sutter. "We just can't stop ourselves from putting our names on our flags," Sutter says. "If you can't tell what city they go to, yeah, that's exactly the problem, except for Anaheim"

The European equivalent of the municipal seal is the city coat of arms. These flags are everywhere in the US. The flag of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, was adopted in 1955. The seal-on-a-bedsheet flags are particularly painful and offensive to me.

Steve Kodis, a graphic designer from Milwaukee, wants to change the city's flag. The flag includes a picture of the Civil War battle flag of the Milwaukee regiment. 105 entries were received, but none of the new entries were worthy of flying over the city.

Steve Kotas is trying to redesign the Milwaukee flag. He says the best way to make a good flag is to take the motto off. Kotas: "In every bad flag there's a good Flag trying to get out" "Every great city deserves a great flag," he says.

The San Francisco city flag is in need of a makeover. The city flag could become a symbol of how a city considers design. The current design is too big and doesn't represent the city well. Here are some suggestions to make the flag more beautiful.

A well-designed flag could be seen as an indicator of how a city considers all of its design systems. The marriage of good design and civic pride is something that we need in all places. The best part about municipal flags is that we own them.

In the United States, we're aware of the fact that corporations are legal persons. In pre-independence India, a court held that a Hindu idol was a legal person. The great apes that you'll see behind me, they too are legal things.

The story of James Stewart is told in a new book, "James Stewart: The Story of a Black Man" The book is based on a real-life case involving a black man and a white man. The story is told through the eyes of the black man, James Stewart, and his family.

In 1772, Lord Mansfield ruled that James Somerset was a legal person. He issued the writ of habeus corpus, and James's body was brought in by the captain of the ship. The Nonhuman Rights Project is looking at what values and principles judges should use.

The Nonhuman Rights Project argues that drawing a line in order to enslave an autonomous and self-determining being like you're seeing behind me, that that's a violation of equality. It took us seven years, to find the jurisdiction where we wanted to begin filing our first suit. We chose the state of New York.

Chimpanzees are numerate and have a social culture. They have some kind of moral capacity. They don't have any legal rights. Scientists in the Taï Forests in the Ivory Coast found chimpanzees who were using these rocks to smash open the incredibly hard nuts.

The Nonhuman Rights Project filed three suits all across the state of New York using the same common law writ of habeus corpus argument that had been used with James Somerset. They wanted the chimpanzees out, and we wanted them brought to Save the Chimps, a tremendous chimpanzee sanctuary in South Florida.

Photographer and surfer David Hancocks has been photographing the Arctic Circle for more than a decade. He has traveled to Iceland, Norway, Alaska, Chile and the Faroe Islands to find the best waves in the world. He says he was inspired by the challenge of finding the perfect waves in such a remote area.

CNN's John Defterios traveled to the Arctic Circle to film a documentary. He experienced a blizzard and had to be rescued from the water. Defterio: "I could literally feel the blood trying to leave my hands, feet and face"

In 2011, during the final six months of Kim Jong-Il's life, I lived undercover in North Korea. It was a special year, marking the 100th anniversary of the birth of North Korea's original Great Leader, Kim Il-Sung. To celebrate the occasion, the regime shut down all universities, and sent students off to the fields.

The students were not allowed to leave the campus, or communicate with their parents. Their days were meticulously mapped out, and any free time they had was devoted to honoring their Great Leader. Lesson plans had to meet the approval of North Korean staff. Every room was bugged, and every conversation, overheard.

The North Korean leader's ideology and his students' day-to-day realities were all built on lies. The difference between truth and lies seemed at times hazy to them. They lie to shield their system from the world, or they were taught lies, and were just regurgitating them.

"I was spending all of my time with these young men. And watching them open up even in the tiniest of ways, was deeply moving" "They wrote that they were worried about their future. In those letters, they rarely ever mentioned their Great Leader"

"I wanted so much to tell them the truth, of their country and of the outside world" "But for them, the truth was dangerous. By encouraging them to run after it, I was putting them at risk" "I think they knew how sad I was"

MIRA, a P.C. software platform, uses a motion capture camera to transform traditional exercises into video games. The software is very customizable, and physical therapists can also create their own exercises. Poor muscle tone and impaired balance are the number one cause of falls, so reversing these problems through targeted exercise will help keep older people safer.

The tool is now available in over 10 countries, including the U.S. and the UK. It can be used to help patients with physical and mental health problems. It costs less than $1,000 and can be downloaded by anyone with an Xbox One.

Physicists work with patients to regain the range of movement lost due to an accident or injury. Patients find physical therapy boring, frustrating, confusing and lengthy before seeing results. The majority of patients don't do their exercises and therefore take a lot longer to get better.

CNN's John Sutter talks about the search for alien life. Sutter: There are just so many stars and so many planets out there, that surely, there must be life somewhere out there. "We have absolutely no evidence for life beyond Earth yet," Sutter says.

Kepler-186f is in a zone that is not too far from the star, so that the temperature may be just right for life. We know of a dozen planets that orbit two stars, and there's likely many more out there. If we could visit one of those planets, you would see two sunsets and have two shadows.

This planet is over 50 times closer to its star than our Earth is to the sun. The surface is hot enough to melt rock and has liquid lava lakes. We don't know much about this planet, but one possibility is that it's a water world.

Astronomers have been able to study dozens of exoplanet atmospheres, about six of them in great detail. But those are not small planets like Earth. They're big, hot planets that are easy to see. And in the search for planets, and in the future, planets that might be like Earth, we're able to help address some of the most amazing and mysterious questions.

MIT professor explains how exoplanet atmospheres are studied. Each different atom and molecule has a special set of lines, a fingerprint, if you will. The goal is to look for gases in other planet atmospheres that don't belong, that we might be able to attribute to life.

Life produces thousands of gases, including carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, molecular hydrogen, molecular nitrogen, methane, methyl chloride. "We think we have found something very interesting in another field," researcher says. "How and why did life originate and populate our planet? But a really big challenge ahead of us is: how?"

The starshade is a specially shaped screen that blocks out the light of a star. The goal is to block out the starlight to incredible precision so that we'd be able to see the planets directly. It's shaped like a giant flower, and this is one of the prototype petals.

In the next generation of space telescopes, we will have the capability to find and identity other Earths. We are making a new kind of map of the nearby stars and of the planets orbiting them. And so I envision that our descendants, hundreds of years from now, will embark on an interstellar journey to other worlds.

Rosetta Mission Manager Fred Jansen: "It's the first time in human history that this really is within reach for us" "We're going to look at a special kind of planet called transient exoplanets" "After 9/11, the FBI was given an edict: never again"

The FBI is responsible for more terrorism plots in the U.S. than any other organization. An informant can earn 100,000 dollars or more for every terrorism case they bring to the FBI. The FBI is paying mostly criminals and con men six figures to spy on communities in the United States.

Sami Osmakac, a young man who was living near Tampa, Florida, had no connections to international terrorist groups. An FBI informant gave him a job, handed him money, introduced him to an undercover agent posing as a terrorist. The lead undercover agent would go back to the Tampa field office with his recording equipment on.

CNN's John Sutter says the U.S. government has a problem with "hollywood terrorists" Sutter: The FBI has never been able to prove that these people are actually terrorists. He says the problem is that the government doesn't know what to do about it.

The Intercept published a story about how Sami Osmakac was set up in an FBI sting. The story was based on leaked transcripts of private FBI conversations. The FBI spends 3.3 billion dollars a year on domestic counterterrorism activities. The pursuit of terrorists has consumed the FBI.

In the 14 years since 9/11, you can count about six real terrorist attacks in the United States. The FBI has bragged about how it's foiled dozens of terrorism plots. In all, the FBI has arrested more than 175 people in aggressive, undercover stings.

LZ Granderson: "Babies' first words aren't just things like balls and ducks, they're things like "all gone" "They're figuring out the entire world. It has to be that powerful," he says. "There really is genius there that is underappreciated"

LS: In any scenario, our machines have so much to learn from our toddlers. Mark Twain summed up what I take to be one of the fundamental problems of cognitive science with a single witticism. It's the structured, hierarchical nature of human knowledge that remains a real challenge.

Babies make generalizations about almost everything, says David Frum. Frum: "One gets such wholesale returns of conjecture out of such a trifling investment in fact" "It's really easy to pull three blue balls in a row out of a box of mostly blue balls," he says.

A baby's ability to generalize properties of blue balls to yellow balls is fascinating. From a few bones, we infer the existence of dinosuars. The really interesting question is what happens when we show babies exactly the same thing. That is not plausibly randomly sampled evidence.

LZ Granderson: Babies are much more likely to generalize the evidence when it's plausibly representative of the population. LZ: "Babies, in this respect, like scientists, care whether evidence is randomly sampled or not" He says babies use this to develop expectations about the world: what squeaks and what doesn't.

In this next experiment, we're going to give babies just a tiny bit of statistical data supporting one hypothesis over the other. Some people can make this toy go, and some can't. The important point here is it provides a little bit of evidence that the problem isn't with the toy, it's with the person.

LS: I have spent the past decade trying to understand the mystery of how children learn so much from so little so quickly. YG: Arthur, let me try again, okay? L: Of course babies give toys to their mommies when they can't make them work. L: And this suggests it doesn't matter who tries this toy, the toy is broken.

LS: In the second year of life, babies can use a tiny bit of statistical data to decide between two fundamentally different strategies for acting in the world. LS: Children's ability to make rich inferences from sparse data underlies all the species-specific cultural learning that we do.

"It's a story about the kinds of computations that uniquely human minds can perform" "We are very unlikely to see anything even approximating the computational power of a human child in my lifetime or in yours" "Everybody has a plan, until they get punched in the face"

The top five Idealab companies -- Citysearch, CarsDirect, GoTo, NetZero, Tickets.com -- all became billion-dollar successes. The five companies on the bottom -- Z.com, Insider Pages, MyLife, Desktop Factory, Peoplelink -- didn't succeed.

Timing accounted for 42 percent of the difference between success and failure. Team and execution came in second, and the idea, the differentiability of the idea came in third. "I believe that the startup organization is one of the greatest forms to make the world a better place"

GoTo.com, Citysearch and Z.com were all founded when broadband penetration was too low. YouTube was perfectly timed when it had a business model and broadband penetration crossed 50 percent in America. The best way to assess timing is to look at whether consumers are really ready for what you have to offer them.

In the great 1980s movie  "The Blues Brothers," there's a scene where John Belushi goes to visit Dan Aykroyd in his apartment in Chicago for the very first time. By the 100th time, at least for me, I became numb to it. Why do we get used to everyday things?

As humans, our brains encode everyday things into habits to free up space to learn new things. Habituation is one of the most basic ways, as humans, we learn. But sometimes, habituation isn't good, as this story shows.

Jerry Seinfeld's entire career was built on noticing those little details, those idiotic things we do every day that we don't even remember. Comedians know all about this. It's our job to not just notice those things, but to go one step further and try to fix them.

"We ran that product for over two hours. We ran it for about 30 minutes in the factory to make sure that hard drive's going to be working years later for the customer after they  pull it out of the box" "We're not going to let that  happen to our product," he says.

The TED Talk is hosted by TED Talk presenter and product designer, John Sutter. Sutter: "There are invisible problems all around us, ones we can solve. But first we need to see them, to feel them" Sutter offers tips on how to fight habituation.

In the 1970s, the energy crisis struck, and customers started thinking about how to save energy. Instead of just turning up and down, you now had to program it. So you could tell it the temperature you wanted at a certain time. Now that seemed great. But it turned out that no one saved any energy.

Thermostat designers went back to the drawing board and focused on that programming step. They put a machine-learning algorithm in instead of the programming that would simply watch when you turned it up and down. And you know what? It worked. People are saving energy  without any programming.

Strawberry Mansion was labeled "low-performing and persistently dangerous" due to its low test scores and high number of weapons, drugs, assaults and arrests. The halls were dim and dark from poor lighting. There were tons of piles of broken old furniture and desks in the classrooms.

Strawberry Mansion High School is a low-income, low-performing school in North Philadelphia. Principal: "I was not going to be afraid to address anything that was not good for children" "I am a leader, so I know I cannot do anything alone," principal says. Strawberry Mansion was removed from the Persistently Dangerous List after five years on the list. The school's new principal created a "non-negotiables" program to promote positive behavior. The program included a variety of start and end times, remediation and extracurricular activities.
