When I have a perceptual experience that I describe as a red tomato, I am interacting with reality, but that reality is not ared tomato and is nothing like a red tomatoes. When I describe a lion or a steak, I'm interacting with Reality, but Reality is not lion or steak. Reality is the real source of cause and effect in the world -- not brains, not neurons.

Theory of evolution presents us with the ultimate dare: Dare to recognize that perception is not about seeing truth, it's about having kids. Once we let go of our massively intuitive but massively false assumption about the nature of reality, it opens up new ways to think about life's greatest mystery.

Darwin: Our perceptions have been shaped not to show us reality as it is. But that does not mean the same thing about our logic or mathematics, he says. Darwin: What's true about perception may not be true about math and logic. He says we have to look at each cognitive faculty one at a time.

phthalmologists say a third of the brain's cortex is engaged in vision. The eye is like a 130-megapixel camera, according to neuroscientists. The brain is made up of billions of neurons and trillions of synapses. It takes a picture of objective reality as it is seen by the eye.

Neuroscientists tell us that they are creating, in real time, all the shapes, objects, colors, and motions that we see. But that doesn't explain the billions of neurons and trillions of synapses that are engaged in vision.

neuroscientists say that we don't just construct, we reconstruct. Those of our ancestors who saw more accurately had a competitive advantage compared to those who saw less accurately. So, when I have an experience that I describe as a red tomato, that experience is actually an accurate reconstruction of a real red tomato.

Australia had to change its bottles to save its beetles. The males swarm all over the bottles trying to mate. They lose all interest in the real females. The species almost went extinct. It looked like they saw reality as it is, but apparently not. Evolution had given them a hack.

Fitness is not the same thing as reality as it is, and it's fitness, and not reality, that figures centrally in the equations of evolution. In almost every simulation, organisms that see none of reality but are just tuned to fitness drive to extinction. Those perceptions of reality go extinct.

Huxley: All organisms, including us, are in the same boat as the jewel beetle. The relationship between brain activity and conscious experiences is still a mystery. Huxley says we are shaped with tricks and hacks that keep us alive.

Hoffman: If you think that train coming down the track at 200 MPH is just an icon of your desktop, why don't you step in front of it? And after you're gone, and your theory with you, we'll know that there's more to that train than just an icons.

Physicists have told us for a long time that the metal of that train looks solid but really it's mostly empty space with microscopic particles zipping around. We all see a cube because we all, each one of us, constructs the cube that we see. The same is true of all physical objects.

Theory of evolution is telling us that once again, we're wrong. We're misinterpreting the content of our perceptual experiences. It's as hard for us to let go of spacetime and objects as it is for the jewel beetle. Why? Because we're blind to our own blindnesses.

An evolutionary biologist at Purdue University named William Muir studied chickens. He was interested in productivity, but it's easy to measure in chickens because you just count the eggs. So what is it that makes some groups obviously more successful and more productive than others? A team at MIT took to research.

Arup, one of the world's most successful engineering firms, was commissioned to build the equestrian center for the Beijing Olympics. Arup believes that the culture of helpfulness is central to their success. In groups that are highly attuned and sensitive to each other, ideas can flow and grow.

What drives helpfulness is people getting to know each other, says David Walliams. Companies don't have ideas; only people do. What motivates people are the bonds and loyalty and trust they develop between each other. "What matters is the mortar, not just the bricks," he says.

Social capital is the reliance and interdependency that builds trust. The term comes from sociologists who were studying communities that proved particularly resilient in times of stress. For decades, the prevalence estimates remained stable at just three or four children in 10,000. In the 1990s, the numbers started to skyrocket. Fundraising organizations like Autism Speaks routinely refer to autism as an epidemic. 132 kids in California got the measles by either visiting Disneyland or being exposed to someone who'd been there.

Leo Kanner classified autism as a form of infantile psychosis caused by cold and unaffectionate parents. By the 1950s, as the world's leading authority on the subject, he declared that he had seen less than 150 true cases of his syndrome while fielding referrals from as far away as South Africa.

Autism became a source of shame and stigma for families, and two generations of autistic children were shipped off to institutions for their own good. Lorna Wing was a cognitive psychologist in London who thought that Kanner's theory of refrigerator parenting were "bloody stupid" She and her colleague Judith Gould undertook a study of autism prevalence in the general population.

Hans Asperger ran a combination clinic and residential school in Vienna in the 1930s. He viewed autism as a diverse continuum that spans an astonishing range of giftedness and disability. Lorna and Judith realized that Kanner had been as wrong about autism being rare.

Autistic people reject the notion that they are puzzles to be solved by the next medical breakthrough. Autistics are one of the largest minority groups in the world. The normal human brain is easily distractable, obsessively social, and suffers from a deficit of attention to detail.

Writer's great uncle died in the last days of the pre-antibiotic era. People are dying of infections again because of a phenomenon called antibiotic resistance. Bacteria compete against each other for resources, for food, by manufacturing lethal compounds.

In 2000, the CDC identified a single case in a hospital in North Carolina of an infection resistant to all but two drugs. The gene that creates that resistance, known as NDM, has now spread from India into China, Asia, Africa, Europe and Canada. In the United States and Europe, 50,000 people a year die of infections which no drugs can help.

A recent study estimates that without antibiotics, one out of ever six would die. Without that protection, we'd lose the ability to open the hidden spaces of the body. We'd have to learn to fear infections that now seem minor. The first person to receive penicillin, a British policeman named Albert Alexander, was so ravaged by infection that his scalp oozed pus and doctors had to take out an eye.

In the United States, possibly 80 percent of the antibiotics sold every year go to farm animals, not to humans. In much of the developing world, most antibiotics still are. And because bacteria can pass their DNA to each other like a traveler handing off a suitcase at an airport, there is no knowing where it will spread.

"I hope this evil can be averted," says the doctor. "It takes pharmaceutical chemistry 10 years to derive a new drug," he says. "We could build gatekeeping into drug order systems," he adds. "Those are the tech solutions"

Antibiotic resistance is a habit. We all know how hard it is to change a habit, but as a society, we've done that in the past. People used to toss litter into the streets, used to not wear seatbelts. We don't do those things anymore. We could change social norms around antibiotic use too.

The average commute time in the U.S. is 50 minutes. That's about six billion minutes wasted in commuting every day. The average life expectancy of a person is 162 lifetimes spent every day, wasted, just getting from A to B. We should do something about that.

The car uses a map and its sensor data to understand where it is in the world. It then layer on top of that what it sees in the moment. The car then predicts what's going to happen, such as a truck making a lane change.

Vehicles have to deal with other people moving through that construction zone as well. 1.2 million people are killed on the world's roads every year. Abortion is hotly debated, but it's still rare for women to talk about it. There are two main ways to get started. One is to listen closely. The other way is to share stories. This isn't just about abortion. It's so many important issues.

"Pro-voice" works on hard issues like immigration, religious tolerance, violence against women. It also works on deeply personal topics that might only matter to you and your immediate family and friends. Listening and storytelling are the hallmarks of pro-voice practice.

There is no perfect time and no perfect place to start a difficult conversation. If we truly listen to one another, we will hear things that demand that we shift our own perceptions. There's lots of ways to be a good listener and I'm going to give you just a couple.

When we reflect the language of the person who is sharing their own story, we are conveying that we are interested in understanding who they are and what they're going through. So, another way to be pro-voice is to share your story with someone else, who might actually make a different decision.

Pro-voice creates a culture that values what makes us human, our flaws and our imperfections. It generates empathy that we need to overcome all the ways that we try to hurt one another. Pro-voice is about the real stories of real people making an impact on the way abortion is understood and discussed.

The TED Talk is a thought experiment on the effects of heroin on the human body. The author, who has a history of drug addiction, thought he knew what would happen. He was shocked to learn that the drug is actually much more addictive than he first thought.

In Rat Park, they don't like the drug water. They almost never use it compulsively. None of them ever overdose. Scientists use insects to make fundamental discoveries about everything from the structure of our nervous systems to how our genes and DNA work. Insects seem like they do everything that people do. They meet, they mate, they fight, they break up. They do so with what looks like love or animosity.

Female aphids can make little, tiny clones of themselves without ever mating. Dragonflies and damselflies have penises that look kind of like Swiss Army knives. They use these devices to remove the sperm from previous males that the female has mated with.

The males of katydids are very picky about who they mate with. They give the female something called a nuptial gift. The gift is very nutritious and the female eats it during and after mating. The bigger it is, the better off the male is, because that means more time for his sperm to drain into her body.

The ancient Greeks couldn't figure out the drones' sex. They found it difficult to believe that any animals that bore such a weapon could possibly be a female. Even today, my students call every animal they see, including insects, a male.

Scientists use white rats or fruit flies as stand-ins for all other animals, including people. The idea is that what's true for a person will also be true for the white rat. Scientists use males, in any species, as though they are the model system. The way things are supposed to be.

Insects have little brains, so it's hard to think of them as people. They're more numerous than any other kind of animal. They make us question what's normal and what's not. The allure of another world is part of why they're so popular.

In Western cultures, when you have cancer, it's as if you disappear in a way. With all this information and support, I was able to form a team of several neurosurgeons, traditional doctors, oncologists, and several hundred volunteers. Together, we were able toform a strategy for my own cure in many languages, according to many cultures.

Thousands of people shared their stories, their experiences. Doctors got to talk with people they don't usually consult when they think about cancer.

Homo sapiens are the only animals that can cooperate both flexibly and in very large numbers. A stem cell that builds up the entire vertebrate skeleton, bone, cartilage and the fibrous elements of skeleton is called a skeletal stem cell. The degeneration or dysfunction of this stem cell is what's causing osteochondral arthritis, a very common ailment. The cells live inside the skeleton.

Stem cells are dying to form cartilage. They form their own furls of cartilage around themselves. They are the most efficient repairers of fractures that we've ever encountered. Their numbers decline precipitously, precipitiously, tenfold, fiftyfold as you age.

"What's at stake, as I said before, is not killing something, but growing something" "Can you imagine ways of passively loading and unloading bone so that you can recreate or regenerate degenerating cartilage?" "What if the organ needed to have memory?"

At the center of his work is a split screen to represent his split world view. His work is about uniting these two worldviews, moving away from assembly and closer into growth. At the intersection of these four fields, his team and I create objects and products across scales.

The helmet combines stiff and soft materials in 20-micron resolution - the resolution of a human hair. The acoustic chair is printed out of 44 different properties, varying in rigidity, opacity and color, corresponding to pressure points on the human body. The second-most abundant biopolymer on the planet is called chitin. 100 million tons of it are produced every year by organisms such as shrimps, crabs, scorpions and butterflies. By varying chemical concentrations, we were able to achieve a wide array of properties.

Scientists have created a structure made of shrimp shells that behaves like a tree. They used the same design principles to create life-sustaining clothing for interplanetary voyages. "I like to think of synthetic biology as liquid alchemy, only instead of transmuting precious metals, you're synthesizing new biological functionality inside very small channels"

Scientists have created a 3-D model of a silkworm cocoon using a magnetic field. The structure of the cocoon is created by combining two proteins in different concentrations. The process is similar to that used in 3D printing, but in a more complex way.

We used a sun path diagram to reveal the distribution of light and heat on our structure. We then created holes, or apertures, that would lock in the rays of light. And after four weeks of feeding, they were ready to spin with us. Over two to three weeks, the silkworms spin 6,500 kilometers.

The UN agreed in 2001 to halve the proportion of people living in poverty by 2015. The target was to take from a baseline of 1990, when 36 percent of the world's population lived in poverty. This year, global poverty is going to fall to 12 percent.

The Global Goals aren't just ambitious, they're also pretty complicated. Over 17 goals, there are then 169 targets and literally hundreds of indicators. Some of the goals are pretty specific -- end hunger -- others are a lot vaguer -- promote peaceful and tolerant societies.

The Social Progress Index sums all this together using 52 indicators to create an aggregate score on a scale of 0 to 100. The highest performing country, Norway, scores 88. Central African Republic, scores 31. The average human being is living on a level of social progress about the same of Cuba or Kazakhstan today.

The leaders of the world agreed a new set of Global Goals for the development of the. world to 2030. The best forecast comes from the US Department of Agriculture, which forecasts 3.1 percent average global economic growth over the next 15 years. If they're right, per capita GDP will be about $23,000.

Economic growth seems to have really helped in the fight against poverty. But it doesn't seem to be having much impact on trying to get to the Global Goals. So what's going on? In a way, we're the victims of our own success.

The world is scoring 61 on social progress, and the place we want to get to is 75. From poor countries like Rwanda to richer countries like New Zealand, we see that it's possible to get lots of social progress. If we prioritize the well-being of people, we can make a lot more progress than our GDP might expect.

If we rely on economic growth alone, we're going to get to 62.4. We have to prioritize social progress, and really scale solutions around the world. I believe the Global Goals are a historic opportunity, because the world's leaders have promised to deliver them.

The People's Report Card grades countries on a scale of F to A. The Global Goals are all about getting to an A, the report card says. "Let's reject business as usual. Let's choose the world that we want to live in," Green says.

It takes years for a drug to go from being tested on cells to being available to the public. It takes billions of dollars of funding to go through that process. The world is going backwards, not forwards. We need to focus on how to get to the top.

Ambien was released on the market over 20 years ago. The Food and Drug Administration recommended cutting the dose in half for women only. Women metabolize the drug at a slower rate than men, causing them to wake up with more of the active drug in their system.

Women's health became synonymous with reproduction: breasts, ovaries, uterus, pregnancy. The concept was challenged by the medical community and by public health policymakers in the 1980s. Since that time, evidence has come to light that shows us just how different men and women are in every way.

Shadi Omar Kataf and Mouaz Al Balkhi drowned trying to swim across the English Channel. The two young men fled the war in Syria, ended up stuck in Calais, bought wetsuits and drowned. Between 3,500 and 5,000 people are living here under horrible conditions.

Mouaz was born in the Syrian capital of Damascus in 1991. His father spent 11 years in prison for belonging to the political opposition in Syria. Mouaz studied to become an electrical engineer at the University of Damascus. He made at least 12 failed attempts to cross the English Channel by hiding in a truck.
Mouaz and his family were killed in the Syrian civil war. They lived in an area of Damascus known as Camp Yarmouk. Out of a population of 150,000, only 18,000 are believed to still be in the area.

Shadi and one of his sisters fled to Libya after the fall of Gaddafi. He fell in love with the ocean, and hoped to find work as a diver in Italy. But reality was not that easy. He was found 800 kilometers away in a wetsuit on a Norway beach.

A better life for all of us is to be able to live in peace with ourselves and our loved ones. We can't do that if we live in fear of our future. We need to be free from fear of what the future holds for us.

A few years ago, with my colleague, Emmanuelle Charpentier, I invented a new technology for editing genomes. The opportunity to do this kind of genome editing also raises various ethical issues that we have to consider. The CRISPR technology allows scientists to make changes to the DNA in cells that could allow us to cure genetic disease.

The Cas9 gene-editing system can be used to repair DNA breaks. The technology is similar to a computer program that can be programmed to fix a typo. It could be used in the treatment of diseases such as cystic fibrosis, for example.

The first applications of the CRISPR technology are going to happen in the blood. The technology is being used to make very precise changes that allow us to study the way that these changes in the cell's DNA affect either a tissue or an entire organism.

Jennifer Doudna: "This raises a number of ethical questions that we have to carefully consider" She and her colleagues have called for a global pause in any clinical application of the CRISPR technology. "This is no longer science fiction. Genome-engineered animals and plants are happening right now," she says.

JD: I hope that we can air the views of many different individuals and stakeholders who want to think about how to use this technology responsibly. BG: Is there a possible split happening in the science community about this? JD: In the end, this technology will be used for human genome engineering, but I think to do that without careful consideration and discussion of the risks would not be responsible.

As a Deaf person living in a world of sound, it's as if I was blindly following its rules, customs, behaviors and norms without ever questioning them. I learn and mirror that behavior. At the same time, I've learned that I create sound, and I've seen how people respond to me.

In Deaf culture, movement is equivalent to sound. A typical staff contains five lines. The lines already contain sound through the subtle smudges and smears. If you're playing a musical instrument and you notice a "p" in the score, you need to play softer.

"I know sound so well that it doesn't have to be something just experienced through the ears," says the artist. In American Sign Language, there are different ways to say the same thing. For example, the sign for "day" is "all day" If you repeat the sign over and over, it becomes a piece of music. The same thing can be done with other words and phrases.

French sign language was brought to America during the early 1800s. As time went by, mixed with local signs, it evolved into the language we know today as ASL. Common time is a musical term with a specific time signature of four beats per measure.

The International [Sign] is a visual tool to help communicate across cultures and sign languages around the world. The sign for "to fall in love" in ASL is the same as "common time" and "enlightenment" In ASL, the head and the chest are used to convey different meanings.

GlaxoSmithKline estimates 90 percent of drugs work in only 30 to 50 percent of the people. 300 people have to take the drug for a year before one heart attack, stroke or other adverse event is prevented. Side effects include debilitating muscle and joint pain, gastrointestinal distress.

You're 15 times more likely to be harmed by the drug than you are to be helped by it. The most widely performed surgery on men over the age of 50, removal of the prostate for cancer, the number needed to treat is 49. 49 surgeries are done for every one person who's helped. The side effects in that case occur in 50 percent of the patients.

The brain under stress releases cortisol, and one of the things that happens at that moment is a whole bunch on systems shut down. The idea is to think ahead to what those failures might be, to put systems in place that will help minimize the damage, or to prevent the bad things from happening.

In California, we already recycle about 40 billion gallons a year of water through the two-stage advanced process. The water comes into our treatment wetland, it's exposed to sunlight and algae, and those break down the organic chemicals. It then flows down to Anaheim, and becomes the drinking water of the city.

In California and other modern American cities, about half of our water use happens outdoors. We've seen that it's possible to have our lawns survive and our plants survive with about half as much water. There's no need to start painting concrete green and putting in Astroturf and buying cactuses.

Cave diver: "Let's create a water supply that will be able to withstand any of the challenges that climate change throws at us in the coming years" "I'm an underwater explorer, more specifically a cave diver. And my voice is the one that's going to teach you about the inside of Mother Earth," he says.

Caves are repositories of amazing life-forms that we never knew existed before. They have no pigment and no eyes in many cases, and these animals are also extremely long-lived. In fact, animals swimming in these caves today are identical in the fossil record.

Paleoclimatologists are also interested in where the sea level stands at other times on earth. In places like Mexico, in the Bahamas, and even in Cuba, we're looking at cultural remains and also human remains in caves. But as it turns out, we know a lot more about space than we do about underground waterways.

Informational tool allows users to create their own 3D models of the world around them. Informational tools can also be used to help people understand the world in a new way. The technology is being developed by the University of California, San Diego.

InFORM is an interface built on inFORM to allow urban planners to design and view entire cities. The pins of the display represent people's hands, allowing them to actually touch and manipulate objects at a distance. You can also manipulate and collaborate on 3D data sets as well.

"We started with a single motor, a single linear actuator, and then we had to design a custom circuit board" "It's not that complex compared to what's going on at CERN, but it did take a long time for us to build it"

A new high-resolution version of TRANSFORM uses an array of servomotors to change from interactive wristband to a touch- input device to a phone. TRANSFORM is an interactive table-scale version of these shape displays. The system will understand what shape it's in and change to that mode.

We need computers that can physically adapt to us. We need to harness the rich dexterity that we have of our hands. I think we need to go beyond this, beyond devices, to really think about new ways that we can bring our information into the world. Thank you very much.

The first poem was generated by an algorithm called Racter, that was created back in the 1970s. The second poem was written by a guy called Frank O'Hara, who happens to be one of my favorite human poets. We have, more or less, a 50/50 split here.

According to the logic of the Turing test, can a computer write poetry? Well, yes, absolutely it can. So you'd be surprised to find that Poem 1 was written by the very human poet Gertrude Stein. And Poem 2 was generated by an algorithm called RKCP.

Poem 2 was fed a bunch of poems by a poet called Emily Dickinson. It looked at the way she used language, learned the model, and then it regenerated a model according to that same structure. But the important thing to know about RKCP is that it doesn't know the meaning of the words it's using.

The human is not a cold, hard fact. Rather, it is something that's constructed with our opinions and something that changes over time. The computer, more or less, works like a mirror that reflects any idea of a human that we show it. We show it Emily Dickinson, it gives Emily Dickinson back to us.

The computer is a mirror that reflects any idea of the human we teach it. The human is not a scientific fact, that it's an ever-shifting, concatenating idea and one that changes over time. This is an essentially philosophical idea, and it's one that can't be answered with software alone.

CNN's John Defterios asks: "What kind of change are you foreseeing?" Defterio: "If we don't change the architecture of the Eurozone, it's going to get worse and worse" "We need to change the way we look at the world," he says, "and not just the way it looks at us"

Greece has lost one-third of its nominal GDP, says Yanis Varoufakis. "This is worse than the Great Depression," he says. "If we allow ourselves to fall into a route of the postmodern 1930's, that will be detrimental to the future of Europeans and non-Europeans"

In the last three months, in the United States, in Britain and in the Eurozone, we have invested, collectively, 3.4 trillion dollars on all the wealth-producing goods. The result is stagnant wages, more than a quarter of 25- to 54-year-olds in America, Japan and in Europe out of work.

Aristotle defined democracy as the constitution in which the free and the poor, being in the majority, control government. The working poor acquired the rights to political judgments that were afforded equal weight in the decision-making concerning matters of state. We mistakenly believe that capitalism begets inevitably democracy.

The economic sphere has been colonizing and cannibalizing the political sphere. The more capitalism succeeds in taking the demos out of democracy, the taller the twin peaks and the greater the waste of human resources and humanity's wealth. The question is whether capitalism will be succeeded by something resembling a Matrix dystopia or something closer to a Star Trek-like society.

Greece's newly elected government is trying to reform the country's economy. Greece's Finance Minister says the country needs a "Star Trek-like utopia" to achieve this. He suggests a world where all income stems from capital, and the concept of wage labor becomes obsolete.

Yanis Varoufakis: If there was any relevance in what I just said, then Marx is relevant. The whole point of reunifying the political and economic is. If we don't do it, then technological innovation is going to create such a massive fall in aggregate demand.

Greece's Finance Minister Yves Villeprez talks to CNN about his year in office. He says China is creating an artificial environment so we can satisfy our addiction to color. He also talks about his experience as the Finance Minister of Greece earlier this year.

The ocean is 71 percent of the planet, and blue light can extend down to almost a 1,000 meters. In the middle of our corals, is this green fluorescent fish. This molecule has turned out to be one of the most revolutionary tools in biomedical science.

The Kaupichphys eel is the first green fluorescent vertebrate ever seen. Scientists are trying to find out how prevalent this phenomenon is. The ocean is a massive filter, and as soon as you start going underwater, you're going to lose your colors, and it's going to get dark.

In total -- we just reported this last year -- we found over 200 species of biofluorescent fish. The only time we've ever seen this, it's either on red fluorescent algae or red fluorescent coral. The males give birth, just phenomenal creatures.

The first biofluorescent swellshark was found in a deep, dark canyon off the coast of California. "They're showing these distinct patterns, and there are areas that are fluorescent and Areas that are not fluorescent" The swellsharks have twinkling spots on them that are much brighter than other parts of them.

The first biofluorescent sea turtle was found in the Solomon Islands. The shark sees in the blue-green interface, about 100 times better than we can see in the dark. There are only a few thousand breeding females of the hawksbill turtle left.

CNN's John Defterios explores the depths of the ocean with a team of scientists. The team uses submersibles with special blue lights on the front to illuminate the deep ocean. Defterio: "We're entering a new age of exploration, where we have to take great care"

The court's decision ends a 25-year practice of allowing patents on human genes in the U.S. It clears a significant barrier to biomedical discovery and innovation. It helps to ensure that patients like Abigail, Kathleen and Eileen have access to the tests that they need.

Gene patents typically contain dozens of claims, but the most controversial are to so-called "isolated DNA" Patent holder has right to stop anyone from using that gene in research or clinical testing. Allowing patent holders, often private companies, to lock up stretches of the human genome was harming patients.

The Supreme Court has made clear that certain things are not patent eligible. DNA, the most fundamental structure of life, codes for the production of all of our proteins. DNA is both a product of nature and a law of nature, regardless of whether it's in our bodies or sitting in a test tube.

Patent office had issued thousands of patents on human genes for more than 20 years. Legislation to ban gene patents had been introduced year after year in Congress. Myriad had used its patents to maintain a complete monopoly on BRCA testing in the United States.

Kathleen Maxian's sister developed breast cancer at age 40 and she was tested by Myriad. The test was negative. That meant that Eileen's cancer most likely didn't run in the family. Two years later, Kathleen was diagnosed with advanced-stage ovarian cancer. It turned out that Kathleen's sister was among the 12 percent who received a false-negative test result.

Myriad says isolated BRCA genes were products of nature. Case was randomly assigned to Judge Robert Sweet. In March 2010, Judge Sweet issued his opinion -- 152 pages -- and a complete victory for Myriad. "We could not get over how eloquently he described the science in the case," plaintiff says.

Myriad appealed to the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. The US government submitted a brief on Myriad's side in the district court. The two judges who ruled against Myriad did so for completely different reasons. The court has a reputation for being very, very pro-patent.

The Supreme Court only hears about one percent of the cases that it receives, and it agreed to hear ours. "I want the justices to have the very same reaction that I had when you brought this issue to me seven years ago," Judge Bryson says.

The Supreme Court ruled 9-0 in favor of Myriad's DNA test for BRCA genes. The decision sparked a wave of interest in testing for the gene, which is linked to breast and ovarian cancer. "I started to be one of those people who felt that computers are boring and technical and lonely"

Little girls don't know that they are not supposed to like computers. It's us parents who feel like science is this esoteric, weird discipline. We've built layers and layers of abstraction on top of each other to the point that we no longer have any idea how computers work.

Computer scientists built these amazing, beautiful machines, but they made them very, very foreign to us. We don't know how to speak to the computers anymore without our fancy user interfaces. Bertrand Russell's lifelong quest to find an exact language between English and mathematics found its home inside of a computer.

In Ruby's world, you learn technology through play. She has friends like the Snow Leopard, who is beautiful but doesn't want to play with the other kids. She taught me that you're not supposed to be afraid of the bugs under your bed. And even the biggest of the problems are a group of tiny problems.

"I tell the kids, "Today you have this magic ability to make anything in this room into a computer." And again, the kids go, "Sounds really hard, I don't know the right answer for this." But I tell them, "Don't worry. They've just started to hear about this thing called The Internet of Things" And that's the moment when the kid realizes that the world is definitely not ready yet, that a way of making the world more ready

When she was a girl, she wanted to be a storyteller. programming turned out to be the perfect profession for me. I still create worlds. Imagine a world where the little Ada Lovelaces of tomorrow, who live in a permanent reality of 1s and 0s, they grow up to be very optimistic about technology.

Programming started as a means of self-expression for Melati Wijsen. She wanted to somehow express all of this love, so she built him a website. "I did what every single teenage girl would want to do. Create something out of nothing," she says.

Bye Bye Plastic Bags is a group of children from all over the island of Vanuatu. The children were inspired by the efforts to say no to plastic bags in many other places. The group uses a multi-layered approach, based on an on- and off-line signature petition.

Village is already two-thirds along the way of becoming plastic bag free. First attempts to get the government of Bali on board failed. The village mayor was our first friend and he loved our T-shirts. The Bali airport handles 16 million arrivals and departures a year.

Interactors are the youngest department of Rotary International. They are inspired by Jane Goodall and Ban Ki Moon. They have learned about the importance of commitment and patience. They also learned how to deal with frustrations and how to build relationships.

Isabel and IW went on a hunger strike to raise awareness about plastic bags. The girls wanted to get Bali's governor to meet with them to talk about how to stop plastic bags on the island. Police were called to their home and school on day two of the hunger strike.

Bali's mayor has pledged to make the island plastic bag free by 2018. "We remind him and his team of the promises he has made," says IW. IW: Stop handing out free plastic bags and bring in your own reusable bag is our next message.

Bali's Green School is built out of bamboo and teaches children to be leaders of today. The school has been working for three years to say no to plastic bags on the island. "We still have a lot of work to do, but know that we still not stop until the first question asked when arriving at the Bali airports is "Do you have nay plastic bags to declare?"

Pleurobot is a robot designed to closely mimic a salamander species called Pleurodeles waltl. The robot can walk, and as you'll see later, it can also swim. Biorobotics is a field of research in robotics where people want to take inspiration from animals.

Pleurobot is a robot that simulates the movement of a salamander. The amphibian is a key animal from an evolutionary point of view. It makes a wonderful link between swimming, as you find it in eels or fish, and quadruped locomotion.

The robot is able to switch between walking, trotting and flapping its wings. It was created by a team of researchers at the University of Jena in Germany. The robot is now being used to train other robots to do the same.

The robot can mimic the movements of a real-life salamander. It can also be used to swim in the water. The robot is controlled by a computer program on the inside of the robot. It is not yet clear if the robot will be used in the real world.

Cheetah-Cub can control speed, heading and type of gait by stimulating the spinal cord. The robot can also do turning by stimulating more one side of the cord than the other. Scientists studied cat biomechanics to see how much the morphology helps locomotion.

The Cheetah-Cub robot is a toy, but it was really used as a scientific tool to investigate these properties of the legs of the cat. The robot is very compliant, very lightweight, and also very elastic, so you can easily press it down and it will not break.

The spinal cord is the key controller for locomotion in humans. If it is damaged, a person can become paraplegic or tetraplegic. This is why it is important to understand how the spinal cord works. It is also important to know how it communicates with the rest of the body.

In the spinal cord you find reflexes that create a sensorimotor coordination loop. The ability to create and sustain economic growth is the defining challenge of our time. In these countries, it is essential that they grow at a minimum of seven percent a year.

CNN's John Defterios speaks to a group of young people about the future of the world. He says they are concerned about the impact of economic growth on the environment. Defterio: "We're going to have to pursue it with a better form of economic stance"

capitalism is set on the basis of an individual utility maximizer, he says. But in practical experience, capitalism is much more of a spectrum, he adds. U.S. should focus on purer forms of capitalism, particularly those embodied by the United States, he argues.

Dambisa: In order to create sustainable, long-term economic growth, we're going to have to be more broad-minded about what might work. "We have to recognize that ideology is the enemy of growth," says Dambisa.

"I think it is absolutely the case that traditional models of economic growth are not working the way we would like them to," he says. "There is not a fundamental agreement between what the developed world wants and what the emerging world wants," he adds.

Dambisa: "Developed countries have a real, important responsibility" "They continue to underperform and to see an erosion in the three key drivers of economic growth" "It cannot be a situation where we start ascribing policies to the emerging markets"

Andrés Navarrette traveled to the Amazon to see the legendary "warm stream of the Amazon" The river is protected by a powerful shaman and can only be swum in after heavy rain. The average temperatures in the river are 86 degrees C. The river flows hot and fast.

The water is clean and had a pleasant taste, which is a little weird for geothermal systems. The locals had always known about this place, and that I was by no means the first outsider to see it. They would go into towns and ask the Inca, "Where's another civilization we can conquer?"

The Inca, out of vengeance, told them, "Go to the Amazon. You'll find all the gold you want there" The indigenous name of the river, Shanay-timpishka, "boiled with the heat of the sun" It actually took me three years to get that footage.

The river flows wider than a two-lane road along most of its path. The Spanish set off into the jungle, but the few that return come back with stories of powerful shamans. There are thermal pools larger than this TED stage, and that waterfall that you see there is six meters tall.

The boiling river exists independent of volcanism, according to scientists. Animals fall in and lose power, losing power, until they get to a point where hot water goes into their mouths and they cook from the inside out. They're trying to swim out, but their meat is cooking on the bone because it's so hot.

The boiling river is over 700 kilometers away from the nearest volcanic center. The waters could be coming from as far away as glaciers in the Andes. Researchers genetically sequenced the extremophile lifeforms living in and around the river. They have found new lifeforms, unique species living in the boiling river.

The Peruvian government says the land is just another stretch of unprotected land ready for development. "We live in an incredible world. We live in a world where shamans still sing to the spirits of the jungle, where rivers do boil and where legends do come to life"

The first case of Ebola in Sierra Leone was reported on May 23. The virus has since spread to other parts of the country. The U.S. government has sent a team to Sierra Leone to help with the outbreak. The team is working with the local government to find a way to stop the spread.

The genome of a virus is the blueprint. It says everything that makes up us, and it tells us so much information. We could see that as the virus was moving between humans, it was mutating. The diagnostics, the vaccines, the therapies that we're using, are all based on that genome sequence.

The Lassa virus is a lot like Ebola. It can cause a severe fever and can often be fatal. The problem is that the data that all of us are using, Googling on the web is just too limited to do what we need to do.

Many health-care workers died while the world waited and while we all worked, quietly and separately. Ebola on one person's doorstep could soon be on ours. We're all in this fight together. We all have to demand that of ourselves and others.

This is the first outbreak in West Africa, near the border of Sierra Leone and Liberia. The next time this happens, it could happen in a city of millions. This experience shows us, that we have the technology to win this thing. But we can only do it if we do it together.

Matthew Williams was one of over 6,500 athletes with intellectual disabilities from 165 countries who competed in LA. He says Special Olympics transforms the self-identity of athletes and the perceptions of everyone watching. "This movement has changed my life and those of so many others"

Special Olympics gives people with intellectual disabilities the chance to be part of a team and compete in sports. It also gives them a chance to improve their physical and mental health. The U.S. has the largest number of Special Olympics athletes in the world, with more than 100,000 members.

Special Olympics is transforming more than just the athlete in their sport. The day before our game, the Nigerian basketball team went to the World Games Healthy Athlete screening. They were more excited, happy and confident, because their coach could vocally communicate with them.

The world does not see all people with disabilities as champions. The next time you see someone with a disability, tell them how much it hurts. The world is a better place because of the Special Olympics, says Jackie. "I am no longer hidden, I am a champion," he says.

Global marine life has been slashed in half in the last 40 years. Over 90 percent of our largest predatory species have disappeared since the 1950s. Over 2.6 billion people depend on it every single day. We have to stop plundering our oceans the way we have.

The World Health Organization recently reported that 800 million people are suffering from malnutrition and food shortage. The solution lies in aquaculture -- the farming of fish, plants like seaweed, shellfish and crustaceans. As the great ocean hero Jacques Cousteau once said, "We must start using the ocean as farmers instead of hunters"

Fish is the last food that we hunt. Scientists have a lot of theories about why this is, but almost all of them involve nutrition. Fish is healthy, it prevents heart disease, it provides key amino acids and key fatty acids like Omega-3s. There's 500 species of fish being farmed currently.

In the last 50 years, global meat consumption has more than quadrupled. In the next 35 years, we are going to need an additional 85 million tons to meet demand. Every single fishing vessel combined, small and large, produces about 65 million tons of wild-caught seafood.

A cow needs to eat eight to nine pounds of feed and drink almost 8,000 liters of water to create just one pound of meat. Experts agree that it's impossible to farm cows for every inhabitant on this planet. And we can't keep cutting down rain forests for it.

Fish are the most resource-efficient animal protein available to humankind, aside from insects. Sixty-five percent of these fisheries, globally, are badly managed. By 2050, we are going to need at least 70 percent more protein than what is available today.

Fish farming is by far the best animal farming available to humankind. But it's had a really bad reputation. New technologies means that we can now produce a feed that's perfectly natural. Microbes, for example, can be a perfect alternative for high-grade fish meal -- at scale.

The UN predicts the world's population will reach 11 billion by the end of the century. Insects are the perfect recycling because they're grown on food waste. Microbes and insects are actually net water producers. This revolution is starting as we speak, it just needs scale.

We need to have a meal that we can trust, live long lives. Even in the poorest countries, it's not just about money. The day will come where people will realize -- no, demand -- farmed fish on their plate that's farmed well.

LZ Granderson says the use of race in medicine is a problem. He says it's a social construct, not a medical one. Granderson: We need to stop using race as a barometer of health and well-being. We need more information about the source of our food, he says.

Doctors use race as a convenient proxy for more important factors, like muscle mass, enzyme level. Doctors routinely interpret GFR, this important indicator of kidney function, by race. The exact same creatinine level automatically produces a different GFR estimate depending on whether or not the patient is African-American.

Race can't substitute for clinical measures without sacrificing patient well-being. Race medicine also leaves patients of color especially vulnerable to harmful biases and stereotypes. Black and Latino patients are twice as likely to receive no pain medication as whites. The Food and Drug Administration has even approved a race-specific medicine.

Dr. Samuel Cartwright argued in the 1850s that slavery was beneficial for black people for medical reasons. Cartwright helped to perfect a medical device for measuring breathing called the spirometer to show the presumed deficiency in black people's lungs. Today, doctors still uphold Cartwright's claim the black people as a race have lower lung capacity than white people.

Roxanne Jones: It's time to stop using race as a way to solve social problems. She says the real problem is that we don't know how to solve it. Jones: We need to find out how to use race to improve the lives of others.

Neurosurgeon: "With a little bit of help, the brain is able to help itself" "We wanted to grow cells from these pieces of tissue" "It's not an easy task. Growing cells from a piece of tissue is a bit the same as growing very small children out from their family"

The adult brain has stem cells, but they're very rare and they're located in deep and small niches in the depths of the brain. Regular stem cells are very active cells. These blue and red cells are called doublecortin-positive cells. All of you have them in your brain.

The cells represent four percent of your cortical brain cells. They have a very important role during the development stage. We think that they may participate in brain repair because we find them in higher concentration close to brain lesions. We call these autologous grafts -- autografts.

In the first-case scenario, we re-implanted the cells in the normal brain and what we saw is that they completely disappeared after a few weeks, as if they were taken from the brain, they go back home, the space is already busy, they are not needed there, so they disappear. In the second case, we performed the lesion, and in this case, the cells remained and they became mature neurons.

"We know that we can apply them in other neuropathological models, like Parkinson's" "It takes a long time and a lot of patience and almost a professional team to do it" "I hope that one day we'll be able to use them in humans" "We're not there yet"

Jocelyne Bremner is a doctor who is trying to improve a neurological function through surgical strategies. She says it takes a long time to select the patients, do the treatment and evaluate if it's useful to do this kind of treatment. BremNER: Imagine worldwide how a trove of previously unknown texts could radically transform our knowledge of the past.

The book was written in the 13th century, but was lost during the Second World War. It is the only surviving copy of a book of the same name. The book is called "The Art of Reading" and is written in Latin. It was written by a group of men who wanted to learn more about the art of reading.

The Codex Vercellensis is the oldest translation of the Gospels into Latin. Using infrared, we've been able to read even the darkest corners of the Dead Sea Scrolls. This is the closest we can come to the Bible at the time of the foundation of Christendom under Emperor Constantine.

The Lazarus Project is a not-for-profit initiative to bring multispectral imaging to individual researchers and smaller institutions. The technology is expensive and very rare, and the imaging and image processing skills are esoteric. Over the past five years, our team of imaging scientists, scholars and students has travelled to seven different countries.

Multispectral light can take us back to the first stuttering moments of an object's creation. Through this lens, we witness the mistakes, the changes of mind, the naïvetés. Textual science is a marriage of the traditional skills of a literary scholar with new techniques.

Mali's high humidity is putting manuscripts that could change the history of world culture in jeopardy. The manuscripts are hidden in Bamako, the capital of Mali, moldering in the high humidity. What was rescued by ruse is now once again in jeopardy, this time by climate.

"I'm not a man. And I shouldn't have to use the men's room" "There's no legal or ethical way to enforce laws like these anyway" "They don't make anyone safer. But they do for sure make the world more dangerous"

Trans people, especially trans and gender-nonconforming youth face additional challenges when accessing pools and gyms. "We need to get honest and quit calling them public places. And we all need a safe place to pee," she says. "If I could change the world tomorrow, the very first thing I would do is create single stall bathrooms"

A four-year-old girl was bullied for using the wrong bathroom at her preschool. "I wanted to tell her that it was all going to get better when she got older, but I couldn't," says the girl's mother. "She doesn't need to know that, I figure. She doesn't want to know"

We can't change the world overnight for our children, but we can give them a safe and private place to escape that world. So let's just build some single stall, gender-neutral bathrooms with a little bench for getting changed into your gym clothes.

CNN's John Sutter has been photographing the world's oceans for more than a decade. Sutter: "I've visited hundreds of marine locations, but there are a handful of seascapes that have touched me incredibly deeply" "You can't love something and become a champion for it if you don't know it exists," Sutter says.

Every June and July, huge numbers of sardines travel north to the Maldives. In hot pursuit are hoards of hungry and agile predators. They drive and trap the fish upward against the ocean surface, then they rush in to dine.

Manta rays earn the Maldivian economy in excess of 8 million dollars every single year. Fishermen once hunted these manta rays to make traditional drums from their skins. The experience of diving amongst such masses of hundreds of rays is truly unforgettable.

The San Ignacio Lagoon is a critical calving ground for gray whales. Decades of overfishing had brought them close to collapse. Local fisherman convinced the authorities to proclaim their waters a marine reserve. In 2005, after only a single decade of protection, scientists measured the largest recovery of fish ever recorded.

Photographer Paul Barnwell has been documenting the world's oceans for 40 years. Barnwell says he wants to focus on nature's resilience in the face of 7.3 billion people. He says he always operates on the assumption that the next great picture is right around the corner.

LZ Granderson says he wants to teach people how to talk to each other. He says it's important to be able to say what you want to say without saying it. Granderson: "There is no reason to be afraid to talk about anything"

How many of you know at least one person that you avoid because you just don't want to talk to them? There is no reason why most of your interactions can't be like that. I have 10 basic rules. If you just choose one of them, you'll already enjoy better conversations.
M. Scott Peck: "Everyone you will ever meet knows something that you don't" Start your questions with who, what, when, where, why or how, he says. Use open-ended questions, like "Were you angry?"

CNN.com's John Sutter talks about the importance of listening to your guests on the radio. Sutter: "Stories and ideas are going to come to you. You need to let them come and let them go" "Let them describe it. They're the ones that know," Sutter says.

Don't equate your experience with theirs. Talk should not be cheap. People don't care about the years, the names, the dates, all those details that you're struggling to come up with in your mind. What they care about is you.

Buddha said, "If your mouth is open, you're not learning" Calvin Coolidge: "No man ever listened his way out of a job" The average person talks at about 225 word per minute, but we can listen at up to 500 words per minute.

"I keep my mouth shut as often as I possibly can, and I'm always prepared to be amazed" "We're less likely to compromise, which means we're not listening to each other" "You have to listen to one another" "Don't be afraid to ask questions"

Data science is the only way to understand interactions between drugs and glucose, says Dr. Richard Schafer. Schafer: "I'm an informatics and data science guy and really, in my opinion, the only hope is to leverage lots of data"

Russian-born Dr. Russ Borsuk says he was impressed by a student's work on a pillbox. But he says it's not publishable because it doesn't have "standard-of-proof evidence" He says the student found two drugs that had similar glucose-changing signals. The drugs are Paxil and pravastatin.

Stanford researchers found 10 patients on two drugs who had problems with their glucose. Eight out of the 10 had a bump in their glucose when they got the second P. glucose went up 20 milligrams per deciliter. If it gets up to 120, 125, your doctor begins to think about a potential diagnosis of diabetes.

Researchers found that patients getting two drugs were having their glucose bump somewhat significantly. When we looked at the glucose of diabetics, it was going up 60 milligrams per deciliter, not just 20. This was a big deal, and we said "We've got to publish this"

CNN's Jim Boulden asked Google to search for side effects of drugs. He says the results showed that when the drugs were given to mice, their glucose levels went up. Bouldens: "It's kind of a bummer that we can't use that information"

Researchers looked at what people search for when they have hyperglycemia. They found that if they search for "paroxetine" or "pravastatin," the rate goes up. They also found that when they searched for "urinating a lot," the rates went up.

The FDA is using social media to look for side effects of drugs. The aim is to find out if a drug is more effective or less effective when taken with another drug. The data will be used to create a more accurate picture of drug interactions.

The two drugs actually caused problems. They could throw somebody into diabetes who would otherwise not be in diabetes. We could have found new effects of drugs that neither of them has alone, but together, instead of causing a side effect, could be a new and novel treatment for diseases that don't have treatments.

Siyanda Mohutsiwa is a 22-year-old Pan-Africanist. His parents are from two different African countries. He started the hashtag #ifAfricawasabar in July. He says it was a chance for people to share their Africanness.

The author was born in South Africa and raised in the U.S. She moved back to South Africa when she was 14. She says she is still trying to understand her heritage and her place in the world. "I feel like I'm in a strange place right now," she says. "It's very strange."

The year was 2011 and all over southern Africa and the whole continent, affordable data packages for smartphones and Internet surfing became much easier to get. So this meant that if you were a teenage girl in Botswana and you wanted to have fun on the Internet, you had to tweet in English.

CNN's John Defterios writes about the role of African nations in the world. He says the continent is at the center of the world's problems. He asks: Why aren't we doing a better job of sharing the successes and failures of other countries?

"I think that the biggest way for Africa to share its successes is to foster something I like to call social Pan-Africanism" "My dream is that young Africans stop allowing borders and circumstance to suffocate our innovation" "In Africa, we say, "If you want to go fast, you go alone, but if you wants to go far, you going together" "I believe that social Pan - Africanism is how we can go far together"

The hashtag #ifafricawasabar garnered around 60,000 tweets, lit up the continent and made its way to publications all over the world. For the first time ever, African pain and African aspiration has the ability to be witnessed by those who can empathize with it the most: other Africans.

CNN's Tom Charity says he's in the Edison camp, even if people don't always like him. Charity: Tesla has kind of this mind grab these days, but who actually changed the world? Charity: I know people who work for Google and they have their own small data center at home.

Linux founder says he's trying to dial it down a bit. "I think I'm more of an Edison than a Tesla," he says. "Without doing the whole open source and really letting go thing, Linux would never have been what it is"

LZ Granderson: Code either works or it doesn't. LZ: It's not up to you to make the decision. He says there are other ways to make a difference. "It's not just black and white," LZ says. "There's more to it"

Linus Torvalds: "I work alone in my house, often in my bathrobe" "I did not start Linux as a collaborative project. I started it as one in a series of many projects I had done at the time for myself" "There was no open source on my radar at all"

Lukas Lukas: "I made it publicly available, and it wasn't even open source at that point" "I was actually worried about the whole commercial interests coming in," Lukas says. "Your software is in every single one of them," he adds.

LT: "I'm actually not a people person. I don't really love other people -- I love computers, I love interacting with other people on email, because it kind of gives you that buffer" "The big point for me was not being alone and having 10, maybe 100 people being involved"

The Linux kernel is the world's largest operating system. It's used by more than 100 million computers worldwide. The Linux kernel was created in 1999. It was designed to be used in a variety of ways, not just as a source of code.

Linux and Git arose almost as an unintended consequence of your desire not to have to work with too many people. LT: Git is my second big project, which was only created for me to maintain my first big project. I don't code for fun, but I want to code for something meaningful.

The author's sister used to prepare him for family meetings before they took place. "I was not -- I was a geek. I was into computers," he says. "My sister said that my biggest exceptional quality was that I would not let go. That's about being stubborn"

LT: I'm not a people person; it's not something I'm particularly proud of, but it's part of me. The whole point of Silicon Valley is that people jump between jobs to kind of mix up the pot. That's not the kind of person I am.

I was afraid of commercial people taking advantage of your work, but it turned out to be lovely, lovely people. They did all the things that I was not at all interested in doing, and they had completely different goals. But because it was open source they could do it, and it actually works really beautifully together.

The code is like a calming color, it's not something that really stimulates you. The most interesting part to me is the last if statement. It's trying to remove an existing entry from a list. There's a difference between if it's the first entry or whether it's an entry in the middle.

Lighting in practice is placing lights inside this three-dimensional world. We can make a world with monsters, with robots that fall in love, we can even make pigs fly. While this is an incredible thing, this untethered artistic freedom can create chaos.

The film uses science and the world we know as a backbone, to ground ourselves in something relatable and recognizable. Finding Nemo is an excellent example of this. A major portion of the movie takes place underwater. We coded up a light that mimics this physics, and then what happens with the color.

"WALL-E" is about a young boy who finds beauty in the simplest things. The film uses science to create something wonderful. "We are not beholden to it. We use story and artistic touch to get us to a place of wonder," says director.

WALL-E doesn't have a face or traditional dialogue, for that matter. The animators were heavily dependent on the binoculars to sell his acting and emotions. The triple lenses inside his binoculared were a mess of reflections. We tried turning them down, blocking them, nothing was working.

"WALL-E" was the first computer animation any of us had ever seen. In the movie towards the end, Wall-E loses his personality, essentially going dead. "We bring that light back to bring the aperture blades back, and he returns to that sweet, soulful robot"

The director had a vision for this scene based on some wonderful footage of jellyfish in the South Pacific. The reviews with the director turned from the normal look-and-feel conversation into more and more questions about numbers and percentages. But even through all the frustrations, I still believed it could be beautiful.

"This is the moment that I live for in lighting. The moment where it all comes together and we get a world that we can believe in" "It's this interweaving of art and science that elevates the world to a place of wonder, a place where the things you imagine can become real"

Cancer affects all of us -- especially the highly invasive and drug-resistant ones. The key is a set of molecules known as siRNA. Each siRNA molecule can turn off a specific gene inside the cell. But if it gets exposed to the enzymes that reside in our bloodstream, it degrades.

The nanoparticle has to be about one one-hundredth the size of a human hair. It has to get through the bloodstream, penetrate the tumor tissue and be tiny enough to be taken up inside the cancer cell. Engineering at the molecular level can provide exciting new ways to fight the most aggressive forms of cancer.

The siRNA is deployed first. It acts for hours, giving enough time to silence and block those survival genes. Then, the chemotherapy drug comes out of the core and destroys the tumor cell cleanly and efficiently. With sufficient gene blockers, we can address many different kinds of mutations.

Nanostructure particles have been tested in a highly aggressive form of triple-negative breast cancer. The tumors stopped growing, decreased in size and were eliminated in some cases. What's great about this approach is that it can be personalized.

"It's not just about building really elegant science. It's about understanding the power of engineering on the scale of molecules" "We can think of these very aggressive forms of cancer as kind of supervillains in a comic book. They're clever, they're adaptable and they're very good at staying alive"

Shapiro: People returning to work after a career break: I call them relaunchers. He says people's view of you is frozen in time. Shapiro: "You are going to have a lot of conversations that don't go anywhere"

It's a great confidence boost to be back in touch with these people and hear their interest in returning to work. Closely related are career transitioners of all kinds: veterans, military spouses, retirees and repatriating expats. For those of us who took career breaks for childcare reasons, we have fewer or no maternity leaves.

Employers are worried that relaunchers are technologically obsolete. Relaunchers need to come to the table with a working knowledge of office management software. It's the relauncher's responsibility to demonstrate to the employer where they can add the most value.

In 2010, I started noticing the use of a short-term paid work opportunity as a way for professionals to return to work. Goldman Sachs and Sara Lee started corporate reentry internship programs. These internships are paid, and the people who move on to permanent roles are commanding competitive salaries. The internship allows the employer to base their hiring decision on an actual work sample.

Tracy Shapiro was a relauncher when she decided to return to work. She got a temp job in a finance department, but the company told her there was a possibility it could turn into something more. She ended up blowing away all of their expectations, and the company made her a permanent offer.

Successful relaunchers are everywhere and in every field. Don't hesitate to suggest an internship or an internship-like arrangement to an employer that does not have a formal reentry internship program. Be their first success story, and you can be the example for more relauncher to come.

Norwegian author says exploration and exploitation is about coming up with what's new. He says exploration is risky, but exploitation is taking the knowledge we have and making good, better products. "It's about making our trains run on time," he says.

Only about two percent of companies are able to effectively explore and exploit at the same time, he says. "The real, real solution to quality growth is figuring out the balance between two activities: exploration and exploitation," he adds. "Doing both well as the. same time is art -- pushing both exploration and. exploitation"

There are so many traps that keep us where we are, he says. We discover something, but we don't have the patience or persistence to get at it and make it work. Another trap is the success trap. Both are necessary, but it can be too much of a good thing.

Firm's CEO: "Success is a lousy teacher. It seduces us into thinking we cannot fail" "We are like that, too. When we know something well, it's difficult to change," he says. "I see other companies that say, "I'll win the next innovation cycle, whatever it takes"

"I don't think it's possible for any of us to be able to balance the two," he says. "I think the mark of a good company is to be open to being challenged," he adds. "And I think that's what we need to do here"

The beauty of exploration is in the balance, says the CEO of French biotech company Facit. Facit went from maximum revenue to zero in just six months. The company's engineers bought cheap, small electronic calculators in Japan to double-check their calculators. But exploration can go wild, too, says CEO.

How would we survive on a planet like Mars? How would we ship supplies from Earth? How do we grow things like food that grew up on Earth like us? Will we be able to survive in space? How will we find our way back to Earth?

The longest continuous amount of time that any human has spent in space is in the vicinity of 12 to 14 months. Using the tools of synthetic biology, we can now edit the genes of nearly any organism, microscopic or not. synthetic biology will be a means for us to engineer not only our food, our fuel and our environment.

GMOs can be used to make plants that can survive in harsh conditions. They can also be used for medicine and fuel, as well as food and water. The technology could be used on Mars, but it would require huge amounts of new land.

Deinococcus radiodurans is known to be able to withstand cold, dehydration, vacuum, acid, and, most notably, radiation. While its radiation tolerance mechanisms are known, we have yet to adapt the relevant genes to mammals. Using the tools of synthetic biology, we can harness the bacterium's ability to thrive under otherwise lethal doses of radiation.

Humanity has the capacity to decide for ourselves our own genetic destiny. The answers will lie in our choice to use or abandon the technology that we have gleaned from life. Space is cold, brutal and unforgiving. Our path to the stars will be rife with trials that will bring us to question who we are.

CNN's John Defterios is a self-confessed procrastinator. He started playing Nintendo games at 5am and would not stop until he had mastered them. This served him well in college, because he finished his senior thesis four months before the deadline. He was proud of that, until a few years ago.

People who rush in and do everything early are rated as less creative than people who procrastinate moderately. The people who race in are in such a frenzy that they don't have original thoughts either. Maybe original people just have bad work habits. Maybe procrastinating does not cause creativity.

Procrastination gives you time to consider divergent ideas, to think in nonlinear ways, to make unexpected leaps. The moderate procrastinators are 16 percent more creative than the other two groups. As Aaron Sorkin put it, "You call it procrastinating. I call it thinking"

The night before the biggest speech of his life, the March on Washington, Martin Luther King, Jr. was up past 3am rewriting his speech. By delaying the task of finalizing the speech until the very last minute, he left himself open to the widest range of possible ideas.

First movers had a failure rate of 47 percent, compared with only 8 percent for the improvers. Facebook waited to build a social network until after Myspace and Friendster. It's much easier to improve on somebody else's idea than to create something new from scratch.

Firefox and Chrome users significantly outperform Internet Explorer and Safari users. The four browser groups on average have similar typing speed and they also have similar levels of computer knowledge. The key to being original is just a simple thing of avoiding the leap from step three to step four.

If you use Internet Explorer or Safari, those came preinstalled on your computer, and you accepted the default option that was handed to you. If you wanted Firefox or Chrome, you had to doubt the default and ask, is there a different option out there, and then be a little resourceful.

Bach, Beethoven, Mozart had to generate hundreds and hundreds of compositions to come up with a much smaller number of masterpieces. Originals are not that different from the rest of us. They feel fear and doubt. They procrastinate. They have bad ideas.

Mars is less than half the size of the Earth, but the surface area that you can stand on is equivalent to the surface of Earth. The atmosphere on Mars is really thin -- 100 times thinner than on Earth -- and it's not breathable. The average temperature is minus 81 degrees, although there is quite a range of temperature.

Humans could reach Mars in 240 days, if they launch on a specific day. The biggest rocket we have now is only half big enough to get there. Only about a third of the missions to Mars have been successful. Some think if we got there by 2050, that'd be a pretty good achievement.

CNN's John Sutter asks: Can Elon Musk get us to Mars by 2027? Sutter: "I don't think they're going to bother in 2035, because we will already be there" "I think it's a pretty good bet," Sutter says. "I'm not saying it's going to happen, but I think it will"

NASA has taken a huge responsibility in figuring out how we can live on Mars. Water is the basis of all life as we know it, and it's far too heavy for us to carry water from the Earth to Mars. The soil alone on Mars contains up to 60 percent water.

Orbiters tell us that there are huge amounts of underground water on Mars as well as glaciers. If only the water ice at the poles on Mars melted, most of the planet would be under 30 feet of water. Moxie is a reverse fuel cell that sucks in the Martian atmosphere and pumps out oxygen.

The next big rover that NASA sends to Mars in 2020 will be able to produce enough oxygen to keep one person alive indefinitely. The soil on Mars, by and large, is perfect for making bricks. Most of our food will arrive from Earth, and it will be dried.

On Mars there's hardly any atmospheric pressure. Dava Newman, a scientist at MIT, has created a sleek space suit. It will keep us together, block radiation and keep us warm. Food, shelter, clothing, water, oxygen ... we can do this.

It won't take long for the temperature on Mars to start rising, probably less than 20 years. Eventually, Mars will be made to feel like British Columbia. We'll still be left with the complicated problem of making the atmosphere breathable. But humans are amazingly smart and incredibly adaptable.

We could do a lot of good with the money it will take to establish a thriving colony on Mars. There will be software companies, there will be hotels and bars. "Where were The New Yorker's fabled copy editors?" a reader wrote. "There's no excuse for this mistake," says a copy editor. "No-nothingism" might be American vernacular for "nihilism," he says.

The editor never sells out the writer, never goes public about bad jokes that had to be cut. A great editor saves a writer from her excesses. Copy editors, too, have a code; we don't advertise our oversights. "Sandy" sometimes writes a sentence that gives a copy editor pause.

Sandy: "Technically, the "like" should be an "as," but it sounds ridiculous" "I decided that the hurricane conferred poetic justice on Sandy and let the sentence stand," he says. "We work at the level of the sentence, maybe the paragraph, the words, the punctuation"

The New Yorker's style for "microphone" in its abbreviated form is "mike" The music industry spells it "mic" because that's how it's spelled on the equipment. "Their" is plural and "everyone," its antecedent, is singular.

Every publication has a house style. The New Yorker's is particularly distinctive. We still spell "teen-ager" with a hyphen, as if that word had just been coined. The editor pointed out that we could not have "present" and "presence" in the same sentence.
