In India, only 12 percent of girls and women have access to hygienic ways of managing their periods. Menstrual hygiene is a very important risk factor for reproductive tract infections. Even buying a sanitary napkin is considered shameful in Garhwa, Jharkhand.

The author's period brought in the social restrictions that are imposed upon our girls and women when they're on their periods. The author was not allowed to touch or eat pickles. She had to wash her bed sheet after every period, even if it was not stained.

About 85 percent of girls and women in India would follow one or more restrictive customs on their periods every month. They're not allowed to take baths during periods, and in some households they are even secluded from other family members. Can you imagine what this does to the self-esteem and self-confidence of a young girl? The psychological trauma that this inflicts.

Researchers found that many parents and teachers wanted to educate girls about periods before they have started getting their menstrual cycle. Since it is a taboo, they feel inhibition and shameful in talking about it. Girls nowadays get their periods in classes 6 and 7, but our educational curriculum teaches them about periods only in standard 8 and 9.

"Menstrupedia Comic" aims to educate girls about menstruation in a fun and engaging way. The cartoon characters represent girls in their different phases of puberty. Parents and teachers were comfortable in talking about periods to young girls using the book, and sometimes even boys were interested.

15 schools in different parts of India have made this book a part of their school curriculum to teach girls about menstruation. So far, more than 4,000 girls have been educated by using the book in India. Research shows that three out of every 10 girls are not aware of menstruation at the time of their first periods.

The library of Earth is an old one. Most pages are destroyed soon after being written. Some pages are overwritten, creating difficult-to-decipher palimpsests of long-gone landscapes. Unlike the Moon -- our dead, rocky companion -- the Earth is alive.

The Earth's volumes remained inscrutable to humans until recently. The answer relies on a formula that all paleontologists use. If you want to find dinosaurs like I do, find the rocks of Mesozoic and go there. You can only make a fossil in a sedimentary rock, a rock made by sand and mud.

Every pebble that you see on the ground there is a piece of dinosaur bone. When you go to a place that's relatively unexplored, you have a much better chance of finding something that's new to science. The question is: Will you find something that is scientifically significant?

Dreadnoughtus schrani was 85 feet from snout to tail. It stood two-and-a-half stories at the shoulder, and weighed 65 tons. That's the mass of eight or nine T. rex. The bison in Yellowstone injure far more people than do the grizzly bears.

Dreadnoughtus was a model of efficiency. It could clear out a huge envelope of vegetation, taking in tens of thousands of calories while expending very few. It evolved a bulldog-like wide-gait stance, giving them immense stability. The penalty for falling over is death.

An asteroid hits the Earth and wipes out the dinosaurs. The continents drifted. The mammals rose. And then, in East Africa, an unpromising species of ape evolved the odd trick of sentient thought. With seven billion peripatetic Homo sapiens on the planet, it was perhaps inevitable that one of them would eventually trod on the grave of the magnificent titan.

The dinosaurs were wiped out between 235 and 66 million years ago. The bones of Dreadnoughtus lay underground for 77 million years. The tiniest perturbation of that asteroid far from Earth would have caused it to miss our planet by a wide margin.

Dinosaurs died in the world's fifth mass extinction, snuffed out in a cosmic accident through no fault of their own. The nature of the fossil record tells us that our place on this planet is both precarious and potentially fleeting. Why study the ancient past? Because it gives us perspective and humility.

People in emerging markets that may seem risky and unpredictable on the surface are actually willing and have the capacity to repay. Our credit scores have helped us deliver over 200,000 loans in Kenya in just the past year. With something as simple as a credit score, we're giving people the power to build their own futures.

The number of atoms, the file that I will save in my thumb drive to assemble a little baby, will actually fill an entire Titanic of thumb drives -- multiplied 2,000 times. This is the biggest amount of information that exists. But nature, fortunately, is much smarter than a young man, and in four billion years, managed to pack this information in a small crystal.

It took more than 40 years to finally poke inside a human cell, take out this crystal, unroll it, and read it for the first time. The code comes out to be a fairly simple alphabet, four letters: A, T, C and G. To build a human, you need three billion of them.

A 3D printer needs three elements: a bit of information, some raw material, some energy. To you it sounds like mute letters, but this sequence gives the color of the eyes. We have no cure for it, and it's just two letters of difference from what we are.

My mom takes three elements: a bit of information, which is between my father and my mom in this case, raw elements and energy in the same media, that is food, and after several months, produces me.

Lying is a typical part of development for children. Some children begin to tell lies as young as two years of age. Good lying requires two key ingredients: theory of mind and self-control. Lying is the basis of lying because I know you don't know what I know.

Children who have more advanced mind-reading and self-control abilities tell lies earlier and are more sophisticated liars, researchers say. Deficits in these abilities are associated with serious developmental problems, such as ADHD and autism. "If you discover your two-year-old is telling his or her first lie, instead of being alarmed, you should celebrate"

Kang Lee: If you guess randomly, there's a 50 percent chance you're going to get it right. If your accuracy is around 50 percent, it means you are a terrible detector of children's lies. Kang Lee: Let's start with undergrads and law school students, who typically have limited experience with children.

Social workers and child-protection lawyers can't detect children's lies. Judges, customs officers and police officers, who deal with liars on a daily basis, can't. Their performance is around chance. What about parents? Can parents detect other children's lying? No, they cannot.

Under our facial skin, there's a rich network of blood vessels. When we experience different emotions, our facial blood flow changes subtly. These changes are regulated by the autonomic system that is beyond our conscious control. By looking at facial blood. flow changes, we can reveal people's hidden emotions.

Technology can reveal the hidden emotions associated with lying. It can do so noninvasively, remotely, inexpensively, with an accuracy at about 85 percent. The technology can be used in education, health care, and other fields, the researchers say.

Transdermal optical imaging technology is at a very early stage of development. It could be used to detect politicians' heart rate, mood and stress. The technology could also be used in dating to determine whether a woman likes you or she is just trying to be nice to you.

Pancreatic cancer is one of the most painful tumor types. The hard-to-reach location prevents the doctor from surgically removing it. chemotherapy is the only option for the pancreatic cancer patient. The drugs will reach healthy organs, resulting in high toxic effect for the patients overall.

The drug is embedded into devices that look like this one. They are flexible enough that they can be folded to fit into the catheter, so the doctor can implant it directly on top of the tumor with minimally invasive surgery. They will actually physically prevent the tumor from entering other organs, controlling the metastasis.

Pancreatic cancer is the third cause of cancer deaths. Only eight percent of the patients will survive beyond five years. By rethinking the way we deliver the drug, we are also opening the door to finding new innovative solutions for almost all other impossible problems in pancreatic cancer patients.

About 20 percent of people wind up with chronic, long-term PTSD. The most vulnerable are people who were abused as children, who suffered trauma as children. If you served in Vietnam and your brother is schizophrenic, you're more likely to get PTSD from Vietnam.

Iraq and Afghanistan have produced, thank God, a casualty rate about one third of what it was in Vietnam. As a result, the casualty rates have gone down. But they've also produced three times the disability rates. Around half of our military has filed for some kind of PTSD compensation from the government.

Vets are slightly less likely to commit suicide later if they deploy to Iraq or Afghanistan, a study found. But if you come back to an alienating, modern society, you might remain traumatized your entire life. Modern society has probably produced the highest rates of suicide and depression and anxiety and loneliness and child abuse ever in human history.

Around 50 percent of veterans have filed for PTSD compensation. The highest rates of depression were urban women in North America. The wealthiest group in the U.S. was also the wealthiest group. The military is trying to find out what is causing these problems.

The Israeli military has a PTSD rate of around one percent. When soldiers come back from the front line, they're not going from a military environment to a civilian environment. They're coming back to a community where everyone understands about the military. It's as if they're all in one big tribe.

After 9/11, the murder rate in New York City went down by 40 percent. Even combat veterans of previous wars who suffered from PTSD said that their symptoms went down. The reason is that if you traumatize an entire society, we don't fall apart and turn on one another.

The gap between rich and poor is the biggest it's ever been. Veterans have gone away and are coming back and seeing their own country with fresh eyes. It's time for this country to unite, if only to help the men and women who fought to protect us.

The word introspection does not appear a single time in the books we want to analyze. The distance between any two words is indicative of how closely related they are. Words automatically organize into semantic neighborhoods. The words "grapefruit" and "logarithm" are very far away from each other.

The word astronomy is exactly where it should be, between what it is, and what it describes. The algorithm also identifies what are our intuitions, of which words should lead in the neighborhood of introspection. So for instance, words such as "self," "guilt," "reason," "emotion," are very close to "introspection," but other words, suchas "red," "football," "candle," are just far away.

In August of 2012, I led my first expedition, taking a group of artists and scholars up the northwest coast of Greenland. The sheer size of the icebergs is humbling. The locals spoke to me of vast areas of sea ice that are no longer freezing over as they once did.

Greenland's melting glaciers are one of the largest contributing factors to rising sea levels. Experts predict ice-free Arctic summers as early as 2020. Sea levels are likely to rise between two and ten feet by century's end. The Maldives is the lowest and flattest country in the entire world.

CNN's John Sutter talks about his time in the Marine Corps. Sutter was injured while on duty in Iraq and had to leave the military. He decided to go back to school and become an actor. He says he was surprised by how difficult it was to transition from military to civilian life.

In the military, everything has meaning. Everything you do is either steeped in tradition or has a practical purpose. You can't smoke in the field because you don't want to give away your position. You don't touch your face -- you have to maintain a personal level of health and hygiene.

In the military, "there's no rank. Here you're just another body" In the civilian world, "you have a role, you have to know your role" "I was really, for the first time, discovering playwrights and characters and plays that had nothing to do with the military"

2.6 million babies die around the world before they're even one month old. That's the population of Vancouver. The shocking thing is: Why? In too many cases, we simply don't know, CNN's John D. Sutter says.

"We have no idea" why babies are dying, says Dr. Frank. "I want to fix it," he says. "That's why I'm trying to do what I'm doing. I want to make a difference" He says he's taking a new approach to the problem of babies dying.

At the time, in those front lines in the war on cancer, we had few tools. And the tools we did have couldn't differentiate between the cancer cells that we wanted to hit hard and those healthy cells. It's a drug called Herceptin that allowed us to precisely target HER2-positive breast cancer.

AIDS was a death sentence for doctors in San Francisco in the '80s. Now, things are better, but HIV/AIDS remains a terrible global challenge. antiretroviral therapy can virtually guarantee that a woman will not transmit the virus to her baby.

In sub-Saharan Africa we can test and treat pregnant women where rates are highest. This precision approach has cut by nearly half HIV transmission from mothers to baby in the last five years. We know who to target, what to target and how to target.

In Africa, babies are dying because of a bacterial infection transferred from the mother to the baby. Once we define the problem, we can prevent that death with something as cheap and safe as penicillin. With this approach, and with these interventions and others like them, I have no doubt that a precision public health approach can help our world achieve our 15-year goal.

The promise of precision public health is to bring these two worlds together, he says. Every day in the rich world, we're bringing incredible talent and tools to precisely target diseases, he adds. But it's not like that everywhere. In Ethiopia, parents delay picking the names for their new babies by a month or more.

Spending on war per person per year now amounts to about 249 dollars -- 249 dollars per person. That is roughly 12 times what we spend on foreign aid. The curbing of small arms is not going to solve the problem of war. But we can shift that balance.

LIFE Magazine commissioned me to create a panoramic photograph of the cast and crew of Baz Luhrmann's film Romeo + Juliet. Photography can be described as the recording of a single moment frozen within a fraction of time. Most of my time is spent up high, and I'm usually in a cherry picker or a crane.

Photographs are like a real-time puzzle, says photographer. "I'm compressing the day and night as I saw it, creating a unique harmony between these two very discordant worlds" "I have absolutely zero control when I get up there on any given day and capture photographs"

"Day to Night" is a series of photographs of the U.S. National Park Service. The series is inspired by the work of the late artist George Bierstadt. "It's about landscape, it's about color, and it's also about history," photographer says.

Photographer and his wife had to tape their feet into position every time he clicked the shutter on this image. The two most important things are patience and the power of observation, he says. "Time is this extraordinary thing that we never can really wrap our heads around," he says of his work.

Photographer captures the moment people share their experiences of the world around them. "The act of sharing has suddenly become more important than the experience itself," he says. "It's a powerful disconnect between what we think the human experience is and what it is evolving into"

Day to Night is a new way of seeing, compressing time, exploring the space-time continuum within a photograph. Photographing for anywhere from 15 to 30 hours and shooting over 1,500 images, I then choose the best moments of the day and night.

The Gauss Curve is trapped inside a transparent box as Dream in "The Sandman" comics. The curve is the supreme goddess of unreason, says the professor. "Beautiful mathematical explanations are not only for our pleasure," he says.

And if you look at the Fields Medal, often called the Nobel Prize for mathematics, you will find that France has more Fields medalists per person than any other country.

The highest piles correspond to those sites which somehow are better connected than the others, more pointed at than the other. The algorithm is based on the Galton Board experiment.

The Chinese believe certain animals get on better than the others. Parents choose specific years to give birth to babies, because they believe the team effort by the right combination of animals can give prosperity to families. We even refer to the zodiac when entering into romantic relations.

In 2012, the birthrate in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan increased by five percent. That was the last month for the Year of the Horse. The most undesirable animals, the Goat and Tiger, are at the top of the chart.

Many Chinese people make their investment decisions based on the zodiac sign index. Judgments are being made about your fortune or misfortune, your personality, career prospects and how you will do in a given year. China plays such an important role in the global economy and geopolitics.

The Chinese zodiac is a 12-year cycle labeled with animals, starting with a Rat and ending with a Pig. Most Westerners think of Greco-Roman zodiac, the signs divided into 12 months. The swing hater is sister to the swing voter -- they just can't decide!

Poverty is a problem like any other. Global poverty has powerful levers. Let's engage our collective passion for problem-solving and figure out what those levers are. Most of the world's poor are farmers. More than half engage in farming as a major source of income.

When farmers become more productive, they earn more income, they climb out of poverty, they feed their communities and they reduce environmental pressure. Most of the farmers I know are actually women. If we're going to put the future of humanity in one person's hands, then I'm really glad it's her.

Many smallholder farmers lack access to basic tools and knowledge. These are tools and techniques that date to the Bronze Age, and it's why many farmers are still very poor. But as a field practitioner, I believe these are actually very solvable problems if we just take the right strategies.

Ending poverty is simply a matter of delivering proven goods and services to people. We don't need more genius types right now. We just haven't delivered these things to everybody just yet. The humble delivery guy is going to end global poverty in our lifetime.

The program provides practical, hands-on training to farmers in the field every two weeks. It's kind of like Amazon for rural farmers. Farmers pay us little by little over time, covering most of our expenses. There are many companies, governments and nonprofits that have delivery armies.

Humanity has already invented effective tools to end poverty. We just need to deliver them. This talk is all about those levers, and why they make poverty a winnable fight in our lifetimes. In every field of human development, super-smart people have invented inexpensive, highly effective tools.

For the first time in human history, we have a vast amount of delivery infrastructure available to us. The world's companies, governments and non-profits have delivery armies that are fully capable of covering this relatively small area. If we are willing, every one of us has a role to play.

"We are an exceptional people. We've run marathons at a five-minute mile pace" "If we have the will, every one of us has a role to play" "It's incredibly possible to end extreme poverty. We just need to deliver proven goods and services"

40 million Americans are indebted for their passage to the new economy. Even a college grad earned 10 percent more in 2001 than she did in 2013. The worst of times can be the best of times, because certain truths flash up in ways that you can't ignore.

The U.S. owes more than $1.2 billion in student loans. The loans are used to pay for education and other services. The debt is a form of student loan debt. It is a way of paying for education, not a way to pay.

College is the new high school, we already say, but why stop there? People can be upsold on certifications and recertifications, master's degrees, doctoral degrees. Buy a degree, much like you do a Lexus of a Louis Vuitton bag, to distinguish yourself from others.

It is nearly impossible for an American to get discharged their student loan debts. Two out of three people who enroll are not going to find an adequate job. The future, for them, doesn't look particularly promising. And it is they who are going to suffer the most punishing forms of student debt.

Income-Based Tuition would link the cost of a major to the expected income. College administrators would be forced to manage costs better, to find innovative ways to do so. Users would be able to figure out how much money they will make from a given college and major.

Some college grads pay 25 percent of their income servicing their student debt. That kind if inequity would end when majors are priced more correctly, says author. For his generation, higher education was free because it was thought of as a public good. Not anymore.

The idea that nonviolent struggle is equivalent to street protests is a real problem. Nonviolent activists can neutralize the military by causing soldiers to defect. They can disrupt the economy through strikes and boycotts. Powerful opponents are not going to give people what they want just because they asked nicely.

A group of people in Guatemala called for the president to step down. The president refused, so the people took to the streets to demand his resignation. The people of Guatemala have shown that they can take action even if they don't have the power.

Nonviolent struggle is just as complex as military warfare, if not more so. Nonviolent activists around the world are getting better at grabbing headlines, but these isolated actions do very little if they're not part of a larger strategy. A general wouldn't march his troops into battle unless he had a plan to win the war.

nonviolent struggle is at least as powerful and as effective as violence. Most people associate this type of action with Gandhi and Martin Luther King. People have been using nonviolent action for thousands of years. Most of the rights that we have today in this country weren't handed to us.

India has been fighting the challenge of access, having enough schools, and enrollment. VR is going to play an incredibly important role in the history of mediums. It's the first medium that actually makes the jump from our internalization of an author's expression of an experience, to our experiencing it firsthand. The same thing happens when we look at the cave painting version of the story, the book about the mammoth hunt.

In all other mediums, your consciousness interprets the medium. Virtual reality bridges that gap. In VR today, we're more learning grammar than writing language. We've made 15 films in the last year at our VR company, Vrse. The potential for VR is enormous.

The New York Times film crew tries to break every rule in the book to see what they can achieve. The result is a giant rectangle that stretches from the top to the bottom of the screen. "We found that we have a unique, direct path into your senses, your emotions, even your body," says the film's director. "Music guides us how to feel. It deepens every experience"

"Waves of Grace" was a collaboration between Vrse, the United Nations, Gabo Arora, and Imraan Ismail. In virtual reality, composition is now where your consciousness exists and how the world moves around you. A close-up in VR means you're actually close up to someone.

VR makes anywhere and anyone feel local. That's why it works as an empathy machine. Our film "Clouds Over Sidra" takes you to a Syrian refugee camp. It's not using physical celluloid or paper or TV signals. It actually employs what we use to make sense of the world.

What if instead of verbally telling you about a dream, I could let you live inside that dream? What if you could surf gravitational waves on the edge of a black hole, or create galaxies from scratch, or communicate with each other not using words but using our raw thoughts? That's not a virtual reality anymore.

Warren Berger says design thinking teaches us to look sideways, to reframe, to refine, to experiment and, probably most importantly, ask those stupid questions. At the age of 10, I was told I was going to lose my hearing. I started thinking: What if we started designing for disability first -- not the norm? I also believe that people with disabilities have great potential to be designers within this design-thinking process.

In the United States, the law protects an employee's right to discuss their pay. But keeping salaries secret leads to what economists call "information asymmetry" In one famous example, writers in the Algonquin Round Table showed up for work with their salaries on their chests.

Economists warn that information asymmetry can cause markets to go awry. Two-thirds of everyone who is paid at the market rate said they felt they were underpaid. 60 percent said that they intended to quit, regardless of where they were.

Entrepreneurs and corporate leaders have been experimenting with sharing salaries for years. Openness remains the best way to ensure fairness, and pay transparency does that. When people know how they're being paid and how that pay compares to their peers', they're more likely to work hard.

Some companies post the formula for calculating pay, and others post the pay levels. The assumed reason is that if everybody knew what everybody got paid, then all hell would break loose. A thousand years ago, three brothers in Baghdad designed a device that was an automated organ. The organ could be trained to play various songs by using instructions encoded by placing pins on a rotating cylinder. In the 1700s, music-making machines became the playthings of the Parisian elite.

Inventors used paper to make the first programmable loom. The first machines were made in the 17th century in France. The machines were used to make patterns for the first musical instruments. The loom was later adapted to make more complex patterns.

In 1750, a programmable flute entertaining the Parisian elite would have been as powerful a clue as anything else at the time. Sometimes people invent things because they want to stay alive or feed their children. But just as often, new ideas come into the world simply because they're fun.

The author has asked people all over the world about the dilemma of speaking up. He says each of us have something called a range of acceptable behavior. When we step outside that range, we get punished in a variety of ways, he says.

CNN's John Sutter talks about how power determines a person's range. Sutter: "Your power determines your range. Your range isn't fixed; it's actually pretty dynamic. It expands and it narrows based on the context" "When we lack power, our range narrows," Sutter says.

Women have the same need as men to speak up, but they have barriers to doing so. What looks like a gender difference are really often just power differences in disguise. Women have a narrow range, and our double bind is very large. So we need to find ways to expand our range.

When I feel powerful, I feel confident, not fearful; I expand my own range. When other people see me as powerful, they grant me a wider range. We need tools to expand our range of acceptable behavior. Speaking up is risky, but these tools will lower your risk of speaking up.

perspective-taking is one of the most important tools we have to expand our range. When I take your perspective, and I think about what you really want, you're more likely to give me what I really want. We often get self-focused in a crisis.

When we take someone's perspective, it allows us to be ambitious and assertive, but still be likable. "My friend is going to be evicted unless I get him $2,000 immediately," he told a bank manager. "Oh! You don't want to rob the bank -- you want to take out a loan," the bank manager said.

When we advocate for others, we expand our range in our own eyes and the eyes of others, but we also earn strong allies. When we ask others for advice, they like us because we flatter them, and we're expressing humility. And this doesn't just work with salespeople; it works with parents.

The self-promotion double bind is that if we don't advertise our accomplishments, no one notices, and if we do, we're not likable. Expertise gives us credibility. When we have high power, we already have credibility. We only need good evidence.

Lizzie Wolf asks people to describe a passion of theirs to her. When we tap into our passion, we give ourselves the courage to speak up, she says. Tapping into passion even works when we come across as too weak, Wolf says.

CO2 emissions are expected to continue to grow for the next 30 years. The bulk of the growth comes from the developing countries. China has made the choice to run on coal. The United States has an alternative. Eastern Europe, still very heavily committed to natural gas and to coal. China has many fewer choices and a much harder row to hoe. The OECD Europe has a choice. It has renewables.

Between one and three one-gigawatt coal plants are being turned on around the world. Every 100 of those plants will use up between one percent and three percent of the Earth's climate budget. New nuclear plants are on the drawing boards around the world. They say they can deliver power for 5 cents a kilowatt hour. The second alternative that could be there in time is utility-scale solar backed up with natural gas. Outdated regulations and yesterday's mindsets are holding new nuclear back.

About 1,800 of these weapons are on high alert, which means they can be launched within 15 minutes of a presidential command. "I know this is a bummer of an issue, and maybe you have that -- what was it? -- psychic fatigue that we heard about a little bit earlier," says CNN's John Sutter.

Nuclear weapons are vulnerable. We have solid evidence that terrorists are trying to get ahold of them. Nuclear weapons should be ended on the 100th anniversary of its inception. It has to be about strategies for mutually assured prosperity or, at the very least, mutually assured survival. By 2045, we will have held billions of people hostage to the threat of nuclear annihilation.

The more people share their knowledge, the better they do on every metric. Givers spend a lot of time trying to help other people and improve the team. Takers tend to rise quickly but also fall quickly in most jobs. And they fall at the hands of matchers.

Hiring and screening and team building is not about bringing in the givers; it's about weeding out the takers. We're actually pretty bad at figuring out who's a taker, especially on first impressions. The givers will be generous because they don't have to worry about the consequences.

The difference between agreeable and disagreeable people can be seen in their behavior. The more giving you are, the more likely it is that you will make a difference to someone else's life. The most giving people are often the ones who make the most difference.

Cancer researchers are working on ways to make regular screening for many types of cancers much more accessible. The silver bullet in this case are tiny vesicles, little escape pods regularly shed by cells called exosomes. Exosomes are important biomarkers that provide an early-warning system for the development of cancer.

Exosomes contain surface receptors, proteins and other genetic material collected from their cell of origin. When absorbed by a neighboring cell, exosomes release their contents into the receiving cell, and can set in motion fundamental changes in gene expression. Currently, no automated exosome isolation system exists to make regular screening economically accessible.

Cancer is emotionally draining and, for many, financially destructive. The idea here is that the separation process for screening could be as simple as processing a sample of urine, blood or saliva. A second core source of power is wealth. Money creates the ability to buy results and to buy almost any other kind of power. Power is something we are often uncomfortable talking about. There are three laws of power worth examining. Power begets more power, and so does powerlessness. The only thing that keeps law number three from leading to a situation where only one person has all the power is how we apply laws one and two.

In a democracy, power is supposed to reside with the people. To read power means to pay attention to as many texts of power as you can. In this case, that means understanding who has the power and who doesn't. In the end, it's the people who have the power.

Power is the ability to make others do what you would have them do. It governs how any form of government works. The molecular causes of Alzheimer's are still debated. Most neuroscientists believe that the disease begins when amyloid beta begins to accumulate. Too much is released, or not enough is cleared away, and the synapse begins to pile up.

Scientists are betting big on the simplest solution: keep amyloid plaques from reaching that tipping point. By mid-stage Alzheimer's, we have massive inflammation and tangles and all-out war at the synapse and cell death. So the cure for Alzheimer's will likely be a preventative medicine.

The way we live can influence the accumulation of amyloid plaques. We've all inherited our genes from our moms and our dads. Some of these genes will increase our risk and some will decrease it. If you're like Alice in "Still Alice," you've inherited a rare genetic mutation.

Scientists believe that poor sleep hygiene might actually be a predictor of Alzheimer's. A single night of sleep deprivation leads to an increase in amyloid beta. High blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, smoking, high cholesterol, have all been shown to increase our risk.

Aerobic exercise has been shown in many studies to decrease amyloid beta in animal models of the disease. Some autopsy studies have shown that as many as 80 percent of people with Alzheimer's also had cardiovascular disease. So a heart-healthy Mediterranean lifestyle and diet can help to counter the tipping of this scale.

In the Nun Study, 678 nuns, all over the age of 75, were followed for more than two decades. Despite the presence of plaques and tangles and brain shrinkage, the nuns who had belonged to these brains showed no signs of having the disease while they were alive. Scientists think it's because these nuns had a high level of cognitive reserve.

If you have Alzheimer's, three of your synapses are damaged or destroyed. Building an Alzheimer's-resistant brain means learning to speak Italian, meeting new friends, reading a book, or listening to a great TED Talk. You don't want to simply retrieve information you've already learned. You want to pave new neural roads.

Alzheimer's doesn't mean you're dying tomorrow. Diagnosis doesn't have to be. Keep living. You won't lose your emotional memory. You'll still be able to understand love and joy. And you are more than what you can remember.

Under 100 percent sea ice in the dead of winter, bowhead whales are singing. Sound transmits very well underwater, much better than it does in air, so signals can be heard over great distances. Arctic marine mammals have to hear each other, and they also have to listen for cues in the environment.

Climate change and decreases in sea ice are also altering the underwater soundscape of the Arctic. The sounds are inaudible above water depending on where you are and the time of year. But the underwaterSoundscape can be as noisy as any jungle or rainforest.

Decreases in sea ice have allowed humans to occupy the Arctic more often. With less seasonal sea ice, subarctic species are moving north. The number of storms and the intensity of storms in the Arctic has been increasing. All of this is raising noise levels in a previously quiet ocean.

Arctic marine mammals are used to very high levels of noise at certain times of the year. They use sound to study their habitat, to keep in communication with each other, to navigate, to detect predators and prey. Air guns, which produce loud, low-frequency "whoomps" every 10 to 20 seconds, changed the swimming and vocal behavior of whales.

The Arctic embodies this disconnect between what we see on the surface and what's going on underwater. The future "you" has to be like an aging movie star who has been made to believe that there is a possibility of a world which is completely, wholly, self-obsessively in love with itself.

I'm trying to redefine AI to get away from this classical notion of machines that intelligently pursue objectives. There are three principles involved. Turing: "Can you switch the machine off?" as Turing suggested. The question is: Is it going to let you switch it off? If we do it the classical way, we give it the objective of, "Fetch the coffee, I must fetch the coffee," so obviously the PR2 has been listening to my talk.

Human-compatible AI is the first step in what we're trying to do with human- compatible AI. Just because you behave badly doesn't mean the robot is going to copy your behavior. It's going to understand your motivations and maybe help you resist them if appropriate.

Scientists have been monitoring ocean acidification for over two decades. As more carbon dioxide has entered the ocean, the seawater pH has gone down, which basically means there has been an increase in ocean acidity. The oceans cover two-thirds of our planet.

There has already been an increase in ocean acidity of 26 percent since pre-industrial times, which is directly due to human activities. Unless we can start slowing down our carbon dioxide emissions, we're expecting an increase of 170 percent by the end of this century. This rate of acidification is 10 times faster than any acidification in our oceans for over 55 million years.

As ocean acidity increases, the concentration of carbonate ions in seawater decrease. These ions are basically the building blocks for many marine species to make their shells. And at even even lower levels, they can actually begin to dissolve. So ocean acidification could affect right up through the food chain.

By the end of this century, 70 percent of all known cold-water corals in the entire ocean will be surrounded by seawater that is dissolving their coral structure. The only way of doing that is by reducing our carbon dioxide emissions.

Oceans have absorbed 25 percent of all of the carbon dioxide that we have emitted. As more carbon dioxide enters the ocean, the seawater pH goes down. Only about one in 10 gets the eight to 10 hours of sleep per night recommended by sleep scientists.

Around the time of puberty, teenagers experience a delay in their biological clock. This is driven in part by a shift in the release of the hormone melatonin. Teenagers' bodies wait to start releasing melatonin until around 11pm. This means that waking a teenager up at 6am is the biological equivalent of waking an adult.

Sleep-deprived teens are 55 percent more likely to have used alcohol in the past month. For each hour of lost sleep, there is a 38 percent increase in feeling sad or hopeless. Teens who skip out on sleep are at increased risk for a host of physical health problems.

Schools around the country should start middle and high schools no earlier than 8:30am, author says. "Why should we delay start times for teenagers? We need to toughen them up so they're ready for the real world," he asks. "Think about the tremendous power of sleep," he says.

CNN's John Defterios explores the idea of a basic income guarantee. It's a monthly grant, enough to pay for your basic needs: food, shelter, education. The philosopher Thomas More first hinted at it in his book, "Utopia," 500 years ago.

In 1974, Dauphin, Canada, guaranteed everyone in the town a basic income. For four years, all went well. But then a new government was voted into power, and the new Canadian cabinet saw little point to the expensive experiment.

The hospitalization rate decreased by as much as 8.5 percent. Domestic violence incidents were down, as were mental health complaints. The only ones who worked a little less were new mothers and students. Similar results have since been found in countless other experiments around the globe.

Dauphin's basic income guarantee would cost 500 billion dollars a year. It would be funded by a negative income tax, which would be topped up as soon as you fall below the poverty line. In that scenario, according to our economists' best estimates, for a net cost of 175 billion -- a quarter of US military spending, one percent of GDP -- you could lift all impoverished Americans out of poverty.

James Madison was the "Einstein" of the US Constitution. He thought he had designed a constitution that was against political parties. Today that same constitutional technology is still in use not only in the US, but in places like Canada, India, South Africa, Brazil.

Scientists have been able to leverage the immune system in the fight against cancer. Over 600 clinical trials are open, actively recruiting patients to explore immunotherapy.

Even a cancer as small as one centimeter in diameter harbors over a hundred million different cells. The key to cancer and curing cancer is early detection. Only 15 percent of women are detected at stage one, whereas the vast majority, 70 percent, are detected in stages three and four. The current best ways to screen cancer fall into one of three categories. Medical procedures are the gold standard; they are highly invasive and require a large infrastructure.

Cancer cells grow and die faster than normal cells, and when they die, DNA is shed into the blood system. Most of the DNA that's detected will be from healthy cells. However, there will be a small amount, less than one percent, that comes from the cancer cells.

The genome is a composition of all the genetic information encoded by DNA in an organism. Ultimately, we have information of billions of letters that output from this run. The key, then, is to see whether we're able to detect these recurrences of cancers earlier than with standard methods.

At day 340, we see the rise in the cancer DNA in the blood. That means we are catching this cancer over a hundred days earlier than traditional methods. The next time you hear the word "cancer," I want you to add to the emotions: hope.

Beauty is sculpted by factors that contribute to the survival of the group. Average faces represent the central tendencies of a group. People with mixed features represent different populations. Many people find mixed-race individuals attractive and inbred families less so.

Charles Darwin wrote that the sight of the peacock's tail made him physically ill. Darwin couldn't explain it with his theory of natural selection, so he developed the theory of sexual selection. In 10 generations, 98 percent of a population has a green preference. Attractive faces activate parts of our visual cortex in the back of the brain. Studies suggest our brain automatically responds to beauty by linking vision and pleasure. We also have a "beauty is good" stereotype embedded in the brain. Our brains seem to reflexively associate beauty and good. We need to understand these kinds of implicit biases if we are to overcome them.

Sialic acid is a sugar that is found at certain levels on all of the cells in your body. It's actually quite common on your cells. But for some reason, cancer cells tend to have more than a normal, healthy cell would have.

The sugar coating on our cells is like the sugar coating of a peanut M and M. The immune cells go around and taste all the cells in your body. Once in a while, a cell might taste bad, and when those immune cells get the bad taste, they launch an all-out strike and kill those cells.

When an immune cell snuggles up against a cancer cell to take a taste, it's looking for signs of disease. But if that cancer cell has a dense forest of that sugar, sialic acid, well, it starts to taste pretty good. People who have meaning in life are more resilient, do better in school and at work, and live longer. Belonging comes from being in relationships where you're valued for who you are intrinsically and where you value others as well. True belonging springs from love and it's a choice -- you can choose to cultivate belonging with others.

For many people, belonging is the most essential source of meaning. For others, the key to meaning is the second pillar: purpose. Purpose is less about what you want than what you give. The key to purpose is using your strengths to serve others.

Without something worthwhile to do, people flounder. Belonging, purpose, transcendence are the third and fourth pillars of meaning. The fourth pillar is storytelling, the story you tell yourself about yourself. The third pillar of meaning is about stepping beyond yourself, but in a completely different way.

Emotions are used to explain many things, exploited by our politicians, manipulated by algorithms. Emotional intelligence is considered so important, that this is taught in our schools and businesses. But despite all of this, I sometimes wonder if the way we think about emotions is becoming impoverished.

Emotions are not simple reflexes, but complex systems. They are shaped not just by our bodies, but by our thoughts, our language. What if we were to think again about those odd, untranslatable words for emotions? What if some cultures feel an emotion more intensely just because they've bothered to name and talk about it?

In the 17th century, a Swiss man fell ill with an illness known as "nostalgia" The illness was thought to be caused by the man's love of the city of Basel. Today, the illness is thought to have been caused by a lack of emotional connection.

The last person to die from nostalgia was an American soldier fighting during the First World War in France. Today, not only does the word mean something different -- a sickening for a lost time rather than a lost place -- but homesickness itself is seen as less serious.

The Baining people of Papua New Guinea speak of "awumbuk," a feeling of heaviness. "Amae" is a Japanese word that means "to hand over" or "to let go" This might be a little simplistic, but it is tantalizing to think about.

"Dépaysement" is a French word for unfamiliar place. It evokes the giddy disorientation that you feel in an unfamiliar place, says historian. Learning new and unusual words for emotions will help attune us to the more finely grained aspects of our inner lives.

There are nearly 100 subtypes of HIV, with new subtypes being discovered regularly. HIV in the developed world is almost all of one subtype: subtype B. Some subtypes are more likely to become drug-resistant or progress to AIDS faster.

HIV has a potential to transform itself into a new and different virus every time it infects a cell. The genetic difference between HIV subtypes from different patients may be as much as 35 percent. Despite the remarkable progress we've made in reversing the epidemic, the truth is that we are just a few viral mutations away from disaster.

The myths about the hymen have lived on for centuries because they have cultural significance. They have been used as a powerful tool in the effort to control women's sexuality. Women are still mistrusted, shamed, harmed and subjected to honor killings if they don't bleed on their wedding night.

The "hymen" is a piece of tissue that covers the vaginal opening. It can be broken, but it is not the same thing as a "hug" or a "tongue" It is a part of the woman's body, and should not be destroyed.
